headline: Gunmen Kill 16 at Nursing Home in Yemen Started by Mother Teresa
text: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — A nursing home founded by Mother Teresa and run by Christian nuns in the southern Yemeni city of Aden was transformed into an execution ground on Friday, when four gunmen tied up at least 16 people inside and killed them, officials said.

headline: ‘NCIS’ at 300: The 5 Most Compelling Episodes
text: On March 15, the CBS crime procedural “NCIS” will air its 300th episode. As I write in my look back at 13 years of the series, reaching that number is a rare feat, and it’s usually a fairly circumspect type of show that does it. But while it might be easy to think of “NCIS” as comfort food, it is deeper and more ambitious than most people realize. Here are my nominations as the five most compelling “NCIS” episodes — ones that went unexpected places or showed especially deft writing and acting. (You can watch them all on CBS’s subscription streaming service, CBS All Access; the show’s first 12 seasons are also currently on Netflix.) Agree? Disagree? What episodes really got your attention? Offer up your choices in the comments section.

headline: ‘NCIS’: Meat and Potatoes TV, but Still Popular
text: For a prime-time, scripted American television series to reach 300 episodes is a towering achievement. Fewer than 20 have done it. Yet attaining that milestone also practically guarantees a certain amount of disdain from the type of TV watcher who wants to project coolness. “Lassie.” “Bonanza.” “Law & Order.” “My Three Sons.” Square shows all, each in the 300 club.

headline: More Support for Early Exposure to Peanuts to Prevent Allergies
text: LOS ANGELES — Evidence is accumulating that food allergies in children might be prevented by feeding peanuts and other allergenic food to infants in their first year of life, researchers reported here Friday.

headline: Bud Collins, Who Covered Tennis With Authority and Flash, Dies at 86
text: Bud Collins, the passionate, often irreverent face of tennis for nearly half a century in his Wimbledon broadcasts and his newspaper and magazine columns, died on Friday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 86.

headline: A Sandal’s Name Has Dolce & Gabbana Under Fire Again
text: PARIS — The Italian designers of Dolce & Gabbana are no strangers to scandal. After inflammatory comments about gay adoption and accusations of racial stereotyping on the runway last year, the latest apparent misstep by the duo came this week, after the brand listed a pair of $2,395 shoes on its website as “slave sandals with pompoms” and set in motion a social media firestorm.

headline: At Dior, Dramatic Lips and Clumpy Mascara
text: “It’s all about contradictions,” said Dior’s makeup director, Peter Philips, about the look he created for the house’s fall/winter 2016 show today. This season’s collection mixed prints with patterns — so Philips said he wanted the makeup to reflect a similar attitude. The look he had in mind, he said, was “really sophisticated, with intense, almost dangerous lips on this beautiful, even, alabaster skin, and rebellious clumpy lashes.”

headline: Paying Employees to Lose Weight
text: IF your employer offered you $550 to lose weight, an amount that would be deducted from your health insurance premiums next year, would that provide the motivation to help you finally shed those pounds?

headline: Woolly Mullein: The City Cactus
text: The seed-packed woody stalk of the common or woolly mullein stands out this time of year like an urban saguaro. Once covered with pale green leaves and flowers as yellow as summer, it is now leafless, coarse and bleached, anchored in the poor soil it prefers.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 2: State of the Union
text: Before delving into the secret donations and the breast-cancer-clinic chess match that dominates this episode, let’s take a moment and bow down before the glory that is Ellen Burstyn.

headline: 2 Who Helped Expose Flint Water Crisis Win PEN Awards
text: Two women who sounded early and persistent alarms about the quality of the water in Flint, Mich., will receive the Freedom of Expression Courage Award from PEN America, the group announced on Friday.

headline: T Toasts Marie-Amélie Sauvé With a Dinner in Paris
text: There were plenty of reasons to celebrate last night in Paris: We’re nearing the end of a fashion month that’s seen lots of excitement; our spring men’s style issue hits newsstands inside The Times this Sunday, March 6; and two weeks ago, T announced the appointment of Marie-Amélie Sauvé as our new fashion director. Last night, T’s editor in chief, Deborah Needleman, hosted a dinner to welcome and honor her at Le Grand Véfour, the storied Beaux-Arts establishment — and oldest continually operating restaurant in Paris — where Napoleon and Josephine used to rendezvous. Friends and supporters including Charlotte Rampling, Alber Elbaz, Christian Louboutin, Shayne Oliver, Nicolas Ghesquière, Liya Kebede and many others enjoyed lobster, Champagne and conversation — well into the Parisian night.

headline: T Celebrates Marie-Amélie Sauvé
text: Editor in chief Deborah Needleman hosted a dinner last night at Le Grand Véfour in Paris to honor our new fashion director.

headline: The Return of Joe Bataan, the Boogaloo King
text: Joe Bataan was bouncing around behind his keyboard onstage at the B. B. King Blues Club in Times Square, turning to cue his 14-piece band and clearly enjoying himself. It was a good crowd for a Wednesday night, and the dancers were getting after it, so he was mixing in a dose of mambo with his signature doo-wop-tinged Latin soul songs like “Subway Joe” and “Ordinary Guy.” Between numbers he pointed out friends in the crowd, including a man he introduced as “Lindy from the Dragons,” a comrade from Mr. Bataan’s wild days running with New York street gangs in the 1950s.

headline: Big Man on a Global Campus
text: At a meet-and-greet reception for faculty members in early January, Andrew Hamilton, New York University’s energetic new president, told a jokey story on the theme of how warmly he had been welcomed to the city.

headline: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall Marry in London
text: Rupert Murdoch, the executive chairman of News Corporation, and the former model Jerry Hall were married on Friday at a centuries-old mansion in central London, weeks after announcing their engagement.

headline: Can Labor Still Turn Out the Vote?
text: ON Labor Day in 1960, John F. Kennedy kicked off the final push of his presidential campaign in Cadillac Square in Detroit with a rousing speech to thousands of United Auto Workers members. It was a nod to the immense clout of organized labor.

headline: Derby-Caliber Gelding Has Connections Dreaming of the Preakness Instead
text: Jason Servis watched with pride when John, his brother and fellow thoroughbred trainer, sent Smarty Jones to victories in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes in 2004. But his joy turned to sadness when the long-shot Birdstone upset Smarty Jones’s Triple Crown bid by one length in the Belmont Stakes. Sadness turned to dismay when the colt never ran again.

headline: Far From Ireland, a ‘Taste of Home’ in the Bronx
text: Prime Cuts Irish Butchers caters to an Irish enclave in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx with boiling bacon, rashers and soda bread.

headline: Rolling Brogues and Boiling Bacon at Prime Cuts Irish Butchers
text: Shamrocks, Irish flags and Kelly-green awnings line Katonah Avenue in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx. The neighborhood isn’t dressed up for St. Patrick’s Day, though. This area has been the first stop for many Irish immigrants for decades, and many have stuck around.

headline: E.U. Presses for Accord With Turkey to Ease Flow of Migrants
text: BRUSSELS — Leaders of the European Union are aiming to push Turkey closer to an agreement on Monday intended to make the flow of migrants to the Continent more orderly and relieve the fast-growing humanitarian crisis in Greece.

headline: Mets’ Jacob deGrom Reluctantly Accepts $607,000 Salary for 2016
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets quietly sent out a news release Friday morning regarding some financial housekeeping. Each year, teams assign salaries to players who have not played in the major leagues long enough to be eligible for arbitration; most of the time, the player and the team reach an agreement on salary, but in some instances, they do not.

headline: Emanuel Ungaro: Fall 2016 RTW

headline: The Future of Grizzly Bears
text: The 1973 Endangered Species Act, a landmark environmental measure much detested by developers and other commercial interests, is credited with saving the bald eagle, the peregrine falcon, the American alligator and the gray wolf, among other species. If the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service has its way, the grizzly bears in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem will soon join that company of once-close-to-extinction creatures that no longer needed the act’s protection. On Thursday, the service proposed to remove grizzlies in the Yellowstone region — meaning the national park, and the states of Idaho, Montana and Wyoming — from the endangered species list, whose protections the bears have enjoyed since 1975.

headline: Man Convicted of Killing 3 Brooklyn Merchants Gets 75 Years in Prison
text: A traveling clothing salesman was sentenced on Friday to 75 years to life in prison for killing three merchants in Brooklyn in a series of attacks that had shopkeepers on alert for months, prosecutors said.

headline: The Way Things Work
text: ANY MAN-MADE SYSTEM risks becoming so insular it is rendered nonsensical for those outside it. The complexities, anachronisms and demands of the current fashion system almost read like a cautionary tale. Fashion is more democratic and more popular than ever before, and yet the industry’s problems can be summed up by the simple fact that you can’t buy a swimsuit in summer or a heavy coat in winter.

headline: Mets’ Longtime Drill Sergeant Keeps Everything in Line at Camp
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — As another spring training workout day came to a close, a group of Mets pitchers gathered on a remote field for one last round of pitchers’ fielding practice, or P.F.P.s, as they are called. The players knelt in a semicircle on the infield as instructed, and a coach began hitting hard, chopping ground balls toward their chests.

headline: Review: La Otra Orilla and Its Flamenco Bizarro
text: Forget about a dress with an enchantingly long ruffle. How about a flamenco dancer who looks like she stepped out of a J. Crew catalog in a blue striped top and slim navy pants? That, apparently, signals innovation. (Or, as you may be thinking, the exact opposite.)

headline: 3 Top Officials Leaving Coney Island Hospital After Patient’s Death
text: Gisele Soto was in agony.

headline: Supreme Court Blocks Louisiana Abortion Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday temporarily blocked a Louisiana law that its opponents say would leave the state with only one abortion clinic. The court gave no reasons, though it did say that its order was “consistent with” one last June that blocked part of a Texas abortion law.

headline: Time With the Tribe
text: For Dr. Paul Frank, the director of the Fifth Avenue Dermatology Surgery & Laser Center at 86th Street in Manhattan, weekends mean meditation, fitness and plenty of family time.

headline: How Paul Jarrod Frank, a Cosmetic Dermatologist, Spends His Sundays
text: Dr. Paul Jarrod Frank is the director of the Fifth Avenue Dermatology Surgery & Laser Center at 86th Street in Manhattan. Each year he performs over 300 surgeries, including liposuction, and over 1,000 noninvasive procedures, making him somewhat of a celebrity among certain sculpted New Yorkers. Dr. Frank, a 46-year-old dermatologist, grew up on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and attended the Horace Mann School. In his youth, his favorite place to hang out on Friday nights was the steps of the Met. “It’s where I had my first kiss and my first drink,” he said. Dr. Frank lives on East 102nd Street with his wife, Diana, 44, a photographer, and their two children, Aidan, 10, and Avery, 8. Both attend his alma mater. ALIX STRAUSS

headline: Undercover: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Jun Takahashi’s latest designs.

headline: California Gas Leak Threatens Jerry Brown’s Image as a Climate Change Hero
text: LOS ANGELES — In his final term as California’s governor, Jerry Brown has made the battle against climate change a signature issue: He is fighting to vastly reduce the state’s emissions of greenhouse gases, to accelerate the move to electric cars and to rewire the state’s electrical grid. In December, he had a star turn with world leaders at the United Nations climate change conference in Paris.

headline: Noted Pianist Piotr Anderszewski Takes a Break From His Career
text: The superb Polish pianist Piotr Anderszewski does not want to become a “200-concert-per-year performing machine,” as he said in a recent interview with the website Humans of New York. The constant pressure and high expectations make it difficult for an artist to have fun, experiment and “stay in your dreams,” he explained.

headline: Review: At Kishuya, Some Noodles to Go With That Drink
text: Some noodle places try to be distinctive by including sushi, tempura or yakitori selections with the featured item. Kishuya in Hartsdale has added a happy hour, with a banner in its window proclaiming ramen and izakaya, which is sort of a Japanese version of a small tavern.

headline: Here’s Hoping Earth Imagery Isn’t Too Routine to Inspire
text: Much has been written about the remarkable achievements of NASA astronaut Scott Kelly and his Russian counterpart, cosmonaut Mikhail Kornienko, during their (340-day) Year in Space mission aboard the International Space Station. Daniel Victor had a fine overview on Tuesday and make sure to revisit Kenneth Chang’s fascinating package on Kelly and the long mission, in which, as he notes, Kelly and Kornienko experienced 10,880 sunrises* and sunsets in those 340 days.

headline: Review: At INC, a Menu of Conversation Starters
text: After our first visit to INC American Bar & Kitchen in New Brunswick, my wife asked whether I had noticed that we had not received any bread while waiting for our appetizers.

headline: Review: At Fish on Main, a World of Difference
text: Ayhan Hassan has gone upscale with his newest venture, Fish on Main. In 1980, Mr. Hassan opened his first restaurant, Ayhan’s Shish-Kebab, in Port Washington. He now owns five Shish-Kebabs in Nassau County.

headline: U.S. Pays to Feed and Shelter Cuban Migrants Stranded in Costa Rica
text: MIAMI — The United States government has been paying to feed and shelter thousands of Cubans trying to migrate to the United States, in what critics consider another sign of the lopsided treatment provided to Cubans under American law.

headline: A Dress That Moves — With a Life of Its Own
text: For the designer Hussein Chalayan, technology is an essential part of designing a collection. It’s evident in the way he carefully describes his ideas for his performative runway shows — but also in the way he explains his process.”For me, it always starts with the idea and the piece I’m making. The way it’s presented comes after,” he says. (Today, Chalayan showed his fall/winter 2016 collection in Paris, which was full of dresses and blouses printed with technical drawings.)

headline: Review: At Vespa, Italian Authenticity With a Contemporary Vroom
text: Vespa in Italian means wasp or hornet, both of which suggest a “buzz.” Certainly a buzz exists at the newish Vespa restaurant in Westport, with its stylish décor, farm-to-table cuisine and genial atmosphere. And, at least when I visited, there wasn’t a single Vespa, an Italian motor scooter, parked outside.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Yamamoto, who just opened a retrospective in New York, debuts his fall collection.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Looks (and Listens) for Authenticity in Its Tunes
text: On the most recent episode of the new HBO drama “Vinyl” — a “Mad Men” for the 1970s record industry created by Terence Winter, Martin Scorsese, Mick Jagger and Rich Cohen — the fictional proto-punk band Nasty Bits gets its big break in front of label executives eager to find a fresh sound.

headline: Paris Fashion Week’s Best-Kept Secret
text: Until recently, Paris had been devoid of food delivery services, much less gluten-free and dairy-free options. But the luxury sector executive Isabella Capece Galeota has introduced a solution — which coincides with the French capital’s fashion week. She and her husband, Xavier Barroux, decided to soft-launch their Maisie Café ahead of its official May opening near Place Vendôme to bring healthy snack alternatives to the show-going masses. The menu includes fresh coconut-water-based, cold-pressed juices; three types of shakes (banana, avocado and espresso); a cucumber detox; and chocolate or fruit granolas. By Capece Galeota’s count, they’ve already distributed several hundred M/M-branded bottles, which bodes well for such an endeavor in a gastronomic epicenter. “Here, people will not eat or drink something because it’s good for them — you have the added pressure of making it taste good, as well,” she says. “This is the capital of gourmet food, so you have to make gourmet juices.”

headline: Ben Carson's Path to the Exit
text: Ben Carson formally announced on Friday that he was ending his Republican presidential campaign. Here are some of the most emblematic moments of his bid, from debate mishaps and interview gaffes to campaign shake-ups.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Art Rules
text: Young artists challenged the status quo with their installations in the defunct post office at Moynihan Station, and the New York art establishment mingled at the Armory Show on the Hudson Piers.

headline: It’s Not a Reading, It’s Literary Cabaret
text: When Amanda Foreman and Lucas Wittmann founded House of SpeakEasy, the organization behind their literary cabaret series, “Seriously Entertaining,” they wanted to break from the format of typical bookstore readings and hark back to the performative styles of authors like Dickens and Twain.

headline: Migrant Crisis Alters E.U. Calculations for Greece as Its Debt Struggle Continues
text: ATHENS — When Greece’s debt crisis threatened to sink the European Union’s single currency last summer, the rest of Europe, led by Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, ganged up to deliver the Greek government a stern message: Overcome your domestic political problems and do what is necessary to hold the Continent together.

headline: Restoring a Music Room’s Grandeur at the Rosen House
text: On Feb. 16, 1946, about 60 people witnessed the first concert with tickets at what would become the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah. They did so in comfort befitting the ornate setting, seated in plush velvet chairs facing the stage in the grandly appointed music room of the treasure-filled home now known as the Rosen House.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic Dives Into Brahms’s ‘German Requiem’
text: The New York Philharmonic’s program this week could hardly be simpler or more moving. It consists of a single hourlong choral work by Brahms, “Ein Deutsches Requiem” (“A German Requiem”), exquisitely prepared and performed.
