headline: Review: In ‘Ropes,’ a High-Wire Act of Brotherly Bonding
text: Ever since Cain and Abel, many stories have been told about brothers who do not get along. A variation on this eternal theme is currently being presented by the Two River Theater in Red Bank in the United States premiere of “Ropes.”

headline: Embracing Art to Escape the Holocaust’s Shadow
text: Ruth Jacobsen, 83, a collage artist, and Judith Leiber, 95, a handbag designer, built creative careers after enduring Nazi repression.

headline: 2 Holocaust Survivors Turn to Art to Reclaim Lost Lives
text: The collage artist Ruth Jacobsen, 83, and the handbag designer Judith Leiber, 95, both Holocaust survivors, have relied on the creative process and a strong-willed entrepreneurial spirit to reclaim their lives and break glass ceilings for women in the United States.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Art Rules
text: March 1: While the political world had everyone in a tizzy, the New York art world exploded last week with fairs, exhibitions and a new museum. One fair was the Spring/Break Art Show in the main post office on Eighth Avenue and 31st Street. The art installations had a youthful exuberance. More than 7,000 attended the opening festivities.

headline: Review: 2 Sisters Navigate 100 Years of Black History in ‘Having Our Say’
text: Don’t call them old maids. Don’t call them African-Americans. Sadie and Bessie Delany, holding forth at Long Wharf Theater in Emily Mann’s Tony-nominated 1995 play, “Having Our Say: The Delany Sisters’ First 100 Years,” are very particular about things, whether the exact placement of a spotlessly white cutwork tablecloth, the precise thickness of an orange slice for ambrosia, or the careful arrangement of sparkling goblets and candlesticks. And when you have lived past the century mark, you are entitled to have things just as you want them. And husbands were not among the things they wanted. They were “too smart, too independent for most men,” Bessie says.

headline: Bill Cunningham’s Evening Hours
text: Mr. Cunningham covers events in March.

headline: Review: The Minnesota Orchestra’s White Light and White Heat
text: A few years ago, Osmo Vanska and his Minnesota Orchestra experienced a bitter inversion of the old maxim. How do you not get to Carnegie Hall? Lockout, lockout, lockout.

headline: Review: ‘Neal Brennan 3 MICS’ Comes at Comedy From Several Directions
text: Neal Brennan’s three-cornered show at the Lynn Redgrave Theater doesn’t quite add up to a play; it’s more like listening to a decent comedy album while eavesdropping on someone’s therapy sessions. Think of it as an effort to present in stage form the dichotomy that many comics have written or talked about over the years: that humor is how they deal with personal pain.

headline: Regina King Has So Many Stories to Tell
text: LOS ANGELES — Regina King’s house has a cozy seat at the foot of a hill in a section of the Los Feliz neighborhood here. The house isn’t far from the street but fosters an aura of secluded serenity anyway: A grapefruit tree guards the property. Off the rear patio is a small room with a vintage Pac-Man console and a signed LP of Prince’s “Controversy” on the wall.

headline: Your Evening Briefing.
text: Your Evening Briefing.

headline: Donald Trump Is Spending Nearly $2 Million on TV Ads
text: Donald J. Trump is dropping close to $1 million apiece in Ohio and Florida for television ads, two people tracking media spending said, in a signal that the sustained advertising assault against him is taking a toll.

headline: Art Gone to Hell: A Boschian Bestiary
text: Most of Hieronymus Bosch’s surviving paintings are now on display in his hometown. Here’s a guide to a few of them.

headline: For Hieronymus Bosch, One Helluva Homecoming
text: ’S-HERTOGENBOSCH, the Netherlands — Hieronymus Bosch died 500 years ago, his soul dispatched to parts unknown — perhaps oblivion, perhaps heavenly peace, perhaps a hellscape of his own invention. His reputation, however, resides in earthly paradise, with two blockbuster exhibitions this year, drawing tens of thousands to admire his slavering, fluttering, waddling abominations.

headline: As Olympics Near and Zika Spreads, No Talk of a Plan B
text: How confident is Scott Blackmun, the chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, that the Zika virus will not ruin the Rio Summer Olympics or render them unsafe for athletes, workers and spectators?

headline: Your Back Pages: Readers Share Dylan Memories
text: This week, we published an article about the new Bob Dylan Archive in Tulsa, Okla. The lyrics, letters, photographs and other ephemera among the more than 6,000 items in the archive represent decades of American history. Arguably just as important as Mr. Dylan’s items are the memories carried by generations of fans. So we asked readers to share something from their own personal Dylan archives: the vinyl copy of “Blonde on Blonde” that survived moves, marriages and children; the ticket stub that conjures mental images of an inspiring performance; the bootlegged recording from the show.

headline: She Wanted to Do Her Research. He Wanted to Talk ‘Feelings.’
text: Honolulu — OVER the past two decades as a professor, I’ve grown thousands of plants, studying how their biology shifts in response to our changing environment. Soon I’ll begin to design and build my fourth laboratory; I’ll teach classes and take on more staff members, as I do every year. Like all professors, I also do a lot of extra jobs for which I was never trained, such as advising former students as they navigate the wider world. Last year, after one of my most talented students left to start her next adventure, she would text me now and then: “This is such a great place,” “I am learning so much here” and “I know this is where I am supposed to be.”

headline: Bravo Zulu: On (Representative) Ryan Zinke
text: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social-media presences of celebrities.

headline: Email Regarding Tom Donilon
text: This email, released by the State Department, was sent to Hillary Clinton's private server, which she used while she was secretary of state. The correspondence is full of tongue-in-cheek remarks concerning the overlapping trips to Israel of national security adviser, Thomas E. Donilon, and Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Agency Rivalries and Satire Show Up in Latest of Hillary Clinton’s Emails
text: WASHINGTON — Reviewing Hillary Clinton’s emails for public release has strained the State Department’s lawyers, set off bitter turf battles between the department and other agencies, and ignited a contentious debate over the nature and handling of classified information.

headline: Steven Ballmer, Clippers’ Top Fan, Is Really Invested in Them (for Billions)
text: LOS ANGELES — During the first timeout, a few minutes into Wednesday’s game between the Los Angeles Clippers and the Oklahoma City Thunder at Staples Center here, Steven A. Ballmer looked up from his courtside seat at the fans still filtering in. “There are still some empty seats,” he said.

headline: Rikers Island Cases Are Focus for New Bronx District Attorney
text: The new Bronx district attorney, Darcel D. Clark, oversees the prosecution of crime in a dozen police precincts and scores of neighborhoods.

headline: Fed Proposes New Rule Capping Business Between Banks
text: One of the problems with big Wall Street banks in 2008 was that they had too many of their financial eggs in one basket.

headline: William & Mary Seeks an Elusive Berth
text: Russell Turner was a part of not one but two teams that became the first in their programs’ histories to make an N.C.A.A. tournament. As a player, he was a freshman on the Hampden-Sydney team that made its first Division III tournament in 1989. Now, as the coach of U.C. Irvine, he hopes to lead the Anteaters to a second consecutive berth in the Division I tournament after last season’s team earned the first invitation in program history.

headline: Connecticut Rock Pile Known as Negro Heads May Get a New Name
text: BRANFORD, Conn. — It may be dwarfed by Denali, the 20,308-foot peak in Alaska long known as Mount McKinley. But the mussel-covered pile of rocks about a mile off shore from this briny town on the Long Island Sound is at the center of a naming debate of its own, one fueled by what many consider the ugliness of the label it carries: Negro Heads.

headline: Obstacles for Global Talent in National Women’s Hockey League
text: During a trip to Junior’s restaurant in early February, Nana Fujimoto sat against a wall decorated with Brooklyn Dodgers memorabilia, savoring a slice of cheesecake while discussing her journey from Sapporo, Japan, to the National Women’s Hockey League.

headline: At RSA Conference, Unlikely Allies Address Value of Digital Security
text: SAN FRANCISCO — To Amit Yoran, a digital security veteran, the fight between Apple and the F.B.I. over access to an iPhone can be viewed in black-and-white terms: What law enforcement authorities want is “so misguided, they simply boggle the mind.”

headline: Rev. Robert Palladino, Scribe Who Shaped Apple’s Fonts, Dies at 83
text: Because of a Trappist monk, Apple computer displays look the way they do today.

headline: Distant, Tropical Isle Is Home Court for the French in a Davis Cup Match
text: BAIE-MAHAULT, Guadeloupe — It seems fantastic that four of the world’s best tennis players would descend upon a small Caribbean island more than 4,000 miles from home to take the first step toward their elusive Davis Cup.

headline: Harvard Law to Abandon Crest Linked to Slavery
text: Harvard Law School is poised to abandon an 80-year-old shield based on the crest of a slaveholding family that helped endow the institution, as campuses across the country debate the use of historic names and symbols that some consider offensive.

headline: Trump’s Softened Stance on Visas Alarms Some Immigration Critics
text: Amid the sparring and free-flying insults of Thursday night’s Republican presidential debate, Donald J. Trump said he wanted to expand the number of visas available for highly skilled immigrants.

headline: Toxic Passaic River to Get $1.38 Billion Cleanup Over 10 Years
text: NEWARK — The Passaic River was once the backbone of an industrial corridor, snaking through this stretch of northern New Jersey and sustaining the factories and plants that cropped up alongside it. But now, the river’s banks are dotted by deserted manufacturing sites while the waterway remains scarred after decades as a dumping ground for industrial pollutants that linger in the water and have seeped into the soil.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “They need food. They need to eat. They’re stealing everything.”

headline: Ted Cruz Promoted Himself and Conservative Causes as Texas’ Solicitor General
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — From its start in 1999, the office of the solicitor general of Texas was run by a plain-spoken Mormon, a by-the-books lawyer known for mentoring young attorneys and defending the state, whatever the political consequences.

headline: Spain’s Socialist Leader Loses Another Vote to Become Prime Minister
text: MADRID — The leader of the Socialist party, Pedro Sánchez, on Friday lost another parliamentary vote in his bid to become prime minister, prolonging the deadlock in Spanish politics.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Join Bernie Sanders at Fox News Town Hall on Monday
text: Hillary Clinton will join Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont at a town hall event hosted by Fox News on Monday night in Detroit, the network announced.

headline: Clinton Offers Economic Plan Focused on Jobs
text: In an election year defined by angry populism, Hillary Clinton made an optimistic economic pitch on Friday, presenting a wide-ranging plan for job growth that would provide incentives for corporations that invest in employees and strip tax benefits from companies that move jobs overseas.

headline: Review: Independent Fair Is More Conventional, but Still Eye-Catching
text: The Independent art fair, which runs through Sunday, began as a more provocative alternative to the bigger art fairs. Now in its seventh year, it isn’t quite so independent anymore. There are two iterations in New York — one in November and the one now in TriBeCa — as well as one in Brussels, which opens next month.

headline: Rank and File Republicans Tell Party Elites: We’re Sticking With Donald Trump
text: From Michigan to Louisiana to California on Friday, rank-and-file Republicans expressed mystification, dismissal and contempt over the instructions that their party’s most high-profile leaders were urgently handing down to them: Reject and defeat Donald J. Trump.

headline: Stream of Protesters Turns Donald Trump Rally Into ‘Wild Evening’
text: NEW ORLEANS — An almost constant stream of protesters interrupted Donald J. Trump’s nighttime rally here Friday, often resisting removal and dropping to the ground as security personnel tried to hustle them from the event.

headline: The Right to Sue the Gun Industry
text: The world recoiled in horror in 2012 when 20 Connecticut schoolchildren and six adults were killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School by a deranged teenager using a military-style assault rifle to fire 154 rounds in less than five minutes. The weapon was a Bushmaster AR-15 semiautomatic rifle adapted from its original role as a battlefield weapon. The AR-15, which is designed to inflict maximum casualties with rapid bursts, should never have been available for purchase by civilians.

headline: Breuer Building Expands the Imagination, and the Budget, of the Met
text: Taking on the Breuer building is a big deal even for a behemoth like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with an annual operating budget of $370 million.

headline: A $15 Minimum Wage for New York
text: The lowest-wage workers in New York could soon get a much-needed raise — if the stingy Republicans who control the State Senate don’t block it.

headline: Three More Judges Said to Be Vetted for Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is vetting Merrick B. Garland and Sri Srinivasan, federal appellate judges who have enjoyed substantial support from Republicans in the past, as potential nominees for a Supreme Court vacancy that has set off a brutal election-year fight.

headline: Syria’s Shaky Respite
text: Syrians desperate for normalcy after nearly five blood-soaked years of war have slowly begun testing the cease-fire that took effect a week ago. They are planting potatoes in the garden, going to the market and playing in the street, resuming cherished everyday routines that have been cruelly disrupted.

headline: Scott Kelly Says a Year in Orbit Felt Like ‘Forever’
text: After nearly a year in space, Scott Kelly, the NASA astronaut who returned to Earth this week, is clear on one thing: It was a long trip.

headline: Phil Mickelson Loses Grip on His Game, and Then the Lead
text: DORAL, Fla. — Phil Mickelson was his vintage self on Friday, a thrill ride filled with imagination and anticipation that anything was still possible. At 45, he is the oldest player in the Cadillac Championship field. He was leading by two strokes at midround when he inexplicably lost his momentum and golf’s next generation of stars blew past him like a rogue wind.

headline: Ralph Baruch, Who Shaped Viacom’s Rise, Dies at 92
text: Ralph M. Baruch, a refugee from Nazi Germany who turned Viacom, a small cable and syndication company that CBS spun off in 1971, into a communications and entertainment giant, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Pale Yellow
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Roland Huget is back, and he says below that he might have filled his puzzle differently these days, compared with how he filled it when it was submitted. That’s reasonable. We all evolve over time. And at least Mr. Huget can claim to be the guy who first introduced BARE IT ALL in The New York Times crossword.

headline: Judge Reduces Man’s Wrongful Conviction Award to $12 Million
text: A judge who had previously thrown out a jury’s award to a New York City man who was wrongly convicted of rape and imprisoned for over 20 years ruled on Friday that the judgment should be reduced by more than $6 million.

headline: Blame HUD for America’s Lead Epidemic
text: Chicago — SINCE news first emerged last year about dangerously high levels of lead in the drinking water in Flint, Mich., it has become shockingly clear that that city is far from alone. Reports of lead poisoning are on the rise across the country, from New York to Ohio and Iowa, particularly among low-income and minority children.

headline: Chinese Premier’s Annual Work Report
text: Prime Minister Li Keqiang of China delivered his government's annual work report to the National People’s Congress, the national legislature, on Saturday. Here is a transcript of his speech.

headline: Abortion Witch Hunt
text: LAST month, Representative Marsha Blackburn, Republican of Tennessee, in her capacity as chairwoman of the newly created House Select Investigative Panel on Infant Lives, issued subpoenas to three organizations: StemExpress, a company that supplies biological specimens for research; the University of New Mexico, where scientists conduct medical research using fetal tissue; and Southwestern Women’s Options, an abortion clinic in Albuquerque.

headline: How Iran’s Reformists Found Their Center
text: FOR decades, Iran’s politics have centered on a contest of visions that pitted democratic reformists against hard-line theocrats. Under President Hassan Rouhani, that binary has begun to give way. Last week’s elections showcased a coordinated movement toward the center of Iran’s political spectrum.

headline: China’s National People’s Congress: Key Points
text: BEIJING — The Chinese government laid out its priorities for the year on Saturday, when Prime Minister Li Keqiang gave his annual state-of-the-nation report to the legislature, the National People’s Congress. Here are highlights from that report and other government documents released at the legislative meeting in the Great Hall of the People.

headline: Judge Seals Harper Lee’s Will From Public’s Scrutiny
text: MONROEVILLE, Ala. — In death, as in life, Harper Lee appears to have opted for privacy, as a lawyer for the estate of the “To Kill a Mockingbird” author asked this week that her will be sealed from the public.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Misses, and a Bad Week Continues for Knicks
text: BOSTON — Carmelo Anthony was already having a difficult week before he showed up Friday at TD Garden with the rest of the Knicks. Where to begin?

headline: Pat Conroy, Author of ‘The Prince of Tides’ and ‘The Great Santini,’ Dies at 70
text: Pat Conroy, who used his tortured family life and the scenic marshlands of coastal South Carolina as unending sources of inspiration for his fiction, notably the novels “The Great Santini,” “The Lords of Discipline” and “The Prince of Tides,” died on Friday. He was 70.

headline: Tom Knight, Brooklyn’s Baseball Sage, Dies at 89
text: As decades pass, fans of the Brooklyn Dodgers, perhaps the most fervidly nostalgic partisans in the history of sports, are growing fewer and fewer. The 2016 baseball season, now getting underway, is the 59th since the team decamped to Los Angeles, leaving Brooklyn’s baseball die-hards with pangs of heartsickness for the loss of Gil Hodges, Duke Snider and Pee Wee Reese and venomous animosity for the never-to-be-forgiven betrayal of the team owner, Walter O’Malley, who took them away.

headline: Tony Dyson, Who Brought R2-D2 to Rolling, Beeping Life, Dies at 68
text: Tony Dyson, the special-effects designer who built R2-D2, the squat robot sidekick that beeped and whirred its way through seven Star Wars films, died on Friday at his home on the Maltese island of Gozo. He was 68.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
text: Need a laugh? Melissa McCarthy spoofs Miss Moneypenny in “Spy” and Jonah Hill hosts “Saturday Night Live.” Feel like a cry? Amy Adams portrays Margaret Keane, the unheralded artist behind those popular 1960s waifs with sad faces and enormous peepers, in “Big Eyes.”

headline: Paris Fashion Week: The Weekend
text: PARIS — Rise and shine, fashion week folk: The weekend begins with the Japanese designer Junya Watanabe, a former protégé of Rei Kawakubo at Comme des Garçons, who shows (mercifully, with coffee) at 9:30 at La Cantine, on the far side of the Seine.

headline: Corrections: March 5, 2016
text: NATIONAL

headline: ‘No Grace in Defeat’: Our Best Comments of the Week
text: In this new feature, we list the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: Networking in the ‘Girls’ Lounge’
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Serious, successful businesswomen banding together as “girlie girls” to help end gender inequality in the workplace?

headline: After the Broadway Show, a Trip to Hamilton’s Grave
text: The tranquil graveyard at Trinity Church is tucked into an otherwise bustling commercial corner of Lower Manhattan. Inside its gates, weatherworn headstones — some dating from the 1680s — stand in the shadows of skyscrapers.

headline: Millennial Reporters Grab the Campaign-Trail Spotlight
text: When the last presidential race was in its early stages, Katie Glueck was a senior at Northwestern University. Now covering the Ted Cruz campaign for Politico, Ms. Glueck, 26, belongs to a select group of millennial reporters who have a front-row seat to the greatest political show on earth.

headline: Causes of Blindness Vary for Older Adults
text: Q. What’s the No. 1 cause of blindness in older adults in the United States?

headline: A One-Man Quest for Answers in Malaysian Jet’s Disappearance
text: HONG KONG — The search for the Malaysia Airlines jet that vanished almost two years ago has involved ships scanning thousands of square miles of the Indian Ocean seabed. But what could be the most promising development in months was the result of a lone man’s search, one that took him to an uninhabited sandbank along the coast of Mozambique.

headline: The Intrexon Menagerie
text: Randal Kirk’s ventures range from gene therapies and cancer research, to a collection of genetically engineered animals, fruits and insects.

headline: A Biotech Evangelist Seeks a Zika Dividend
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — In the expanding realm ruled by Randal J. Kirk, sliced apples don’t brown. Salmon grow twice as fast without swimming upriver to spawn. Beloved cats are reborn.

headline: In New Economic Plan, China Bets That Hard Choices Can Be Avoided
text: BEIJING — As economic growth has fallen while debts and excess industrial output have risen, Chinese leaders have faced growing questions about whether they will carry out the painful policy surgery many experts say is needed to cut away the financial dead weight on the economy.

headline: Haider Ackermann: Fall 2016
text: The Colombian designer, Mr. Ackermann, debuts his fall collection.

headline: Junya Watanabe: Fall 2016
text: Mr. Watanabe presents his fall looks.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the Academy Awards to Cadaqués, Spain.

headline: Ava McAvoy Transforms at Yohji Yamamoto
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Paris.

headline: Bernie Sanders to Run 5-Minute Documentary Ad on Univision to Court Hispanics
text: In an effort to reach millions of Hispanic voters, Bernie Sanders’s campaign is running a five-minute Spanish-language ad on Univision that calls attention to the plight of a female farm worker in Florida.

headline: Tensions Simmer as a Small Town Seeks Answers in a Boy’s Killing
text: POTSDAM, N.Y. — At the southern edge of this village near the Canadian border, a small billboard slowly comes into focus. On the left is a black-and-white photo of a boy, reminiscent of so many missing-children posters; to the right are the words “Unsolved Murder.”

headline: A Little Variety
text: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: The Daily Shoe: Loewe
text: Jonathan Anderson’s pointed Loewe heels are art for the feet — and as covetable as the clothes.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Dior
text: The edge at the Dior show came out not in the clothes but in the jewelry, as seen in this fistful of rings dangling charms and beads.

headline: The Daily Bag: Loewe
text: The hobo bag gets an update courtesy of Loewe: The soft, laid-back shape was complete with braided straps and gold hardware, making for one of the best bags we’ve seen this week.

headline: Farhad and Joe Examine Silicon Valley’s Pull in Washington
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mr. Isaac is out this week, so Joe Plambeck, deputy technology editor, is filling in.

headline: Ad Calls Trump a Fraud, and Unfit for the White House
text: For 60 seconds, the accusations fly: “Massive Scam.” “Operating a phony university.” “Habitual liar.” Seizing on one of his more questionable business ventures, this ad – helpfully titled “Scam” — assaults Donald J. Trump’s character and fitness for the presidency. The commercial was produced by Our Principles PAC, a group that is not aligned with any of his rivals but that sees Mr. Trump as calamitous to the Republican Party if he becomes its nominee.

headline: Buying a Co-op with ‘Dummy Money’
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: If It’s March, It Must Be Miami: When Home Changes With the Season
text: Oren Alexander, the Miami-based real estate agent to the rich, no longer thinks of his clients as second-home buyers. Today’s ultrawealthy, he says, are often looking for “the four-pack” — a pied-à-terre in New York, a beach house in the Hamptons, a ski villa in Aspen and a winter condo in Miami.

headline: Ted Cruz Keeps Up Pressure on Donald Trump; Bernie Sanders Takes 2 on ‘Super Saturday’
text: Senator Ted Cruz scored decisive wins in the Kansas and Maine caucuses on Saturday, demonstrating his enduring appeal among conservatives as he tried to reel in Donald J. Trump’s significant lead in the Republican presidential race.

headline: The Kasich Con
text: At this point, according to Predictwise, John Kasich has the fourth-best chance of getting the Republican nomination. It’s not a big chance — 5 percent — but you can imagine a scenario in which the stop Trump forces produce a hung convention, and Kasich emerges as the supposedly reasonable candidate. So an advance warning: he’s a con artist too.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Dior, Loewe and Olympia Le-Tan in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Friday.

headline: At Haider Ackermann, an Otherworldly Beauty — With Sculptural Hair
text: “It’s an otherworldly beauty. It’s about very blank faces with beautiful skin,” the makeup artist Lynsey Alexander said of the beauty look at the Haider Ackermann show earlier today. To achieve it, she smoothed and illuminated models’ faces with MAC’s Face and Body Foundation — and mixed it with Face and Body White and Silver Strobe Cream to give a slight iridescent finish to the skin.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Ivy League Coaches’ Choice on Full Contact Will Aid Athletes

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 3: The Trump-Underwood Connection
text: Sometimes art imitates life. Sometimes life imitates art. And sometimes, life imitates art before that art has even shown up on Netflix.

headline: Variety: A Beautiful Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — For me, maps are all about possibilities. Looking at the highways and byways, the cities and towns, the land masses, all I can think of is the possibility of seeing places I’ve never visited and how I will get there. Maps are about adventure.

headline: Red Bulls’ Bradley Wright-Phillips Wins Greater Regard by Scoring Less
text: HARRISON, N.J. — It is hard to argue with the results, even if the cold, spare statistics of soccer suggest otherwise. Bradley Wright-Phillips and his teammates insist that Wright-Phillips, their high-scoring, heel-clicking striker, has been a more efficient player, and the Red Bulls a better team, since he avoided the net-bending feats he accomplished in 2014.

headline: New York Governor Race Analysis and Trump
text: An October 2013 memo sent to senior New York State Republicans urged them to consider Donald J. Trump as the party's nominee for governor.

headline: 'Springboards to the Presidency' Memo
text: A memo sent to Donald J. Trump in December 2013 detailed how he could increase his chances of winning the White House if he first ran for governor of New York.

headline: Donald Trump Considered Path to Presidency Starting at Governor’s Mansion in New York
text: In late December 2013, after Donald J. Trump had met with a number of Republicans to discuss a possible run for governor of New York, he received a memo from an attendee, a freshman assemblyman from upstate.

headline: After Heartbreak, Twins Slugger Miguel Sano Looks Ahead
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — The memorial stretches nearly from the wrist to the elbow on the right forearm of the major leagues’ next slugging star. Miguel Sano, the Minnesota Twins’ 22-year-old power hitter, is never far from his daughter.

headline: Italian Cuisine Worth Going to Prison For
text: MILAN — The waiters glided through the crowded dining room of InGalera, a restaurant that opened recently to rave reviews. Dinner reservations are almost fully booked for March, and the Milanese elite have taken note. A former bank president came a few weeks ago. So did a former Miss Italy. Families come on weekends.

headline: Airbnb Pits Neighbor Against Neighbor in Tourist-Friendly New Orleans
text: Talk to the locals in certain New Orleans neighborhoods — from the historic and genteel Garden District uptown to the dense and increasingly trendy Bywater downriver — and you can be pretty sure that one topic will come up eventually: Airbnb.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Rei Kawakubo debuts her fall collection.

headline: Counseling Organ Donors to Make the Perfect Match
text: Patricia McDonough, 59, is a clinical transplant coordinator at Montefiore Health System in the Bronx.

headline: In the Bizarro World of Negative Interest Rates, Saving Will Cost You
text: Here’s a proposition for you: Hand over your money. I’ll skim some off the top, hold it for a while and return whatever is left in a year or two.

headline: New Yankee Had a Sweet Swing as a Child, but in Golf
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When Aaron Hicks was 10, already busy collecting golf trophies on some of the same courses that Tiger Woods had grown up on, his friends asked him to play Little League with them. So Hicks asked his father for permission.

headline: As Book Opens on M.L.S.’s 21st Season, the Subplots Abound
text: The M.L.S. season that opens Sunday will be the league’s 21st, a fitting number for a year that will feature the debut of the 21-year-old striker Jordan Morris.

headline: Competing Interests on Encryption Divide Top Obama Officials
text: WASHINGTON — The intensifying legal battle over encryption between Apple and the Justice Department has all but obscured another more subtle division, the one inside the Obama administration itself.

headline: Canadiens’ Fast Start Gives Way to Long Skid
text: On the day the Montreal Canadiens completed a winless three-game trip through California, the biggest news for the franchise came almost 3,000 miles away. Hours before the Canadiens lost, 3-2, to the Los Angeles Kings on Thursday, their star goaltender Carey Price, the reigning Hart Trophy winner as the N.H.L.’s most valuable player, spoke at the team’s practice complex in Montreal.

headline: Money Given to Kenya, Since Stolen, Puts Nike in Spotlight
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — When a Chinese clothing company swooped in and offered to sponsor Kenya’s famed runners, Nike panicked, Kenyan officials say.

headline: Brad Weston of Petco: A Haven for Frogs, Snakes, Lizards and Plenty of Dogs
text: 1. Letting the light in

headline: Donald the Dangerous
text: IS there any scarier nightmare than President Donald J. Trump in a tense international crisis, indignant and impatient, with his sweaty finger on the nuclear trigger?

headline: When the Tide of Islamophobia Reached My Hometown Mosque
text: THE Islamic Society of North America’s headquarters sit atop a grassy hill overlooking Plainfield, Ind. The complex includes a prayer hall, a space for community events and a field house with a basketball court and playground. It is surrounded by cornfields. As the largest mosque in the Indianapolis area, it draws hundreds of families, especially during Ramadan and on holidays.

headline: Waiter, Where’s Our (Political) Spinach?
text: ASKED what we prefer to eat for dinner, many of us will virtuously claim a diet of salads and whole grains, never mentioning lifeboat-size portions of penne alla vodka or our addiction to flourless chocolate cake. Asked what we serve the kids, we will nod dutifully to lean proteins and green vegetables, while double-cheese pizza and tater tots will go unmentioned.

headline: The Elements of Trumpism
text: MAYBE Donald Trump is doing us a favor.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A Judge’s Message to the Xenophobes
text: More than two dozen Republican governors were in a virtual stampede last fall to be first to bar the resettlement of federally approved Syrian refugees in their states. The shameless display of jingoism was prompted by the Paris shooting massacre in November and fears — wildly driven by the Republican presidential rivals — that terrorists could infiltrate the United States as refugees despite a resettlement process that is one of the strictest in the world.

headline: Chickens, Home to Roost
text: WASHINGTON — HERE’S why the Trump campaign is wicked fun:

headline: Raise the Legal Age for Cigarette Sales to 21
text: California could soon raise the legal age for buying cigarettes and other tobacco products to 21, from 18. That change could help prevent many young people from becoming addicted and reduce premature deaths from lung cancer and other tobacco-related diseases.

headline: Hidden Gold in College Applications
text: IF the gatekeepers at Davidson College had judged the teenager by her ACT score, she probably wouldn’t have gotten in. It was 25 out of a possible 36, and more than three-quarters of the students at Davidson, a liberal-arts school in North Carolina with about 1,800 undergraduates and an acceptance rate of just over 20 percent, do better than that.

headline: An All-American Family Portrait, in White
text: I walked through the door of Vincent Valdez’s studio, in a renovated firehouse near downtown San Antonio, the other day. I stopped dead, my eyes widened, my mouth made a silent O.

headline: Two-Man Race for Top Rookie Should Be a Rout
text: One rookie-of-the-year contender was called a unicorn by Kevin Durant, has two nicknames that incorporate the word “god” and has single-handedly given hope to New York basketball fans. The other, known simply by his initials, has been honing his game far more quietly in Minnesota.

headline: Pencil Pushes Way Into Daytona Lore
text: When two cars flashed across the finish line together at the Daytona 500 two weeks ago, modern camera technology captured the moment, leaving no doubt that Denny Hamlin had won by a nose.

headline: How Marco Rubio's Grandfather Was Nearly Deported
text: Excerpts from an immigration hearing in 1962 where Marco Rubio's grandfather, Pedro Garcia, discussed his expired green card and pleaded his case to stay in the U.S. as a permanent resident.

headline: Marco Rubio’s Policies Might Shut the Door to People Like His Grandfather
text: MIAMI — Marco Rubio’s grandfather was a man without a country.

headline: Donald Trump Broke Debate Rule About Huddling With Staff, Rivals Say
text: Donald J. Trump flouted a rule set by Fox News during Thursday night’s debate by conversing with his campaign manager during a commercial break, according to two rival campaign officials.

headline: John Kasich Sides With Harry Potter on Strategy
text: — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, speaking to reporters on Saturday in Traverse City, Mich.

headline: The World Has a Problem: Too Many Young People
text: AT no point in recorded history has our world been so demographically lopsided, with old people concentrated in rich countries and the young in not-so-rich countries.

headline: Nina Ricci: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Guillaume Henry presents his latest fall looks.

headline: Taliban Say They Won’t Attend Peace Talks, but Officials Aren’t Convinced
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban said on Saturday that they would not participate in international peace talks, citing what they claimed were increased American airstrikes and Afghan government military operations.

headline: The Return of the D.I.Y. Abortion
text: DURING oral arguments last week before the Supreme Court in Whole Woman’s Health v. Hellerstedt, Justice Elena Kagan noted that she was struck by the clear relationship between abortion restrictions in Texas and the closing of abortion clinics. “It’s almost like the perfect controlled experiment as to the effect of the law, isn’t it?” she said. “It’s like you put the law into effect, 12 clinics closed. You take the law out of effect, they reopen.”

headline: The Eviction Economy
text: I FIRST met Larraine when we both lived in a trailer park on the far South Side of Milwaukee. Fifty-four, with silvering brown hair, Larraine loved mystery novels, “So You Think You Can Dance” and doting on her grandson. Even though she lived in a mobile home park with so many code violations that city inspectors called it an “environmental biohazard,” she kept a tidy trailer and used a hand steamer on the curtains. But Larraine spent more than 70 percent of her income on housing — just as one in four of all renting families who live below the poverty line do. After paying the rent, she was left with $5 a day.

headline: The Rise of Antipolitics
text: Readers discuss a David Brooks column about trends leading to Donald Trump’s candidacy.

headline: Can Nicotine Be Good for You?
text: THERE was something odd about my new patient. She was elegantly dressed and self-possessed, and yet she was slowly, rhythmically chewing gum, something I rarely see in my psychiatry sessions. Was she trying to cover up anxiety about this first encounter, I wondered, or was she perhaps hoping to project a kind of cool, laid-back style?

headline: The Art of Failing Upward
text: IN the start-up world, failure is in. No sooner has an entrepreneur failed at a venture in Silicon Valley than he takes to the web — frequently to blogging sites like Medium, which hosts a continuous stream of essays on the topic — or to the stage at industry conferences like FailCon to narrate the failure and the growth he experienced as a result.

headline: In Character
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — April of this year marks the 400th anniversary of the death of William Shakespeare, and David J. Kahn is back with a puzzle about some of the Bard’s characters.

headline: Votes Being Counted in 5 States
text: Voters turned out for primaries and caucuses in Kansas, Louisiana, Maine, Kentucky and Nebraska.

headline: South Korea Government Accused of Using Defamation Laws to Silence Critics
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In late 2014, months after 304 people died in the sinking of a South Korean ferry, a leaflet began circulating with a scurrilous rumor about President Park Geun-hye: that she had failed to respond swiftly to the disaster that day because she was having a romantic encounter with a former aide.

headline: Maryland House Race a ‘Caldron of Power Couples and Washington, D.C., Politics’
text: CHEVY CHASE, Md. — What happens when a coveted House seat opens up a quick subway ride from the Capitol? A hugely expensive free-for-all, studded with celebrities (or what passes for celebrities in Washington) — with a whiff of dirty tricks.

headline: Crosswords Seemingly Copied From The New York Times Questioned
text: In the world of crossword enthusiasts, a new puzzle presents a fresh challenge each day. But what if the puzzle was plagiarized from one that appeared years ago?

headline: Dr. Myron G. Schultz, Who Helped Identify AIDS Crisis, Dies at 81
text: Dr. Myron G. Schultz, whose detection of a cluster of pneumonia cases in the early 1980s helped public health officials identify the AIDS epidemic, died on Feb. 19 in Atlanta. He was 81.

headline: Britain’s Exclusive Schools Try to Be a Little Less So
text: RUGBY, England — Patrick Derham remembers the moment in October 1973 when, age 14, from a troubled home and planning to join the navy, he saw the course of his life changed, rather miraculously, for the better.

headline: Alumni of Britain’s Elite Schools
text: LONDON — Graduates of Britain’s famous private schools are still overrepresented in the upper tiers of British life, from government to the arts.

headline: Donald Trump Again Alters Course on Torture
text: Donald J. Trump said he would seek to “broaden” laws regarding the torture of terrorism suspects, a day after he said that as president he would be “bound by laws and treaties” that he would not order the military to violate.

headline: Forging a 3-Shot Lead, McIlroy Can See Augusta From Doral
text: DORAL, Fla. — Rory McIlroy has captured three of golf’s four major championships, and with his game kicking into another gear as he methodically took apart the Blue Monster course at Trump National Resort on Saturday, talk will soon shift to the major title he covets most.

headline: With Porzingis Out on Short Notice, Knicks Unite for a Victory
text: With just over an hour remaining before the Knicks tipped off against the Detroit Pistons at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, Coach Kurt Rambis made a rare appearance in the locker room. He called out for Derrick Williams, who could not hear his name over the music pumping through his headphones.

headline: Yale Finally Has an Ivy Title to Call Its Own
text: After Yale’s players had celebrated with bearhugs and a scrum at center court, the Ivy League’s executive director, Robin Harris, told them, “I want to congratulate you on being outright champion.”

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Your Weekend Briefing

headline: Emmarie Huetteman, Christopher Trepky
text: Emmarie Huetteman and Christopher Thomas Trepky were married Feb. 29 under the District of Columbia’s self-uniting marriage statute. The ceremony was at the Tidal Basin next to the National Mall in Washington.

headline: Laura Keane, Eric Ayers
text: Laura Mackenzie Noerr Keane and Eric Matthew Ayers were married March 4 at the London Plane, a restaurant in Seattle. Laura C. Inveen, a Superior Court judge in King County, Wash., officiated.

headline: Rachel Meislin, Marc Ohringer
text: Rachel Julie Meislin, a daughter of Andrea Popowich Meislin and Dr. Robert J. Meislin of New York, was married March 5 to Marc Lee Ohringer, a son of Sheryl Bloom Ohringer and Barry H. Ohringer of Woodland Park, N.J. Rabbi Jeremy Kalmanofsky officiated at Capitale, an event space in New York.

headline: Stephanie Lake and Adam Kool: Love Me, Love My City
text: Stephanie Lindsay Lake, a daughter of Katharine Lindsay Lake and Stephen Randall Lake of Norwalk, Conn., was married March 1 to Adam Michael Kool, a son of Tammy J. Kool and the Rev. Ronald G. Kool of Grand Rapids, Mich. Robert D. Sack, a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, officiated, with Lewis A. Kaplan, a judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, taking part at the Thurgood Marshall United States Court House in New York.

headline: Rachel Pea, Michael Blake
text: Rachel Virginia Pea and Michael Thomas Blake were married March 5 at the Rickhouse, an event space in Durham, N.C. The Rev. Katie Crowe, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Jillian Kotler, Adam Fox
text: Jillian Lauren Kotler, the daughter of Anita Paoli Kotler and Dr. Jon A. Kotler of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married March 5 to Adam Jordan Fox, a son of Laurie M. Fox and George Fox of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Moishe Meir Lipszyc officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Fort Lauderdale.

headline: James Leider, Todd Scher
text: James Gabriel Leider and Todd Gerald Scher are to be married March 6 at the Diplomat Golf & Tennis Club in Hallandale Beach, Fla. Rabbi Allan C. Tuff is to officiate.

headline: Shanshan Li, Sean Sheehy
text: Shanshan Li and Sean Paul Sheehy were married Feb. 29 at City Hall in Cambridge, Mass. Donna P. Lopez, the Cambridge city clerk, officiated.

headline: Jamie Rosen, David Manning
text: Jamie Melissa Rosen, a daughter of Dr. Debra J. Wattenberg and Brett N. Rosen of New York, was married March 5 to David Charles Manning, the son of Gail P. Manning and Frederick J. Manning of Chicago. Rabbi Michael Stanger officiated at the Plaza in New York.

headline: Caitrin McKiernan, Andrew Hicks
text: Caitrin Una McKiernan and Andrew Stephen Hicks were married March 5 at El Presidio Chapel in Santa Barbara, Calif. Dr. Michael Carl Brabeck, the bride’s godfather, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, performed the ceremony.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Everyone expects a deal on the web. Nobody wants to pay retail. Some sellers are now willing to deceive consumers to make the sale.”

headline: Corrections: March 6, 2016
text: NATIONAL

headline: ‘Don’t Write Us Off,’ Bernie Sanders Says After Caucus Wins on Saturday
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, energized by victories Saturday in Kansas and Nebraska, declared that people should not “write off” his campaign and that the caucus wins show that he has the momentum to gain the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: John Kasich Releases Tax Records Showing $5 Million in Income Over Seven Years
text: BIRCH RUN, Mich. — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio released partial tax returns on Saturday showing that he and his wife earned more than $5 million from 2008 through 2014.

headline: It’s Discounted, but Is It a Deal? How List Prices Lost Their Meaning
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As traditional retailing falters, shutting stores and shedding workers, online merchants are reaping the rewards. People like the convenience of e-commerce, and they love the feeling that they are getting a deal.

headline: As Aid Floods Into Flint, a Fix Remains Far Off
text: FLINT, Mich. — For months, almost no one would listen to residents’ fears about their odd-looking drinking water. Now, it seems, everyone is listening — and sending truckloads of bottled water, water filters and baby wipes, and cash donations and television news crews that set up along Saginaw Street downtown.

headline: Lewis Hamilton at Vivienne Westwood
text: The crowd that assembles at the Vivienne Westwood show during Paris Fashion Week is typically an eclectic bunch. So it was something of a surprise on Saturday afternoon to see Lewis Hamilton, the clean-cut reigning Formula One world champion, speeding through the drag queens, goth rockers and the more avant garde of the fashion elite on his way to his spot on the front row. But Mr. Hamilton, who became an official ambassador for British men’s fashion in June, is becoming a seasoned circuit fixture. In Paris for the weekend before the 2016 championship season kicksoff in Melbourne, Australia on March 20, he took five minutes to talkto Styles after the show was over.

headline: Philippines Will Impound Ship Linked to North Korea
text: MANILA — The Philippines will become the first country to enforce tough new United Nations sanctions on North Korea when it begins formal procedures on Monday to impound a cargo vessel linked to the reclusive nation, a government spokesman said on Sunday.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Donald Trump, China, Scott Kelly
text: Here are the week’s top stories.

headline: 1941: Yugoslavia Weighs Closer Ties With Axis Bloc
text: ROME — Axis hopes of creating a solid European continent ranged against England were never higher than they are in Rome today [Mar. 6], with apparently well authenticated reports that Yugoslavia is to follow Bulgaria into the German camp.

headline: Slovakia’s Governing Party Loses Majority as Far Right Makes Gains
text: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — Slovakia’s governing party lost its majority in parliamentary elections, and far-right extremists made striking gains, according to results announced on Sunday.

headline: Time to Cuddle with Cruz?
text: Just when you think it can’t get any worse for the sober-minded, cool-headed traditionalists in the Republican Party, it does. They see their gold-plated gate crasher taken down a peg, only to find themselves faced with the prospect of kissing up to Ted Cruz.

headline: Balenciaga: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Demna Gvasalia’s debut collection for Balenciaga.

headline: The Family Footsteps We Follow
text: My father is one of three brothers who thrived in their respective professions, lifting themselves above the economic station of their Italian-immigrant parents. They’re archetypal American success stories. Buoyed by their good fortune, my siblings, my cousins and I racked up athletic trophies, won scholarships, gained admission to competitive schools, built enviable careers.

headline: Balenciaga’s New Balance
text: PARIS — The most anticipated debut of Paris Fashion Week took place in a white box of a padded sound stage in the far reaches of the 15th Arrondissement as a cold wind blew in from the Seine. Guests trooped down a staircase covered in industrial gray carpet against the soundtrack of air raid sirens, to see Demna Gvasalia, the Georgian fox in the iconoclastic Vetements henhouse of fashion, unveil his Balenciaga. A hush of expectation settled over the crowd.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Mugler
text: The oversize sculptural earrings at Mugler were a nod to the house’s ’80s heyday — simultaneously modern and just a little bit decadent.

headline: New York’s Sounds of Silence
text: Dear Diary:

headline: 1966: Russia Says Venus Probes Failed
text: MOSCOW — The Soviet Union acknowledged last night [March 5] that though the group flight of Venus-2 and Venus-3 was a great technological achievement, it was a scientific failure. Neither of the two spaceships — each weighing more than a ton — returned any information about the cloud-covered planet.

headline: The Daily Bag: Nina Ricci
text: At Nina Ricci, a small, tulip-red bag bloomed like a flower on the runway.

headline: Céline: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Phoebe Philo’s latest designs.

headline: Peyton Manning Expected to Say He’s Leaving the N.F.L.
text: Peyton Manning, the Denver Broncos quarterback and Super Bowl 50 victor who amassed a passel of records and was among the N.F.L.’s most popular players in his 18 seasons in the league, will retire, hobbled by several career-threatening injuries.

headline: A Food Order Ends in a Flurry of Fists, Hurled Sodas and Flying White Sauce
text: What turned out to be the last order of the night — before an attack left a police officer with injuries, a suspect in custody and a Halal Paradise food truck in shambles — came from a man with $4 in his hand and a $5 lamb gyro on his brain.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Comme des Garçons and Junya Watanabe in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

headline: A Sentimental Education From Comme des Garçons, Céline and Undercover
text: PARIS — On Saturday, in the bowels of Le Centorial, the 19th-century building that is the headquarters of the bank formerly known as Crédit Lyonnais, two floors below the soaring central hall, so far underground that cellphones go dark, Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garçons held a history lesson.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Nancy Reagan, an Influential and Protective First Lady, Dies at 94
text: Nancy Reagan, the influential and stylish wife of the 40th president of the United States who unabashedly put Ronald Reagan at the center of her life but became a political figure in her own right, died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 94.

headline: In Sunset Park, a Call for ‘Innovation’ Leads to Fears of Gentrification
text: For decades, the industrial waterfront of Sunset Park, on the western edge of Brooklyn, was an urban flyover country of sorts, as commuters heading to Manhattan or Staten Island zipped past on the elevated Gowanus Expressway, catching glimpses of auto repair shops, huge warehouses and billboards.

headline: Club for Growth to Spend $2 Million on Anti-Trump Ads
text: Club for Growth Action, the “super PAC” arm of the influential anti-tax group, is going on television with $2 million in ads against Donald J. Trump in Illinois, where Republicans will hold a primary on March 15.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 4: Well That Was Surprising
text: Just when this episode threatens to get bogged down in political strategy — Claire and Frank’s continued quid pro quo, the execution of Operation Intimidate Russian President Petrov — Frank Underwood gets shot. The effect is a little like bringing a gun to a chess match. It immediately adds a sense of urgency and danger to this initially dull episode. The way the incident is initially telegraphed, with Claire put on lockdown by the Secret Service in a way that suggests Frank is again attempting to assert his dominance, works quite effectively. Narratively, though, the introduction of an assassination attempt also feels a little desperate and, potentially, like a bad omen for anyone waiting to witness the fall of Frank Underwood.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: Dust off your bugle and sound the “Last Post”: “Downton Abbey” closes its doors after six seasons. Kevin Spacey of “House of Cards” joins the political debate on “Meet the Press.” And Caitlyn Jenner discusses her conservative views and sexual orientation on “I Am Cait.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Is Riding High — That’s the Problem
text: Hillary Clinton could be in for some political peril.

headline: Nancy Reagan Dies at 94
text: Mrs. Reagan died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles.

headline: Review: Carnegie Hall’s ‘West Side Story’ at the Knockdown Center
text: The headlong energy of youth was on ample — no, make that spectacular — display over the weekend in Maspeth, Queens, at the Knockdown Center, a former factory where a wonderfully energized, energizing production of “West Side Story” was presented for just three performances, under the auspices of Carnegie Hall and the Weill Music Institute.

headline: A Call for College Students to Help Shape Their States’ Clean Power Plans
text: Back in January, Eban Goodstein, the director of the Bard College Center for Environmental Policy, distributed an invitation to college students and faculty across the United States to participate in “Power Dialog,” an exciting effort to mesh learning and civic engagement around the nation’s efforts to curtail power plant emissions of carbon dioxide, the main human-generated gas contributing to global warming.*

headline: Republicans and Trade Wars
text: I’m not sure whether anyone but me cares about the Romney-Trump spat over trade policy; it’s much more interesting, for normal human beings anyway, to talk about the size of Trump’s, er, hands. For that matter, even Romney’s past relationship with Trump is notable mainly because racism and birtherism didn’t bother him back in the good old days. Still, the trade dispute is a revealing fight, on both sides.

headline: Nancy Reagan Dies
text: Mrs. Reagan died at 94 on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles.

headline: A Big Night for Ted Cruz and Bernie Sanders
text: The most interesting developments in Saturday’s primary contests centered on Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and Bernie Sanders, in that order.

headline: Billie Jean King Campaigns for Women's Soccer
text: Forty-three years after its creation, the Women’s Tennis Association still bills itself as “the global leader in women’s professional sport.”

headline: Nancy Reagan’s Style
text: Some memorable looks from the former first lady.

headline: In a Note, Bob Dylan Told Barbra Streisand, ‘You Are My Favorite Star’
text: Of the thousands of lyrics, tapes and correspondence in the Bob Dylan Archive, one of the more intriguing items is a handwritten card from Barbra Streisand, postmarked November 1978, in which she thanks Mr. Dylan for sending flowers and suggests that they make a record together.

headline: Candidates React to Nancy Reagan’s Death
text: The presidential candidates reacted quickly to the death Sunday of Nancy Reagan, who died at age 94.

headline: Mets Revamp Sign System After Daniel Murphy’s Departure
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — At some point near the end of spring training, Tim Teufel, the Mets’ third-base coach, will gather the team for a meeting to demonstrate and decode the hand signs they will use this season. One sequence of signs may tell a batter to bunt, or tell a runner to steal, or tell them both that the hit-and-run is on. Teufel has about 10 signs, and he uses his own elaborate system to relay them, just to make the enterprise that much harder for an opponent to pick up on.

headline: How to Watch the Democratic Debate
text: Here’s how we analyzed the Democratic debate.

headline: ‘Zootopia’ Tops the Box Office
text: “Zootopia,” which delighted critics with its low-high approach to topics like racism (err, speciesism), drew moviegoer hooves in droves over the weekend. But Tina Fey’s war dramedy “Whiskey Tango Foxtrot” was a dud, taking in roughly 25 percent less than even the weakest of prerelease analyst projections.

headline: Akris: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Albert Kriemler presents his latest looks.

headline: Louis C.K. Condemns Trump in Email
text: The comedian Louis C.K. condemned the Republican presidential front-runner, Donald J. Trump, in an email to his fans on Saturday. “The guy is Hitler. And by that I mean that we are being Germany in the 30s,” he writes. “Hitler was just some hilarious and refreshing dude with a weird comb over who would say anything at all.”

headline: Nikolaus Harnoncourt, Conductor and Early-Music Specialist, Dies at 86
text: Nikolaus Harnoncourt, a pioneering and influential early-music specialist and respected mainstream maestro, died on Saturday in the village of St. Georgen im Attergau, east of Salzburg, Austria. He was 86.

headline: BET Honors Pay Tribute to Patti LaBelle, Lee Daniels, Eric Holder and Others
text: WASHINGTON — “Black excellence,” the running theme of the BET Honors, was on full display Saturday evening at the Warner Theater here, where the network filmed its annual homage to African-American luminaries in art, music, theater, technology and business.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Haider Ackermann
text: Velvet is proving to be a big trend for fall. Haider Ackermann put his best foot forward with these high-heeled boots in a palette of jewel-tone colors.

headline: Joe Biden Jokingly Suggests Ted Cruz for Supreme Court Pick
text: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had some tongue-in-cheek advice for President Obama on Saturday about whom he should nominate to fill the Supreme Court vacancy that has preoccupied the White House and incited an election-year fight.

headline: Not Everyone Says Headgear Is Right Fit for Girls’ Lacrosse
text: One of the country’s most popular, fastest-growing girls’ sports is nearing a move that might seem obvious to outsiders but has instead engendered rigorous debate: offering players protective headgear.

headline: Nuance Was Never the Plan
text: The Veterans Room at the Park Avenue Armory, restored to all its Gilded Age swagger, opens on Monday.

headline: Law Graduate Gets Her Day in Court, Suing Law School
text: Nearly a decade has passed since an aspiring young lawyer in California, Anna Alaburda, graduated in the top tier of her class, passed the state bar exam and set out to use the law degree she had spent about $150,000 to acquire.

headline: Arnold Schwarzenegger Endorses John Kasich
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Arnold Schwarzenegger endorsed Gov. John Kasich on Sunday as Mr. Kasich rallied voters in his home state of Ohio, whose primary has emerged as a critical moment in the Republican race.

headline: Review: ‘Don Pasquale’ Returns to the Met, With a Bravura Aria and More
text: Two years ago at the Metropolitan Opera, the Mexican tenor Javier Camarena absolutely nailed a bravura aria in Rossini’s “La Cenerentola,” setting off an ovation that would not stop until he repeated its flashy final section — a rare occurrence of an aria encore at the Met.

headline: Review: Elisa Monte Dance Moves On, but Aesthetic Doesn’t Stray
text: After 35 years at the helm of her company, the choreographer Elisa Monte, who began her career as a dancer with Agnes de Mille and Martha Graham, is stepping down. Her troupe’s season at Aaron Davis Hall, which closed on Saturday, warmly ushered in a new artistic director, Tiffany Rea-Fisher, who joined Elisa Monte Dance in 2004.

headline: Givenchy: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Riccardo Tisci is back in Paris to present his fall designs.

headline: The Gilded Age Glows Again at the Park Avenue Armory’s Veterans Room
text: In his story “The Secret Room,” the French novelist Alain Robbe-Grillet describes an interior so ornate as to defy description, whose very dimensions are shadowy but “whose considerable space must in reality extend all around, right and left, as it does toward the faraway browns and blues among the columns standing in line, in every direction.”

headline: Marco Rubio Wins Puerto Rico Primary; Bernie Sanders Takes Maine Caucuses
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida won the Puerto Rico primary on Sunday, giving him a much-needed victory after a string of losses that threatened to push the Republican presidential nomination further out of his reach.

headline: Egypt Says Muslim Brotherhood, Backed by Hamas, Killed Top Prosecutor
text: CAIRO — Egypt said Sunday that members of the banned Muslim Brotherhood, trained by the Palestinian militant group Hamas, carried out the bombing in Cairo that killed Egypt’s top prosecutor last summer.

headline: Michigan Primary Puts Donald Trump’s Rust Belt Strategy to a Test
text: WARREN, Mich. — Neil Mortensen remembers how neighbors lost factory jobs in this suburb north of Detroit, and then, inexorably and sadly, their homes.

headline: Review: Adam Cohen’s ‘Imbeciles’, on the Supreme Court and Justice Not for All
text: Of all the disgraceful rulings the Supreme Court has made in its 227-year history — and the lowlight reel is fairly lengthy — the decision in Buck v. Bell still stands out as one of the ugliest. The case may not be as well known as, for instance, Dred Scott v. Sandford, which denied African-Americans citizenship. But in just five paragraphs, the court upheld a statute that enabled the State of Virginia to sterilize “mental defectives” — specifically one Carrie Buck, a young resident of the Virginia Colony for Epileptics and Feeble-Minded.

headline: For a Young Donald J. Trump, Broadway Held Sway
text: The Broadway producer David Black was sitting in his office, above the Palace Theater, when a young Donald J. Trump walked in, unannounced, and asked him to lunch.

headline: Snowboarding, Once a High-Flying Sport, Crashes to Earth
text: As the Swiss snowboarder Iouri Podladtchikov twisted, flipped and spun above the halfpipe at X Games Oslo last week on his way to a silver medal, the bottom of his board — one of the more valuable pieces of advertising real estate in the sport — displayed no corporate logo. Instead, it was adorned with an artistic design he had created for a college class assignment.

headline: Review: In ‘Damien,’ a Photojournalist Resists His More Devilish Side
text: Damien Thorn, the title character of A&E’s new horror series “Damien,” is subject to a particularly onerous punishment. Throughout the early episodes, whenever he has flashbacks to his childhood, he sees clips from “The Omen.” Talk about hell on earth!

headline: Nancy Reagan’s Style
text: Some memorable looks from the former First Lady Nancy Reagan.

headline: Kendrick Lamar and Lil Wayne Each Sidestep the Traditional Album Cycle
text: Back in the mid-late 2000s, when Lil Wayne used to refer to himself as the “greatest rapper alive,” music flowed forth from him like a geyser. Each year brought several dozen new songs, a sign of an artist obsessed with sound, and also with his own freedom to create.

headline: Emitt Rhodes, a New Album Out, Emerges From His Slumber
text: When the Bangles formed in the 1980s, the band sought out an ace melodist to produce its music: Emitt Rhodes.

headline: G.O.P. Goes Astray on Guantánamo. So Does Obama.
text: WASHINGTON — Even by the standards of an epically polarized Washington, the political talk about President Obama’s effort to close the Guantá namo Bay prison is starkly divorced from facts. On both sides of the debate, many claims collapse under scrutiny.

headline: Review: ‘Hungry’ Portrays a Mourning Clan in Election Year 2016
text: As befits a work with the title “Hungry,” food is prepared — ardently and aromatically — in the wonderful new play written and directed by Richard Nelson, which opened on Friday night at the Public Theater. Yet it is unlikely that the ratatouille and apple crumble on offer will satisfy the appetites of the five women and one man assembled in a snug kitchen in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

headline: Back in The Day
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — The main challenge I faced while solving this nicely symmetrical Monday puzzle was swallowing the emotions that surfaced, a tasty mix of fondness and revulsion for the cute little decade sandwiched between the Awesome ’80s and the terrifying era we live in now. I’m Generation X, though. Eating our feelings is one of our specialties.

headline: Nancy Reagan’s Love of Fashion Recalled at Givenchy Show

headline: N.J. Transit Plans Park-and-Ride Locations

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 7: What Makes a Bad Partnership?
text: Chuck and Wendy retire to the bedroom after a long night. It’s the first time they’ve seen each other since earlier that morning, and they’re dutifully exchanging “What’s up?” questions. Chuck casually lies about how he spent his evening; Wendy casually lies about how she spent her evening. At this point in their marriage, the lies are as routine as slipping on their pajamas — so routine that it isn’t immediately obvious to the viewer that they’re lying to each other at all. There’s no hitch in their voices or calculated hitch in their strides. They’re keeping secrets from each other— betraying each other, in fact — but there’s no indication this is an uncommon night. This is their marriage.

headline: Philosophy’s True Home
text: We’ve all heard the argument that philosophy is isolated, an “ivory tower” discipline cut off from virtually every other progress-making pursuit of knowledge, including math and the sciences, as well as from the actual concerns of daily life. The reasons given for this are many. In a widely read essay in this series, “When Philosophy Lost Its Way,” Robert Frodeman and Adam Briggle claim that it was philosophy’s institutionalization in the university in the late 19th century that separated it from the study of humanity and nature, now the province of social and natural sciences.

headline: ‘Gangster Warlords’ and ‘Narconomics’

Many victims of drug-related violence in Mexico ceased a long time ago to have any apparent connection with the trade. In 2014, members of a drug cartel along with local police abducted and presumably killed 43 student teachers for no discernible reason other than they were preparing to demonstrate against the lamentable state of education in their region.

headline: ‘The Ancient Minstrel,’ by Jim Harrison
text: Katherine Anne Porter argued (or at least asserted) that “novella” is “a slack, boneless, affected word that we do not need to describe anything”; her stern yet vague taxonomy recognized only “short stories, long stories, short novels, novels.” But writers who work in that Venn diagrammatic long story/short novel zone can find reassurance, if not absolute definitional clarity, in this term for something that’s neither a malnourished novel nor an overstuffed story: a genre of its own, distinguished less by length, perhaps, than by the scope or complexity of the narrative. (I’d call Melville’s 14,000-plus-word “Bartleby” a novella — he called it a “tale” — and Joyce’s “The Dead,” some 1,500 words longer, a story.) Certainly Jim Harrison isn’t sniffy about the word — in fact, Jim Harrison isn’t sniffy about much — and since his first collection of novellas, the 1979 “Legends of the Fall,” he has done as much as any living writer to demonstrate the validity and vitality of the form.

headline: Morning Agenda: Court to Hear Law Graduate’s Suit Against Her School
text: COURT TO HEAR LAW GRADUATE’S SUIT AGAINST HER SCHOOL | Five years after suing the Thomas Jefferson School of Law in San Diego over the accuracy of its employment data, Anna Alaburda, one of the school’s former students, will get her day in court,  Elizabeth Olson writes in DealBook. This is not the first time a disgruntled student has sued a law school over publicly listed alumni employment rates, claiming that law schools were counting part-time waitress and other full-time jobs outside the legal field as employment. Those cases often were dismissed because judges contended that law school students should have known that a job as a lawyer was not guaranteed. Only Ms. Alaburda has been successful in getting her case to a trial, thanks to California’s strong consumer protection laws.

text: BEIJING — A Chinese lawyer and professor who was detained last summer during a crackdown on human rights lawyers has fled to the United States after being released from surveillance, according to an international human rights group and a statement from the lawyer.

headline: Barclays Hires 9 From Boutique Firm CMC Capital
text: LONDON — Barclays said on Monday that it had hired a team from the boutique firm CMC Capital as it looked to strengthen its investment bank, one of two divisions that are the focus of the lender’s strategy as it tries to turn around its performance.

text: Galleries have always provided scholarly support for museums exhibiting their artists’ work.

headline: Death of Chinese Woman Trapped in Elevator for Month Stokes Uproar

headline: North Korean Defector in South Seeks Vietnam’s Help to Return Home
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The only North Korean defector in South Korea who has publicly said she wants to return to her home country, insisting that she arrived here by mistake, applied for political asylum at the Vietnamese Embassy in Seoul on Monday.

headline: A Starry Front Row at Stella McCartney
text: PARIS — It may have been snowing on Monday morning here, but at Stella McCartney’s show in the Palais Garnier, the stars were shining brightly.

headline: 1916: Enver Pasha Badly Wounded
