headline: They Feast on the Vines of Chianti, the Swine
text: GAIOLE IN CHIANTI, Italy — Fences are rising. There is talk of a brutal and destructive insurgency, invasions and a slaughter that could include hundreds of thousands in the years ahead.

headline: Tech Giants Battle for Top Cloud Talent
text: Even as much of the tech industry is shifting into a less frothy period, one thing hasn’t changed: the fierce competition for top technical talent.

headline: Counting Characters in Twitter
text: Q. SMS text messages have a character limit of 160 characters, so why does Twitter allow only 140 characters in a tweet?

headline: Aung San Suu Kyi Finds Roadblocks on Path to Presidency
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — Efforts by Myanmar’s democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, to negotiate her way to the presidency this year have failed, associates of hers confirmed on Monday, highlighting the challenges her party faces as it prepares to take power on April 1.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel to Host 2016 Emmys in September
text: The 2016 Emmy Awards will be hosted this year by ABC’s Jimmy Kimmel on Sept. 18, the late night host announced on Twitter.

headline: Ringleader of British Jewelry Theft Is in Failing Health, Lawyer Says
text: LONDON — The white-haired ringleader behind an audacious $20 million jewelry theft at a safe deposit company in central London is in critical condition, a court heard at a sentencing on Monday.

headline: Year After Detentions, Chinese Feminists Mark Setbacks and Progress
text: BEIJING — Dressed as Rosie the Riveter, the icon of American women’s empowerment during World War II, Li Tingting’s raised fist in a photograph posted on Facebook on Monday signaled defiance — one year after the authorities detained her and four other Chinese feminists on the eve of International Women’s Day, causing an international uproar.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Director Michael Engler on the Emotional Final Episode
text: Over six seasons, 14 directors have worked behind the scenes of “Downton Abbey,” which ended its run on Sunday. As with many series, a house visual style was established early on, with specific guidelines on what Michael Engler — who directed the series finale — described as “tonal sensibilities.” Mr. Engler, who has worked on “Sex and the City,” “The West Wing” “Six Feet Under” and “30 Rock,” spoke about working on the final season in an interview in May at Highclere Castle, where much of “Downton Abbey” was shot, then more recently on the phone. These are edited excerpts from the conversations.

headline: Ty Cobb Baseball Card Trove Reignites Dreams of Shoebox Jackpots
text: The unattended bag found while cleaning out a great-grandparent’s home looked like trash, and it was nearly discarded. But someone decided to root through the pile of postcards and paper products, and was rewarded by finding seven baseball cards from 1909 to 1911 featuring the Hall of Fame player Ty Cobb.

headline: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Apple’s Appeal in E-Book Pricing Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday refused to review an appeals court’s determination that Apple had conspired with book publishers to raise the prices of digital books.

headline: Giambattista Valli: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Valli debuts his latest designs.

headline: 'Unusual Event' at Oconee Nuclear Plant in South Carolina Leads to Shutdown
text: A fire at a nuclear power station in South Carolina damaged a power line and partly shut down the facility on Sunday, but caused no threat to the public, the company said.

headline: Annika Krijt Transforms at Stella McCartney
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Paris.

headline: Iran’s President Flouts News Media Blackout Against a Predecessor
text: TEHRAN — Just a week after his forces made significant gains in national elections, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran has started a campaign to rescind a news media blackout against a former president, Mohammad Khatami.

headline: 1941: Bernstein Loses Slander Suit
text: Henry Bernstein, French playwright and duelist, lost his slander suit today against Alain Laubreaux, editor of the Paris anti-Jewish weekly ‘‘Je Suis Partout.’’

headline: The Daily Bag: Céline
text: The laid-back mood of Céline’s show was evident not only in the clothes but in the bags, too: this elegant, soft clutch had a handle knotted like a scarf.

headline: Prayer Dispute Between Somalis and Plant Reshapes a Colorado Town, Again
text: FORT MORGAN, Colo. — The work is far from glamorous: The thermostat for much of the slaughterhouse is set near freezing, the clatter of machinery is almost deafening, and there is the matter of slicing cattle carcasses every day, eight hours a day.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Balenciaga
text: For his debut collection at Balenciaga, Demna Gvasalia tapped into the spirit of couture with finely constructed garments and big jewels. These satellite earrings, made out of crystals and pearls, covered the ears like sea urchins.

headline: Inside Iris Apfel’s (Very, Very Busy) Week in Paris
text: Iris Apfel went to Paris last week, and quite honestly, the city may never be the same. The 94-year-old New Yorker is the subject of “Iris in Paris,” a fashion exhibition and pop-up shop at Le Bon Marché Rive Gauche department store that celebrates her famous, forthright style. And rightly so.

headline: 9 Great Recipes
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: With Cruz Up, Rubio Down, Where Does That Leave Donald Trump?
text: Get live updates about voting in the March 15 contests.

headline: A Queer Pop-Punk Cult Hero Strikes Out on His Own
text: “I’m bored of just being in a band and touring,” says Seth Bogart, who, after 15 years on stage as slimy-shiny gay pop-punk act Hunx, recently released his debut album under his own name. “I realized that the best place to present my next album would be inside a world I made for it.”

headline: An Espresso Maker That Hums Along With Cécile McLorin Salvant
text: To some, the Moka pot is a fetish and design icon as likely to be found at a museum (one is in the Museum of Modern Art’s permanent collection) as in a young jazz singer’s galley kitchen in Harlem.

headline: Banksy Identified by Scientists. Maybe.
text: It is a mystery that has beguiled observers of the art world: the identity of Banksy, the puckish street artist who has maintained anonymity through more than a decade of widespread fame.

headline: Britain Gets Tougher on Corporate Rule Breakers
text: Wall Street is one of the favorite punching bags in the presidential primary campaigns. Donald J. Trump claimed in September that hedge fund managers were “getting away with murder” by avoiding taxes, while Senator Bernie Sanders argues that “it is time to break up the largest financial institutions in the country.”

headline: Supreme Court Restores Visitation Rights to Lesbian Adoptive Mother
text: WASHINGTON — In a pair of unsigned opinions, the Supreme Court on Monday restored the rights of an adoptive mother who had split with her lesbian partner and reversed a murder conviction tainted by prosecutorial misconduct.

headline: More Latinos Seek Citizenship to Vote Against Trump
text: DENVER — Donald J. Trump’s harsh campaign language against Mexican immigrants has helped him win a substantial delegate lead in the Republican primaries, but it is also mobilizing a different set of likely voters — six in the family of Hortensia Villegas alone.

headline: Lost and Found at Givenchy and Stella McCartney
text: PARIS — Walls and isolationism may be increasingly part of the conversation in both Europe and the United States, but in fashion, designers are still ranging pretty far afield. When all else fails, travel! In your mind, if not in actuality. Surf the globe (or the Internet) for inspiration and see what comes up.

headline: At Céline, a Relaxed Collection — With Many Layers
text: For her fall/winter 2016 collection, Phoebe Philo showed long tunics over flowing pants.

headline: Staten Island Homes Finally Go Up, and Up for Auction, in Hurricane’s Wake
text: Staten Island is not a borough known for its skyline, but along the eastern shore, a jagged silhouette now caps the horizon of New Dorp Beach: up, down, up, down, down, down, up — empty.

headline: Review: In ‘Rising,’ One Dancer’s Interpretation of Four Solos by Four Choreographers
text: The British dancer Aakash Odedra first presented “Rising,” a suite of four solos by four choreographers (including himself), in 2011. Though he had shown parts of it in New York, the full production did not arrive here until Friday, when it came to the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts for one night.

headline: Studies Offer Hope for Malnourished Children
text: Starving children have gut bacterial colonies that are “immature” compared with those of healthy children, and their mothers’ breast milk may lack sugars that can nourish the right bacteria, researchers have found. Those children may not grow even when they are fed nutritious food.

headline: The Costumes That Obscure Doctor and Patient
text: Is it time for new costumes in the long-running improv act featuring doctor and patient? The white coat and the cotton gown are tattered, under continual assault for their practical deficiencies and outmoded symbolism.

headline: Ali Baba’s Cave
text: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Kenneth Kong, a TV personality in Singapore. Kenneth had a moment of global fame about a year ago after sharing the Cheryl’s Birthday problem, a simple challenge that went wildly viral (covered in Numberplay here). The problem generated quite a storm on Twitter, including suggestions for more puzzles. I asked Kenneth if he had a favorite, and he pointed to a suggestion by Igor Diev, who introduces his puzzle this way: “Frankly speaking, the task of #cherylsbirthday you’ve showed the world is rather easy and it’s a shame to be unable to solve it. Let me give you a task that Russian 14-year-old students solve. That’s what should really blow your mind.”

headline: If Britain Leaves E.U., Some Fear France Would Stop Blocking Migrants at Calais
text: PARIS — Long before the large-scale migrant crisis began to haunt Europe, the camp at Calais in northern France was the object of political contention and humanitarian indignation.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Balenciaga
text: With a slanted heel, a heavy jewel and a hot color, these Balenciaga shoes are a fashion moment unto themselves.

headline: Verizon Settles With F.C.C. Over Hidden Tracking via ‘Supercookies’
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission said Monday that it had reached a settlement with Verizon Wireless for its use of hidden tracking technology known as “supercookies,” which were used for targeted advertising without customers’ permission.

headline: Ten Celebrated Chefs’ Contributions to a Brand-New Kitchen
text: When chef Timothy Hollingsworth was conceptualizing Otium, the new restaurant that is part of the Broad Museum in downtown Los Angeles, the former chef de cuisine of French Laundry made a request of colleagues and friends who have been influential in his career — “in order to create a sense of soul and bring my past into Otium,” as he puts it. He sent out a letter before the restaurant opened last fall: “I would like you to send in any pots or pans, a serving vessel of sorts, to Otium for display and possibly use,” it read.

headline: N.R.A. Praises Bernie Sanders for Debate Comments on Gunmakers
text: Senator Bernie Sanders received praise for his views on gun control on Monday from a group that he would probably like some distance from: the National Rifle Association.

headline: Veterans Take On Donald Trump in 2 New Ads
text: American Future Fund, a political nonprofit that does not disclose its donors, is airing a pair of new ads featuring veterans speaking out against Donald J. Trump.

headline: Questlove’s Latest Quest: Bringing Chefs Together
text: In chunky glasses and a comfy cardigan decorated with a carrot brooch, Questlove looked like your favorite uncle as he worked the crowd at his food salon.

headline: Raymond Tomlinson, Who Put the @ Sign in Email, Is Dead at 74
text: Raymond Tomlinson, the computer programmer who in 1971 invented email as it is known today and in the process transformed the “at” sign — @ — from a sparely used price symbol to a permanent fixture in the lives of millions of computer users around the world, died on Saturday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 74.

headline: Nancy Reagan’s Example
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Screenwriter Turned Songwriter Flips His Own Script
text: The story of Ben Abraham’s burgeoning music career sounds like something out of a movie. The singer-songwriter, 30, was born in Melbourne to an Indonesian father and an Australian mother with a thinly veiled family secret: They had been Indonesian pop stars. “I knew they were singers, but they’ve always been a bit cagey about it,” says Abraham, whose debut album, “Sirens,” was released in the U.S. last week. It wasn’t until he was watching TV on a family trip to Indonesia in 2004, however, when a contestant on the show “Indonesian Idol” sang one of his parents’ songs that he learned that just how famous his parents had been. “I was like, ‘Hang on a second — how big were you guys?’” Despite growing up in what he describes as “a very musical household,” Abraham eschewed the family business as an 18-year-old in favor of five years of film school, turning to music only after a professor (“a scary, kind of crotchety stalwart of the Australian writing scene”) offered a particularly stinging critique of his work. “He went through my script scene by scene, and at the end he sort of looked at me and went, ‘It’s just not very interesting, is it?’”

headline: Marco Rubio’s Campaign Echoes ’07 Tax Revolt: A Big Plan With Little Payoff
text: MIAMI — It began with the audacity and promise of a rising political star. Marco Rubio, a young state lawmaker, was going to do what nobody had tried for decades: rewrite the bedeviling tax code in Florida and elevate his stature in the process.

headline: Challenge to Global Insurance Rules Could Slow Overhaul
text: Until recently, international insurance regulation was a relatively quiet field. But since the financial crisis, that has changed.

headline: Michigan Poll Shows John Kasich Gaining Ground on Donald Trump
text: Donald J. Trump is holding a double-digit lead in Michigan ahead of the state’s primary election on Tuesday, but there are signs that Gov. John Kasich is gaining strength.

headline: Emory Acquires W.E.B. DuBois’s Copy of Rare Early Abolitionist Appeal
text: David Walker’s “Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the World,” published in Boston in 1829, was the first sustained attack on slavery and racism written by a black person in the United States. It’s also a notably rare item today, with only a half-dozen early copies, and two first editions, listed in library catalogs.

headline: Hermès: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Nadège Vanhee-Cybulski debuts her fall looks.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 5: The Ghosts of Frank’s Past
text: This episode of “House of Cards” opens with a slow pan into an M.R.I. machine, one where perpendicular red laser lines make President Frank Underwood appear to be caught in the cross hairs. While Frank clings to life in what may be the only hospital in America where fluorescent lights have been replaced with a moody blue glow, the information Lucas Goodwin was so desperate to share has become public knowledge. Lucas’s suicide note has been seized as evidence, and to get ahead of a potential leak, Claire Underwood acknowledges and debunks the “outrageous” claims it makes about the president, including that he murdered both Congressman Peter Russo and the Slugline reporter Zoe Barnes. In more ways than one, this episode evokes thoughts of Metro stations.

headline: Shabab Claim Responsibility for Blast at Somali Airport
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A bomb planted in a laptop computer went off at an airport security checkpoint in the town of Beletwein in central Somalia on Monday, wounding at least six people including two police officers, officials said.

headline: Outdoor Furniture’s New, Sculptural Forms
text: Abstract, intriguing designs that withstand the elements.

headline: Visium Hedge Fund Being Investigated by Justice Dept. and S.E.C.
text: The hedge fund Visium Asset Management is being investigated by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission, the fund told investors on Monday.

headline: Unplanned Pregnancies Hit Lowest Level in 30 Years
text: The rate of unintended pregnancy in the United States has declined to its lowest level in the last three decades.

headline: This Dessert Fits In on St. Patrick’s Day
text: A creamy matcha custard pie that’s about as verdant as you can get for St. Patrick’s Day is the work of Melissa and Emily Elsen, the owners of Four & Twenty Blackbirds in Brooklyn. The matcha, or powdered green tea, is from Ippodo Tea in Murray Hill and is culinary grade so it’s less bitter. To make the tart, heat the oven to 325 degrees. Whisk together ⅔ cup granulated sugar, 1½ tablespoons flour, ¼ teaspoon salt and 2 teaspoons matcha powder. Stir in ½ cup melted unsalted butter, then beat in 3 eggs and 1 egg yolk one at a time. Beat a couple of minutes more, stir in 2 cups heavy cream and ½ teaspoon vanilla, and strain into a par-baked 10-inch pie shell. Bake about 50 minutes, rotating it 180 degrees after 35 minutes, until the pie is set around the edges but still wobbly in the center. Let cool, then adorn with whipped cream: Matcha Custard Pie, $40 at Four & Twenty Blackbirds, 439 Third Avenue (Eighth Street), Brooklyn, 718-499-2917, birdsblack.com.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Loses Finra Arbitration Over Firing
text: When a Wall Street executive is fired, it is usually done quietly.

headline: U.S. Strikes in Somalia Kill 150 Shabab Fighters
text: WASHINGTON — American aircraft on Saturday struck a training camp in Somalia belonging to the Islamist militant group the Shabab, the Pentagon said, killing about 150 fighters who were assembled for what American officials believe was a graduation ceremony and prelude to an imminent attack against American troops and their allies in East Africa.

headline: Turkey Places Conditions on E.U. for Migrant Help
text: BRUSSELS — Turkey surprised European Union leaders on Monday by hitting them with a new set of demands if it is to help stem the flow of refugees from Syria and Iraq and other migrants seeking to enter Europe.

headline: The 2016 Primary Campaign Has a Cold. Pass the Tissues.
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas spent a recuperative day and a half off the campaign trail, holing up in Houston after a winter spent trudging through the Iowa and New Hampshire snow.

headline: Bob Dylan Announces American Tour for the New Album ‘Fallen Angels’
text: Bob Dylan is on the move yet again, with a new album and tour.

headline: Void Left by Peyton Manning May Be Larger for N.F.L. Than for Broncos
text: Peyton Manning’s retirement leaves a hole in the Denver Broncos’ roster. It also leaves one in the N.F.L., among players who match talent on the field with TV-ready appeal.

headline: Democrats: Stick to the Issues
text: While pundits differed on who scored what points in Sunday’s Democratic debate, all agree that the discourse was substantive and policy-focused, a refreshing change from Republican exchanges, which lately have focused more on insults about “hand” size than about ideas.

headline: Retrial in Etan Patz Murder Case Is Delayed
text: The retrial of a New Jersey man accused of strangling Etan Patz was postponed for six months on Monday because the lead defense lawyer has injured his back.

headline: Penguins Make a Bid for the Playoffs by Bouncing Back Again and Again
text: NEWARK — Kyle Palmieri was giving up five inches and 10 pounds on Pittsburgh Penguins center Evgeni Malkin when the two collided early in a game Sunday in Newark. But Palmieri threw a check with enough force to flip Malkin over the boards and into the Devils’ bench.

headline: Brewing Anger in Nicaragua
text: President Daniel Ortega has consolidated his power and helped the economy grow, but opposition from rebels reflects a rising backlash to his policies.

headline: Ortega vs. the Contras: Nicaragua Endures an ’80s Revival
text: NUEVA SEGOVIA, Nicaragua — He calls himself Tyson, wears tattered United States Army fatigues and carries a beat-up AK-47.

headline: Senators Seek Help for Older Americans Tricked Into Smuggling Drugs
text: WASHINGTON — A retired pastor from Maine imprisoned in Spain on drug-smuggling charges has caught the attention of the Senate Special Committee on Aging, whose members say he and other older Americans are being tricked by international drug gangs to carry contraband, then jailed abroad if caught.

headline: Challenges Facing the Monarch Butterfly
text: To the Editor:

headline: Former Jerusalem Bureau Chief Answers Reader’s Questions
text: Deputy international editor Jodi Rudoren, formerly based in Jerusalem, answers reader submitted questions about living in and covering Israel.

headline: Fasting Diets Are Gaining Acceptance
text: Mark Mattson, a neuroscientist at the National Institute on Aging in Maryland, has not had breakfast in 35 years. Most days he practices a form of fasting — skipping lunch, taking a midafternoon run, and then eating all of his daily calories (about 2,000) in a six-hour window starting in the afternoon.

headline: Oklahoma Puts Limits on Oil and Gas Wells to Fight Quakes
text: Facing a six-year barrage of increasingly large earthquakes, Oklahoma regulators are effectively ordering the state’s powerful oil-and-gas industry to substantially cut back the underground disposal of industry wastes that have caused the tremors across the state.

headline: For Spring, a Menagerie of Animal Prints for Men
text: Straight off the runways, a selection of creatures from land and sea.

headline: The ‘Timeseum’: A Consolidated Archive
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how daily news, features and opinion pieces come together at The New York Times.

headline: Sonia Rykiel: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Julie de Libran, who just opened the brand’s first U.S. store, debuts her latest collection.

headline: Oberlin Leaders Denounce Professor’s Remarks as ‘Anti-Semitic’
text: Oberlin College’s governing body has denounced as “anti-Semitic and abhorrent” social media posts by a professor that included suggestions Israeli and United States intelligence services were behind terror attacks.

headline: Hulk Hogan Takes Stand in His Sex-Tape Lawsuit Against Gawker
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Taking the stand as the first witness in his $100 million invasion-of-privacy lawsuit against the website Gawker, the former wrestling champion Hulk Hogan told a jury on Monday that he had been “completely humiliated” by the public release of a video that showed him having sex with his now-former best friend’s wife.

headline: Miles of Moroccan Tiles in the Marais
text: It used to be that top French designers and architects had to leave the country for an up-close look at Popham Design’s Moroccan-made tiles. Now, Caitlin and Samuel Dowe-Sandes, Americans who have lived in Marrakesh for 10 years, have opened a storefront in the Marais. Even with most surfaces covered in cement squares, hand-painted in various patterns and shades of blue, the 375-square-foot space looks and feels more like a chic living room than a shop. ‘‘This way we can show tiles the way we want people to live with them,’’ Caitlin says. An enormous brass table and bronze lighting fixtures that Samuel designed for the space are also for sale, prototypes for a new line.

headline: Banks on Campus
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wall Street Bonuses Fell in 2015, and 2016 Isn’t Looking Rosy
text: Wall Street bonuses are down for the second straight year, and recent market volatility and cutbacks suggest that 2016 is shaping up to be a difficult year, according to the New York State comptroller.

headline: Review: ‘Burning Down the House,’ a Novel Wallowing in Money and Misery
text: The references in and influences behind Jane Mendelsohn’s preposterous new novel, “Burning Down the House,” are beyond eclectic: “The Great Gatsby,” “The Sound and the Fury,” “East of Eden,” “Buddenbrooks,” “Atonement,” the plays of Aeschylus, the movies “Sabrina” and “Heaven Can Wait,” the TV series “Dallas” and “Dynasty,” and countless daytime soaps. It’s no surprise that the resulting novel is a melodramatic mess: suspenseful, even moving at times, but atrociously overwritten and overstuffed with implausible plot twists, stereotyped characters and scenes oozing sweat and tears.

headline: H.I.V. and Minority Men
text: To the Editor:

headline: Three Green (and Geometric) Gems
text: Emeralds and peridots go Nouveau Deco in onyx, diamonds and gold.

headline: Maria Sharapova Admits Taking Meldonium, Drug Newly Banned by Tennis
text: Maria Sharapova, a five-time Grand Slam champion and the world’s highest-paid female athlete, announced Monday that she had tested positive for the recently banned drug meldonium at the Australian Open.

headline: Embargo Lifted, Iranian Oil Reaches Europe
text: Iranian oil attained a new level of restored legitimacy Monday, with word that a tanker anchored near a Spanish refinery had begun off-loading the first shipment for Europe’s consumption since the lifting of a 2012 European Union embargo.

headline: Egyptian Aviation Student Who Made Trump Threat Is Leaving U.S.
text: An Egyptian student in California has agreed to return to Cairo after he wrote a threatening comment on Facebook about Donald J. Trump that drew the attention of the Secret Service and led to the cancellation of his student visa, according to law enforcement officials and his lawyer.

headline: Donald Trump Florida Ad Hits ‘Corrupt Marco Rubio’
text: Donald J. Trump released a savage attack ad against Senator Marco Rubio of Florida that’s set to air in his home state, a 60-second takedown that calls the senator “corrupt” and accuses him of intentionally misusing a Republican Party credit card to line his pockets.

headline: Microsoft Opens Its Corporate Data Software to Linux
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Microsoft built walls between its products and the rest of the industry. Now it is tearing them down.

headline: 1916: Crazy for Chanel Sportswear
text: After the outbreak of World War I in 1914, coverage of fashion in the Herald became noticeably absent for several months. But by the autumn of 1915, Parisian life had returned to relative normality and reports of the latest trends reappeared in the pages. Below are excerpts on the success and influence of Maison Chanel in the spring of 1916:

headline: Microsoft to Close 2 Game Development Studios
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft said it planned to shut down two of its game development studios based in Europe, including the maker of the Fable fantasy series.

headline: Screening for Alzheimer’s Gene Tests the Desire to Know
text: Marty and Matt Reiswig, two brothers in Denver, knew that Alzheimer’s disease ran in their family, but neither of them understood why. Then a cousin, Gary Reiswig, whom they barely knew, wrote a book about their family, “The Thousand Mile Stare.”

headline: Thanat Khoman, Thai Statesman and Co-Founder of Asian Alliance, Dies at 101
text: BANGKOK — Thanat Khoman, a Thai diplomat and statesman who paved the way for United States military bases in Thailand during the Vietnam War and helped found the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, died on Thursday in Bangkok. He was 101.

headline: Yayoi Kusama Debuts Vivid, Whimsical Work in Hawaii
text: In anticipation of next spring’s Honolulu Biennial — which will feature local and Indo-Pacific contemporary art — the Honolulu Biennial Foundation will present Yayoi Kusama’s first Hawaiian exhibition starting this week. The Tokyo-based artist’s “Footprints of Life,” a 15-piece installation of giant blob sculptures — previously exhibited in the 2011 Aichi Triennial and Taiwan’s 2011 Taoyan Land Art Festival — can be interpreted as islands, or as a nod to Kahuli tree snails, endemic only to Oahu, which were nearly picked into extinction to decorate leis in the mid-20th century. According to Isabella Ellaheh Hughes, a co-founder of the foundation, Kusama’s piece “particularly resonates with Hawaii, because innately, this is a place where we are most attuned to our relationship with our delicate ecosystem.”

headline: Dow-DuPont Deal Seems Impermeable to a Bid by BASF
text: DuPont’s planned union with Dow Chemical, both American companies, looks like a tough nut for interlopers to crack. The German chemical giant BASF is considering a counterbid for DuPont, its rival, according to Bloomberg. But tax benefits alone make the American conglomerates’ merger and expected breakup pretty close to ironclad.

headline: At Giambattista Valli, Eyes Get a Silver Streak
text: Giambattista Valli’s fall/winter 2016 collection, which showed today in Paris, featured predominantly black and white pieces punctuated by flashes of silver. Taking a cue from the clothes, the makeup artist Val Garland created two variations of a silver liner: one across the lash line, the other under the brow, by mixing MAC’s Pigment powder in Silver with MAC’s Reflect Pearl glitter and swiping it on in a semi-cat-eye shape. She finished by dotting the corner of the eyes with a creamy highlighter. “It’s an embellished eye,” she said.

headline: Retail Health Clinics Result in Higher Spending, Survey Finds
text: Insurers and employers are eager to have workers explore new ways of getting care, like visiting a clinic at a drugstore when they have a sore throat. The care they receive not only is more convenient, but also costs much less than a visit to the emergency room or a doctor’s office.

headline: Mexico’s President Says Donald Trump Sounds Like Hitler and Mussolini
text: Donald J. Trump’s repeated threats against Mexico drew a forceful response on Monday from President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico, who vowed that his country would never pay for the Republican candidate’s much-ballyhooed border wall and warned that his language was reminiscent of Hitler and Mussolini.

headline: Former Jerusalem Bureau Chief Answers Readers’ Questions
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how daily news, features and opinion pieces come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Jodi Rudoren answers questions from readers about her four years as The Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief.

headline: Fukushima, Five Years On
text: Many people remain displaced and the cleanup of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, and the surrounding areas, may take decades or centuries.

headline: Bill Clinton Has Tough Words for Bernie Sanders in North Carolina
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. – As Hillary Clinton focused on Bernie Sanders in Michigan on Monday, the day before the primary there, her husband, former President Bill Clinton, had some tough words for Mr. Sanders in North Carolina, where early voting is underway for the March 15 nominating contest.

headline: Review: In ‘Of Kings and Prophets,’ Biblical Tales Retold
text: It’s “Game of Thrones” with less scheming and fantasy. It’s “Spartacus” with half the gratuitous violence and considerably less sex. It’s “The Bible” without much Bible.

headline: Zika Risk? Probably Not Covered by Your Travel Policy
text: Until recently, awareness of the Zika virus was largely limited to readers of infectious diseases guides who made it to the last page.

headline: There’s No One Face of Golf Right Now. No One Age, Either.
text: DORAL, Fla. — The takeaway from the World Golf Championships event here is that the Masters cannot start soon enough. Can we press the pause button and freeze the PGA Tour until April 7, the opening round of the Masters?

text: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: March 7, 2016 — Photos of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, China, Germany and the United States.

headline: Aubrey McClendon Is Remembered for Ambition and Philanthropy
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The diverse worlds of energy, politics and sports assembled at the Crossings Community Church here Monday to pay tribute to Aubrey McClendon, the natural gas wildcatting pioneer who helped catalyze the nation’s energy revolution.

headline: Economists Go Negative on Negative Interest Rates
text: When the European Central Bank meets on Thursday, policymakers are expected to push its deposit rate deeper into negative territory, to minus 0.4 percent. The stated aim is to head off deflation.

headline: The 1975’s Album Isn’t on Spotify, but It’s Still No. 1
text: How essential is Spotify in getting an album to No. 1?

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ or the Debate? What People Watched on Sunday Night
text: There was a logjam of big-event television on Sunday night. Several television executives say it is no longer relevant to review same-day ratings, but these programs are near-live events that ran head-to-head on Sunday. This is how they did.

headline: Michael Bloomberg Says He Won’t Run for President
text: Michael R. Bloomberg, who for months quietly laid the groundwork to run for president as an independent, will not enter the 2016 campaign, he said Monday, citing his fear that a three-way race could lead to the election of a candidate he thinks would endanger the country: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Donald Trump Laces Into Japan With a Trade Tirade From the ’80s
text: TOKYO — Donald J. Trump has often aimed his raucous brand of disparagement at foreign countries during his presidential run. There is China, “ripping off” the United States on trade and stealing its jobs. And Mexico, closing its eyes to a flood of migrants and drugs across the border.

headline: Maps Show Where Bloomberg Aides Thought He Would Be Competitive
text: The maps that Michael R. Bloomberg's aides used internally to guide their thinking about how he would affect the presidential race.

headline: Saint Laurent: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Hedi Slimane, who recently presented his men’s wear collection in Los Angeles, debuts his fall looks.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’: Lessons Learned After Six Seasons
text: “Downton Abbey” has poured its last cup of tea, strapped its last traveling case to the car, dispatched its last awkward reaction shot to a mildly witty bon mot. The lesson of Sunday’s series finale was that every complicated melodrama requires a multiplicity of happy endings, no matter how hurriedly achieved. The lesson of the show’s longevity and immense popularity was that even in the age of Very Serious television, our strongest appetite is for sheer escapism, and once we’re hooked we don’t really notice if what we’re being served becomes progressively less savory.

headline: Sorting Out the Ruckus in the G.O.P.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Strike by West Bank Teachers Gains Momentum, Challenging Government
text: BEITIN, West Bank — Children are watching television all night and lolling in pajamas until late afternoon. Parents are scraping together savings to hire tutors. Day care centers have extended their hours. Laith Zeidan, 17, is spending his days working in his uncle’s carwash because, as he put it, “my dad said I had to stay off the streets.”

headline: An Expansive Show of Undersung (Don’t Call them ‘Outsider’) Artists
text: When crates and boxes holding more than 1,000 artworks landed on the doorstep of the Kunsthal in Rotterdam, museum director Emily Ansenk was worried that they might not all fit inside. She soon figured out all she could do was trust James Brett, the mastermind behind the Museum of Everything, a traveling installation with art by self-taught, undiscovered and unintentional creators.

headline: Wells Fargo Charged With Fraud in Video Game Start-Up Case
text: Wells Fargo has been accused of fraud over its role in underwriting a $75 million municipal bond deal for a video game company in Rhode Island that eventually went bankrupt, leaving taxpayers on the hook for the debt.

headline: Review: Andreas Staier on the Harpsichord, Coaxing Gravity and Gloom
text: Andreas Staier’s harpsichord recital at the Frick Collection on Sunday evening was easy to respect but sometimes hard to love. Mr. Staier is an excellent and thoughtful performer on early keyboard instruments — the fortepiano as well as the harpsichord — but somewhat dour in mien, and his program here was almost unrelievedly gloomy.

headline: Review: Tonia Ko’s ‘Strange Sounds and Explosions Worldwide’
text: A listener might assume that a new symphony called “Strange Sounds and Explosions Worldwide” would depict perilous global situations. But the title of Tonia Ko’s new symphony alludes to fireworks and other joyful events, as well as natural ones like erupting volcanoes.

headline: Hopeful Start for First Uterus Transplant Surgery in U.S.
text: CLEVELAND — Just minutes after the patient’s name was placed on the waiting list for a transplant, details about a matching donor popped up.

headline: ‘Alice Isn’t Dead,’ a Dark New Fictional Podcast in a Booming Market
text: The new fictional podcast “Alice Isn’t Dead” starts with a declaration from the narrator: “This is not a story. It’s a road trip.” The aim, she continues, homing in on a mostly universal aspiration for both, is to “end up somewhere else” and to travel “a long way from where we started.”

headline: Mac ‘Ransomware’ Attack Exposes Vulnerability of Apple Users
text: For the first time, security experts say, a dangerous form of software called “ransomware” has successfully targeted a Mac operating system, piercing an image of safety that Apple customers had long enjoyed.

headline: U.S. Restricts Sales to ZTE, Saying It Breached Sanctions
text: HONG KONG — ZTE is one of China’s few truly international electronics firms. Yet American companies will now need special permission to sell to it.

headline: Mitch McConnell Bets That Impasse on Court Now Helps G.O.P. Later
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell has long antagonized Democrats with his tactics. Now he just has them perplexed, wondering why he would unilaterally block a Supreme Court nominee and potentially put vulnerable Republicans at risk with control of the Senate at stake in November.

headline: The Cosby Case: Where Things Stand
text: Bill Cosby had once been due in a Pennsylvania court on Tuesday for a hearing in the only criminal case that has been brought out of the many sexual assault accusations leveled at the once-beloved entertainer. A judicial ruling last week, though, suspended those proceedings, perhaps for many months. Below are questions and answers to help untangle the complexities of that case and five civil suits in which Mr. Cosby is also embroiled.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 4, Episode 6: Is Pollyhop a Sillier Name Than Slugline?
text: Frank Underwood is back in business. After a successful liver transplant, he recovers, leaves the hospital and, by episode’s end, reclaims his job from Donald Blythe.

headline: Erin Andrews Awarded $55 Million in Lawsuit Over Nude Video at Hotel
text: A jury awarded the Fox sportscaster Erin Andrews $55 million in her lawsuit against a Nashville hotel and a stalker after she was secretly videotaped naked several times in 2008, according to reports.

headline: Rumors Fill the Air at Hedi Slimane’s Saint Laurent Show
text: PARIS — The most urgent gossip this Paris Fashion Week has centered on Hedi Slimane, the press-averse designer of Saint Laurent, whom the rumor mill has decreed is imminently leaving Saint Laurent.

headline: For Chris Christie and Donald Trump, Ties Go Back Years
text: Gov. Chris Christie says he first met Donald J. Trump 14 years ago as a courtesy to Judge Maryanne Trump Barry, after she told him, “My little brother really wants to meet you.”

headline: Group Backing Ted Cruz Accuses Marco Rubio of ‘Cronyism’
text: Seeking to drive Senator Marco Rubio from the presidential race, a “super PAC” supporting Senator Ted Cruz is spending heavily against Mr. Rubio in Florida, his home state. The five new ads that the group, Keep the Promise I, have released attack Mr. Rubio’s attendance record in the Senate, his stand on immigration, his tax plan and his relationship with Florida’s sugar producers.

headline: Diplo and Major Lazer Headline in Havana
text: The first concert in Cuba by a major U.S. pop act since the reinstatement of diplomatic relations between the countries drew an estimated 450,000 people.

headline: Diplo and Major Lazer Bring Their Brand of Music to Cuba
text: HAVANA — “I know you’ve been waiting a long time for a party like this,” the D.J. and producer Diplo called out to a sea of pulsating young Cubans here on Sunday evening, during a free concert by his Caribbean-influenced electronic group, Major Lazer.

headline: Julie Kent to Lead Washington Ballet
text: Julie Kent, a beloved ballerina who danced her final performance with American Ballet Theater last June after spending nearly three decades with the company, will be the next artistic director of the Washington Ballet, the company announced on Monday.

headline: Justice Dept. Appeals Ruling in Apple iPhone Case in Brooklyn
text: WASHINGTON — In the latest volley in its high-profile fight with Apple, the Justice Department said on Monday that a federal judge in Brooklyn had erred last week in refusing to order the company to unlock a drug dealer’s iPhone.

headline: Nancy Reagan, the Happiest First Lady
text: FOR more than two hours, Nancy Reagan sat behind the artist Everett Raymond Kinstler as he painted her husband’s portrait in his New York City studio shortly after the Reagans left the White House. Mr. Kinstler, who had done several portraits of President Gerald Ford, was unnerved by Mrs. Reagan’s intensity. “It was terribly distracting,” he recalled. When he asked if she would wait in the living room, Mrs. Reagan replied, unmoved, “No, I really would like to stay here while you work.”

headline: Towns Run by Polygamist Sect Violated Rights of Others, Jury Finds
text: PHOENIX — Two towns run by the polygamist sect controlled by Warren Jeffs routinely violated the civil rights of nonbelievers by discriminating against them in housing permits, policing and utilities hookups, a Federal District Court jury here found Monday.

headline: Democracy’s Disintegration in Turkey
text: If there was any doubt about why the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan seized the newspaper Zaman last week, consider this: Within 48 hours after the takeover, the paper began publishing pro-Erdogan propaganda.

headline: New York to Pay Thousands to 10 Tenants Purged From Rent Freeze Program
text: New York City has agreed to pay $130,000 in legal fees and damages to 10 older or disabled residents who said they were unfairly removed from the Rent Freeze Program after their spouses or parents died.

headline: Jacob deGrom Grumbles, and It Fails to Resonate With Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Brown hair flowing from beneath his blue-and-orange cap, Jacob deGrom moved not a strand when asked about that little old contract deal.

headline: Return of Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist and Rick Nash Draws Near
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Henrik Lundqvist and Rick Nash will miss Tuesday’s game at Buffalo, but they appear closer to returning to the Rangers’ lineup.

headline: Oil Prices Perk Up, Suggesting a Rebound Has Taken Hold
text: After a prolonged slide that took oil prices within sight of the $20-a-barrel threshold last month, sentiment in commodity markets seems to have turned, raising the question of whether oil prices have finally bottomed out.

headline: Elizabeth Garrett, First Female President of Cornell, Dies at 52
text: Elizabeth Garrett, a lawyer and scholar who was the first woman to be president of Cornell University, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan, only eight months after starting the post. She was 52.

headline: Bill Clinton Defends Hillary Clinton, Not Himself, in North Carolina
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — If Bill Clinton felt raked over the coals during the Democratic debate on Sunday night, he didn’t seem sore about it on his three-city swing through North Carolina on Monday.

headline: Lurid Suit Over Hate Mail Embroils Isaac Perlmutter, Marvel Chief
text: Scandals in Palm Beach, Fla., are as much a part of the landscape as Lilly Pulitzer and plastic surgery. In recent years, the wealthy enclave has been rocked by the Bernard L. Madoff Ponzi scheme and the Jeffrey Epstein underage-sex lawsuit, to name just two.

headline: Astoria Residents Say Suspect in Fatal Spree Was a Troubled Local Fixture
text: They are as much a fixture on the streets of Astoria, Queens, as the souvlaki shops and markets selling lamb and feta straight from Greece: a group of about a dozen men, of varying ages, who share the same bleary eyes and frequently unsteady gaits when their indulgences — in marijuana and liquor — catch up to them. Well known to shop owners and local residents, the men stand out from the increasingly hip and well-heeled new arrivals to the neighborhood — ruffians, but benign, viewed more as lost than as a menace.

headline: Mitt Romney Records Phone Message for Marco Rubio’s Campaign
text: Offering Senator Marco Rubio of Florida a much-needed boost, if not an outright endorsement, Mitt Romney has recorded get-out-the-vote calls for Mr. Rubio’s presidential campaign that are being sent to voters in the four states voting on Tuesday.

headline: In This Crowd, It’s O.K. to Stare
text: With college basketball’s postseason in full swing, casual television viewers soon will see famous faces popping up at games across the country: Kim Kardashian. Donald Trump. Miss Universe. Not their actual faces, but rather their attention-grabbing likenesses: oversized cutouts of their heads, waved around by fans looking to draw the eye of both opposing shooters and network cameras.

headline: Netanyahu Calls Off Obama Visit, and Fingers Point
text: WASHINGTON — When it comes to the strained relationship between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, even a single missed meeting is cause for grievance and accusations.

headline: Peyton Manning: Epitome of a Golden Age Goes Out on Top
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — Peyton Manning is the pillar of an enduring, golden era of professional quarterbacks, which will end over the next few years when we see the retirements of Tom Brady, Drew Brees and Philip Rivers.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton Draw Sharp Questions at Fox News Forum
text: DETROIT — The night after a testy Democratic debate, Senator Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton had the chance to confront another adversary: Fox News.

headline: Review: ‘The Royale’ Harks Back to the Fighter Jack Johnson
text: Jay Jackson has found the zone, a place where all he hears is the upbeat percussion of his own thoughts and the drumming of flesh hitting flesh. A declaration of satisfaction purrs out of this perfectly proportioned giant, delivered both to himself and to the young opponent who has surprised him by giving almost as good as he gets: “We’re making music, boy.”

headline: Warm Fuzzies
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — This was a straightforward circled-answer puzzle with a good number of long clues for early in the week – potentially slow going for a new solver, but the corners used crossword standards like ASSUAGE, THANE and UPROOT that you will encounter again. Odd little semi-words like AHH, URL and SLR contributed to the challenge here.

headline: Several More Ex-Guantánamo Detainees Suspected of Militancy, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Intelligence analysts now believe that an additional former Guantánamo Bay detainee has engaged in terrorist activity after his release, while seven more have been added to a roster of those who might be causing problems, according to data disclosed on Monday.

headline: ‘Blindspot’ Season 1, Episode 12: Supersoldiers
text: Things we learned Monday night about Agent Kurt Weller’s father:

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 2, Episode 4:
text: At last, a Season 2 episode of “Better Call Saul” that demonstrates how gripping this show can get.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I think it’s very important to have a great team around you with coaches and doctors, but, at the end of the day, everything you do is on you.”

headline: F.C.C. Fine-Tunes Plan to Subsidize Internet Access
text: WASHINGTON — People who do not have regular access to the Internet can fall behind in school, at work and in other everyday tasks. The Federal Communications Commission is close to what it hopes will be a solution to address that gap: $9.25 a month.

headline: Genetic Test Firm to Make Customers’ Data Publicly Available
text: In an unusual move, a leading genetic testing company is making genetic information from the people it has tested publicly available, a move the company says could make a large trove of data available to researchers looking for genes linked to various diseases.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
text: Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara earned Oscar nominations for their portrayal of women in love in Todd Haynes’s “Carol.” “New Girl” celebrates its 100th episode. And “Of Kings and Prophets” brings the Books of Samuel to television.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Day 8 With Chanel and Valentino
text: PARIS — Tuesday may be the penultimate stretch — with just 36 hours to go until the end of the fall 2016 season — but it holds some big-name shows.

headline: South Korea Accuses North of Hacking Senior Officials’ Phones
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Nearly a year and a half after North Korea was accused of mounting a sophisticated cyberattack against Sony Pictures Entertainment, South Korea’s intelligence agency accused the country of hacking into the smartphones of dozens of senior government officials, and suggested that the North could be preparing a major cyberattack.

headline: Hopping Freight Trains With the Dirty Kids
text: A loose-knit band of young vagabonds seeks peace, love and community going state to state hitchhiking and hopping freight trains.

headline: Methane Has Never Looked So Beautiful
text: What looks like a page ripped from an alien’s dream journal is actually a frozen lake containing methane bubbles trapped in icy cells in Alberta, Canada. In January and February when the lake has frozen over and abrasive winter winds have polished the ice, visitors can peer through a window into one of Earth’s most mesmerizing natural prisons.

headline: Hopping Freight Trains With the Dirty Kids
text: If you combine the tinge of loneliness in Jimmie Rodgers’s “Waiting for a Train” with the outcast mentality of Bob Dylan’s “I Am a Lonesome Hobo,” you might understand the millennial hippiedom of a group called Dirty Kids. They’re not a band, but a self-proclaimed set of countercultural vagabonds: a new wave of nomadic, homeless youth traveling state to state hitchhiking, sleeping in cars and hopping on freight trains.

headline: It’s Not Too Late!
text: It’s 2 a.m. The bar is closing. Republicans have had a series of strong and nasty Trump cocktails. Suddenly Ted Cruz is beginning to look kind of attractive. At least he’s sort of predictable, and he doesn’t talk about his sexual organs in presidential debates!

headline: Will Trump Send Working-Class Whites to the Democrats?
text: Democrats have regularly argued that, with a robust populist pitch, winning back white working-class voters could be within reach.

headline: Reducing Drug Waste Could Save Billions of Dollars
text: Given how expensive many cancer drugs are, it is alarming that the government, private insurers and patients spend an estimated $3 billion a year on cancer medicines that are thrown out because they are packaged in unnecessarily large quantities. The Food and Drug Administration ought to figure out ways to reduce this costly waste.

headline: The Presidential Plot Thickens
text: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. What a week, right? No huge surprises on Super Tuesday, as Trump increased his plurality with wins in a majority of states. Thursday’s Republican debate was yet another dumpster fire of insults and name-calling.

headline: Migrant Children Deserve a Voice in Court
text: In this time of political absurdity, can it be any surprise that a federal immigration judge insists that toddlers can represent themselves in immigration court?

headline: Limit the Next President’s Power to Wage Drone Warfare
text: WHEN Barack Obama took office as the reluctant heir to George W. Bush’s “war on terror,” he renounced some of his predecessor’s most extreme policies. There is one Bush-era policy, though, that President Obama made emphatically his own: the summary killing of suspected militants and terrorists, usually by drone.

text: First of two articles

headline: Chinese Publication, Censored by Government, Exposes Article’s Removal
text: A news organization led by one of China’s most prominent journalists is sounding the alarm about censorship and the growing restrictions on free speech, citing a source very familiar with the situation: itself.

headline: News Q’s | Marine Life Thrives in Unlikely Place: Offshore Oil Rigs
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Marine Life Thrives in Unlikely Place: Offshore Oil Rigs.”

headline: What We’re Watching as 4 States Vote and Both Parties Court Michigan
text: Join us for live updates of the March 8 primaries.

headline: Pentagon Has Plan to Cripple ISIS in Libya With Air Barrage
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has presented the White House with the most detailed set of military options yet for attacking the growing Islamic State threat in Libya, including a range of potential airstrikes against training camps, command centers, munitions depots and other militant targets.

headline: Student Question | How Do You Celebrate Your Birthday?
text: Birthdays can often be a huge deal for children: themed parties, elaborate cakes, lots of presents, even goody bags. But at some point, do we outgrow celebrating our birthday? Or is it still fun to celebrate ourselves once a year with friends and family?

headline: ‘The Profiteers,’ by Sally Denton
text: When James Madison discussed the relationship between corporations and government, he sounded as if he were knocking on doors for Bernie Sanders. “The stockjobbers,” he wrote, “will become the pretorian band of the Government, at once its tool and its tyrant.” But stop right there. You might recognize Madison’s worry about corporations being government’s “tyrant,” but “its tool”?

headline: ‘Because of Sex,’ by Gillian Thomas
text: In the 1960s, Congress passed two bills that changed the working world for women — although, at the time, their impact was far from clear. The aim of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 was certainly not focused on women’s concerns; nor was the vote in 1968 to remove the draft exemption for law school students. But the effects were far-reaching: Law school seats suddenly opened up for women, and as the A.C.L.U. attorney Gillian Thomas suggests in her new book, many of those women went on to fight discrimination in the workplace.
