text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Even for the sport’s best, any success against top-ranked Novak Djokovic — however relative — must be appreciated.

headline: Virginia’s Offense Comes Alive Against Butler
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — Virginia added to an unconventional N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament on Saturday night, but not in the manner of the upset stories that have ruled the first four days. The Cavaliers, regarded as a ferocious defensive team, turned themselves into an offensive locomotive against Butler.

headline: Protester Punched and Kicked at Donald Trump Rally in Tucson
text: Donald J. Trump’s second rally in Arizona on Saturday was studded with repeated interruptions from protesters, along with an incident in which a member of the crowd punched and kicked a protester and another that involved Mr. Trump’s campaign manager.

headline: Ania Barkhordaryan, Raymond Iryami
text: Ania Barkhordaryan, a daughter of Delkash Barkhordarian and Feizallah Barkhordarian of Great Neck, N.Y., is to be married March 20 to Raymond Iryami, a son of Helen Iryami and Dr. Nasser Iryami, also of Great Neck. Rabbi Yedidia Ezrakhian is to perform the ceremony at Temple Israel of Great Neck.

headline: Alyssa Carbone and Jeremy Kees: Alarm Bells Rang, Then Came Wedding Bells
text: Alyssa Maria Carbone and Jeremy David Kees were married March 19. The groom’s father, the Rev. Denton Kees, who is a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Montclair, N.J.

headline: Emily Evans, Adam Schifter
text: Emily Nicole Evans, a daughter of Diane O. Evans and Daryl W. Evans of Atlanta, was married there March 19 to Adam Daniel Schifter, the son of Diane F. Schifter and Dr. Tobias Schifter of Tempe, Ariz. The Rev. Thomas B. Shuler, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Spirit Catholic Church.

headline: Jessica Furst, David Starr
text: Dr. Jessica Rachel Furst, a daughter of Dr. Elisabeth Gomori of Great Neck, N.Y., and Michael L. Furst of Forest Hills, Queens, is to be married March 20 to David Burke Starr, a son of Dr. Susan F. Burke and Dr. Byron D. Starr of River Forest, Ill. Rabbi Andy Bachman is to officiate at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: Celia Berger, Peter Hatfield
text: Celia Faith Berger, a daughter of Caroline A. Anderson of Evanston, Ill., and Stuart M. Berger of Wilmette, Ill., was married on March 19 to Peter Carey Hatfield, a son of Susan C. Hatfield and William F. Hatfield of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Erik W. Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the St. George’s School Chapel in Middletown, R.I.

headline: Elizabeth Corr, Timothy Sheils
text: Elizabeth Ann Corr, the daughter of Jean P. Corr and Patrick J. Corr of Seattle, was married March 18 to Timothy Thomas Sheils, the son of Shelby A. Sheils and John M. Sheils of Portland, Ore. The Rev. John Amsberry, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of Christ the Teacher on the campus of the University of Portland.

headline: Kimberley Jones, Paul Rodler
text: Kimberley Jebeles Jones and Paul Erich Rodler were married March 19 at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. The Rev. Jude Harmon, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Arielle Gelman, Justin Cohen
text: Arielle Michele Gelman, a daughter of Pamela A. Gelman of Jenkintown, Pa., and Dr. Bruce P. Gelman of Elkins Park, Pa., is to be married March 20 to Justin Shawn Cohen, a son of Cheryl F. Cohen and Dr. Barton E. Cohen of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Sherman is to perform the ceremony, with Cantor David F. Tilman taking part, at Congregation Beth El in Voorhees, N.J.

headline: Taylor Breen, Justin Schacter
text: Taylor Morgan Breen, a daughter of Robin D. Breen of Delray Beach, Fla., and Todd M. Breen of Roslyn, N.Y., was married March 19 to Justin Max Schacter, a son of Barbara E. Schacter and Dr. Michael A. Schacter of White Plains. Rabbi Michael White officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan.

headline: Maura Roche, Nicholas Reynolds
text: Maura Rose Roche and Nicholas Edward Reynolds were married March 15 at the Basilica of St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral in Manhattan. Msgr. Donald Sakano performed the ceremony.

headline: Erin Monju and Ryan Whalen: Chuck Schumer Plays Romantic Cheerleader, Again
text: Erin Katherine Monju, the daughter of Patricia M. Monju of New Orleans and John E. Monju of Lafayette, La., was married March 18 to Ryan Michael Whalen, the son of Linda E. McDonough of Boston, and Joseph M. Whalen of Quincy, Mass. Patrick J. Muncie, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion , officiated at Race and Religious, an event space in New Orleans.

headline: Asha Talwar, Matthew Coco
text: Asha Kiran Talwar and Matthew Congrove Coco were married March 19 by Lisa Traina, a Universal Life minister, at the St. Regis in New York in a ceremony that combined Christian and Hindu traditions.

headline: Adam Plotkin, Adam Abrahams
text: Adam Jonathan Plotkin, the son of Mari Plotkin and Dr. David Plotkin of Short Hills, N.J., is to be married March 20 to Adam Bernard Abrahams, a son of Sheila Abrahams and Alan Abrahams of Issaquah, Wash. Rabbi Celia Surget is to officiate on the Grand Terrace of St. Pancras International, a railway station in London.

headline: Kristen Stevens, Michael Maggiore
text: Kristen Ann Stevens and Michael John Maggiore were married March 18 at the home of friends of the couple, Neslihan Danisman and David Bourgeois, in Brooklyn. Ghita Schwarz, a friend of the couple who is affiliated with Universal Ministries in Milford, Ill., officiated.

headline: Allison Harris, Amir Fairdosi
text: Allison Patterson Harris and Amir Shawn Fairdosi are to be married March 20 at the James A. Michener Art Museum in Doylestown, Pa. The Rev. Geoffrey A. Black, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to officiate.

headline: Sabina Pendse, John Byck
text: Sabina Devi Pendse and John Ivey Byck were married March 19 at Haven’s Kitchen, a cafe, cooking school and event space in New York. John C. Collins Jr., a friend of the groom’s family and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Spurs Add to Streak as Warriors Fall to 62-7
text: SAN ANTONIO — The Golden State Warriors have been a history-making machine this season, overshadowing nearly every team that tries to impede their progress. The San Antonio Spurs, though, are assembling a magical season of their own, and they stifled the Warriors, 87-79, on Saturday night at AT&T Center to make a little history of their own.

headline: Trump Didn’t Put the Con in Conservatism
text: So, I’m in a time zone far, far away — and also still shaky, although I’m finally managing to hold down some food. Output will still be low, but I wanted to note something about the reactions to the John Harwood interview with Paul Ryan, which are very relevant to understanding the Republican mess.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Salah Abdeslam, European Union, Donald Trump
text: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on the Apple iPhone Case
text: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on the Apple iPhone Case

headline: Apple vs. the F.B.I.: How the Case Could Play Out
text: Apple is getting ready for a busy week.

headline: 1941: 3,000 Pigeons to Go Abroad
text: Fear of breaking the United States neutrality law was neatly handled yesterday by Godfrey Haggard, British Consul General in New York, when he decided to send 3,000 young American homing pigeons to ‘‘pigeon fanciers on the other side of the Atlantic’’ instead of to the Royal Air Force, for which they are intended.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: 1966: U.S. to Allow Wives’ Return To Vietnam
text: SAIGON — Despite the threat of terrorist activity against Americans here, the State Department has made a quiet decision to allow some governmental wives to join their husbands in Saigon. Most U.S. officials here, even those in the military who apparently will not be able to bring over wives, give their approval.

headline: At Site of Gay Man’s Murder, a Street Corner Acknowledges Its Past
text: There is little about the intersection of 78th Street and 37th Avenue to distinguish it from any other corner in Jackson Heights. Every day, dozens of parents — from dozens of countries — waiting for their children to be dismissed from school stand beneath a sign declaring the intersection “Julio Rivera Corner.” Many of them probably do not even notice it, yet with those three words, the sign acknowledges a tragic — and ultimately transforming — moment in Queens.

headline: Donald Trump Courts Wary Jewish Voters
text: On paper, Donald J. Trump is the last candidate one would expect to raise eyebrows within the Jewish community.

headline: Geoffrey H. Hartman, Scholar Who Saw Literary Criticism as Art, Dies at 86
text: Geoffrey H. Hartman, a literary critic whose work took in the Romantic poets, Judaic sacred texts, Holocaust studies, deconstruction and the workings of memory — and took on the very function of criticism itself — died on March 14 at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 86.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: Tyler Perry’s Easter season extravaganza, “The Passion,” is the latest entry in the growing genre of live TV musicals. And America’s favorite gal pals, Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, are back together in “Sisters,” streaming online.

headline: Turkish Member of ISIS Carried Out Istanbul Bombing, Official Says
text: ISTANBUL — A Turkish member of the Islamic State was the perpetrator of a suicide bombing that killed four foreigners in Istanbul over the weekend, the Turkish interior minister said on Sunday.

headline: ‘Zootopia’ Is Still the Top Film, While ‘Allegiant’ Falters
text: No amount of slick marketing can sell a terrible movie.

headline: Why the Republicans May Do Little in Congress
text: Remember the first branch of American government? With all the attention to the presidential race and the partisan fight over President Obama’s nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court, Congress seems an afterthought.

headline: Donald Trump Faults Protesters Over Violence, Not Their Assailants
text: After his rallies in Arizona this weekend were marked by protests and violence, Donald J. Trump on Sunday complained of a “double standard” in coverage of those incidents and defended his campaign manager after video showed the manager grabbing a demonstrator by the collar and yanking him backward during a rally in Tucson.

headline: As Obama Arrives, Cuba Tightens Grip on Dissent
text: HAVANA — President Obama touched down in Cuba on Sunday, pledging to interact directly with the Cuban people and accelerate engagement between the United States and Cuba after more than a half-century of hostility.

headline: ‘Ip Man 3’ Distributor Is Punished Over Box-Office Fraud
text: Chinese film regulators have cracked down on the film distributor Beijing Max Screen over inflation of ticket sales for the movie “Ip Man 3.” Max Screen has admitted to inflating box-office figures by more than $8.6 million, and has been barred from releasing movies for a month, according to Xinhua News Agency.

headline: Sherwin-Williams to Buy Valspar for $9.3 Billion
text: Sherwin-Williams’s famous logo shows a can of red paint pouring over a globe with the slogan “Cover the Earth.”

headline: A Signature ISIS Explosive in Europe
text: Triacetone triperoxide, which was used in the Paris attacks in November, has become the Islamic State's explosive of choice in Europe. Specialists in bomb detection explain why.

headline: Seeking Access to Facebook in China, Zuckerberg Courts Risks
text: HONG KONG — In terms of publicity, it was a great weekend for Mark Zuckerberg in China.

headline: Bus Crash in Spain Kills at Least 13, Officials Say
text: At least 13 students died on Sunday when a bus crashed on a highway in eastern Spain while on its way back to Barcelona from a day of festivities in Valencia, Spanish officials said.

headline: Garland Shouldn’t Be Considered After Election, McConnell Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, on Sunday dismissed the possibility of Republicans considering President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee after the November election, even if a Democrat were elected president or Republicans lost their majority.

headline: College Sharpshooters Add Theatrics to Their Quivers
text: Cupid. Artemis. Robin Hood. Katniss Everdeen. Jamal Murray. Great archers, all of them.

headline: Villanova Routs Iowa to Advance to Round of 16
text: Since Villanova arrived in Brooklyn last week, the Wildcats have been shadowed by questions about their recent inability to advance past the round of 32 at the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Majority Threshold ‘Unfair’ in G.O.P. Nomination Process, Donald Trump Complains
text: With the prospect of a contested convention looming over the Republican presidential primary, Donald J. Trump on Sunday complained about the party’s rules requiring a candidate to have a majority of delegates to clinch the nomination outright.

headline: After Loss, Warriors Are Bullish as Ever in Pursuit of a Record
text: SAN ANTONIO — Draymond Green of the Golden State Warriors was minutes removed from a rare loss when he fielded a question about the team’s pursuit of the 1995-96 Chicago Bulls for the best record in N.B.A. history. Green asked for clarification: What sort of work did the Warriors have ahead of them? Eleven wins in their final 13 games?

headline: John Kasich Says G.O.P. Senators Should Meet With Supreme Court Nominee
text: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio expressed openness this weekend to considering Judge Merrick B. Garland for the Supreme Court, only to later clarify that he was just being polite and would not, in fact, choose him for the court.

headline: Shukhov Tower in Moscow Placed on Monuments Watch List
text: The Shukhov Tower, a 1920s broadcast transmission tower in Moscow that is a landmark of modernist structural engineering, has been placed on the 2016 World Monuments Fund Watch list of endangered global cultural heritage sites.

headline: Cubans Pack the Streets for a Glimpse of President Obama
text: HAVANA — Shouts of “U.S.A.!” and “Obama!” echoed over the stone plazas as President Obama and his family made their way around rain-slicked courtyards in Old Havana on Sunday evening, savoring the adulation of Cubans welcoming him warmly despite a driving rain as he began a history-making visit.

headline: Hillary Clinton Campaign Has Raised Millions Toward Beating Bernie Sanders
text: Hillary Clinton’s campaign raised more than $30.1 million in February to be used toward defeating Senator Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary and began March with $30.8 million on hand, according to the campaign’s Federal Election Commission report released on Sunday.

headline: Amazon Leans on Government in Its Quest to Be a Delivery Powerhouse
text: WASHINGTON — Ever since Jeff Bezos started the website Amazon to sell books, he has wrestled with how to deliver its products as quickly and cheaply as possible. Today, Amazon, now a retail giant, remains obsessed with this issue, building its own fleet of drones, buying trailers for trucks and signing up drivers for on-demand deliveries.

headline: Julie Kent on Her Plans for Showcasing Washington Dancers
text: Julie Kent told her Instagram followers about her new job earlier this month with a link to an article and a single word: “Surprise!”

headline: Review: ‘Witchcraft: The Jazz Magic of Cy Coleman’ Summons a Bygone Era
text: By the end of Saturday’s opening-night performance of “Witchcraft: The Jazz Magic of Cy Coleman” at the 92nd Street Y, anyone present could be forgiven for imagining that the clock had magically been turned back to 1965 or thereabouts. In a shimmering musical mirage, the bygone Manhattan night life of 50 years ago came into view.

headline: Review: Orpheus’s Shifting Glimmers From Angled Glass
text: To New Yorkers whose daily commute takes them along the West Side Highway, Jean Nouvel’s building at 100 West 11th Avenue, which its architect describes as a “vision machine,” is a familiar sight, a curved structure set with thousands of angled glass panes that make a kaleidoscope of the blues, grays and greens of the sky and river.

headline: Classical Playlist: Brouwer, ‘Cantate Domino’ and More
text: Pedro Chamorro, bandurria; Pedro Mateo González, guitar (Naxos)

headline: Review: Trinity Wall Street Presents Ginastera’s Raging ‘Cantata Para América Mágica’
text: In 1961, two works by Alberto Ginastera — his Piano Concerto No. 1 and “Cantata Para América Mágica” — were given their premieres in Washington as part of the second Inter-American Music Festival. Have they ever been played in such proximity since?

headline: ‘War of the Worlds’ Shape-Shifts Onto the London Stage
text: LONDON — For Americans, “War of the Worlds” evokes images of panic and devastation in New Jersey set to the voice of Orson Welles crackling over the radio in 1938. But in Britain, a 1978 prog-rock album that dramatized H. G. Wells’s tale of Martian takeover is far better known.

headline: Review: ‘Kapoor & Sons’ Centers on an Indian Family’s Flaws
text: “Kapoor & Sons — Since 1921” isn’t about the dynastic family of Hindi movie directors, actors and producers. But it does star one of them, Rishi Kapoor (son of Raj, father of Ranbir), who heavily (and skillfully) made up plays Dadu, the about-to-be-90 paterfamilias of a clan made unhappy by the usual secrets and lies and long-cherished grudges.

headline: Flinging Emojis, Twitch Chatters Revel as Julia Child Cooks
text: When I was a teenager, my friends and I had a blast watching television together — often really bad television — and mocking it ceaselessly. We became the entertainment, not whatever clumsy dialogue or plot twist we derided.

headline: Last-Second Tip-In Shines Spotlight on a Notre Dame Guard
text: Entering Notre Dame’s matchup with Stephen F. Austin, Rex Pflueger was a sparingly used, little-known freshman guard for the Irish who had not scored a field goal since March 5.

headline: Review: Balanchine and Shakespeare Catch Some Waves in Miami
text: MIAMI — As if to illustrate the effects of climate change, Miami City Ballet has set its new production of George Balanchine’s two-act “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” underwater. Transposing the action to the waterways of South Florida, the production is a peak of this company’s 30th-anniversary season. Although the staging does not makes much sense on its own terms and in no way improves the ballet, its daftness is agreeably harmless: You can vaguely enjoy some of its fantasies while seriously loving the choreography. And the Miamians’ dancing has all the wonderful immediacy that makes this company valuable.

headline: Review: In ‘Switched On,’ John Elder Robison’s Asperger’s Brain Is Changed
text: From an early age, it was clear that John Elder Robison had been wired with extra fibers for appreciating music. He could easily hear the difference between one kind of Fender bass and another. He could recognize which of 100 speakers in a sound system was groaning in distress. He could take any musical gizmo and, as Nigel Tufnel might say, make it go to 11. (His talent for creating fire-breathing guitars earned him a gig with Kiss as a young man.)

headline: Anger After Official Says WTA Players Ride on ‘Coattails’ of Men
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The final Sunday of the BNP Paribas Open, one of the biggest joint ATP-WTA events outside the Grand Slam tournaments, is often a showcase for tennis’s superstars, with the women’s and men’s finals played back to back.

headline: SXSW 2016
text: Scenes from concerts by Iggy Pop, Drake and other performers at South by Southwest in Austin, Tex.

headline: SXSW: From Exclusive Performances to Cellphone Souvenirs
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — “I want everybody to download that song, and I want all of you singing that anthem.” Sentiments like that were heard all over South by Southwest music festival, which brought more than 2,000 acts to perform here over five frenetic days and nights. But that request came from Michelle Obama as she promoted “This Is for My Girls,” a single that benefits Let Girls Learn, a project encouraging girls’ education worldwide that was written by Diane Warren and is performed by Missy Elliott, Janelle Monáe, Kelly Rowland, Kelly Clarkson and others. The first lady shared a panel with Ms. Warren and Ms. Elliott along with Queen Latifah and Sophia Bush, extolling the cultural and economic benefits of girls’ education as well as diversity in every field. (Responding to an audience question, Ms. Obama also ruled out the possibility of her running for president.)

headline: Top-Secret
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Molweni, sawubona and hallo! Those are greetings in Xhosa, Zulu and Afrikaans, respectively.

headline: Angela Merkel’s Trust in Turkey and Greece on Migrants Comes With Risks
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel, alternately lauded for courage and reviled for recklessness in admitting more than one million migrants into Germany, finally has what she wanted: a European Union accord with Turkey to reduce and manage the influx.

headline: Jessica Lang Dance to Put Down Roots in Long Island City
text: Jessica Lang Dance, after several nomadic years of renting studio space around New York, is putting down roots in the culture-rich neighborhood of Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Paris Suspect Salah Abdeslam Said to Envision a ‘Restart,’ Officials Say
text: BRUSSELS — Salah Abdeslam, the man believed to be a direct participant in the November attacks in Paris who was arrested on Friday, was planning to “restart something” in Brussels, Belgium’s foreign minister said on Sunday.

headline: Tensions Rise in David Cameron’s Government Over E.U. Vote
text: LONDON — With a referendum on Britain’s membership in the European Union fewer than 100 days away, Prime Minister David Cameron faced deepening fissures within his government on Sunday, underscoring the risk that his Conservative Party could be torn apart over the country’s relationship with the Continent.

headline: Greece Struggles to Enforce Migrant Accord on First Day
text: ATHENS — Greece and the European Union scrambled on Sunday to put in place the people and the facilities needed to carry out a new deal intended to address the migrant crisis that is roiling Europe, as hundreds of migrants in rubber dinghies continued to land on the Greek islands from Turkey.

headline: U.S. Casts Wary Eye on Australian Port Leased by Chinese
text: DARWIN, Australia — The port in this remote northern Australian outpost is little more than a graying old wharf jutting into crocodile-infested waters. On a recent day, there was stifling heat but not a ship in sight. “Our pissy little port,” as John Robinson, a flamboyant local tycoon, calls it.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 21
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: N.C.A.A. Favorites End a Few Charmed Runs
text: Cinderella almost looked like a Lumberjack.

headline: Kraft Reveals Revamped Mac and Cheese, 50 Million Boxes Later
text: USUALLY when companies come out with a new and improved formula, they want the public to know. But when the item in question is an iconic food product, the calculus gets tougher. Every marketer remembers with a shudder the cautionary tale of New Coke.

headline: Manhattan Incompatibility: A Poem
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Hollywood Divided Over Movie Streaming Service
text: LOS ANGELES — Tech entrepreneurs are always rolling into Hollywood with new services that are supposed to modernize the movie business. If only the dusty, old, dimwitted studios and theater companies would stop dragging their feet and sign up, all of the entertainment industry’s problems would be solved.

headline: Billy Eppler Is Rebuilding the Angels, but on a Fast Track
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — Everybody wears red around the Los Angeles Angels. It has been their primary color since 2002, when they won their only World Series. They often wear red jerseys with red numerals. Their executives wear red golf shirts. Their players wear red undershirts, sweatshirts and shorts. The 3-foot Darth Vader figurine in the middle of the locker room? He wears a red jersey, too.

headline: Hawaii Struggles to Keep Rail Project From Becoming a Boondoggle
text: KAPOLEI, Hawaii — From the start — when Honolulu officials began talking about building a 20-mile elevated train line near the southern coast of Oahu — there were concerns. How much would it cost? What would it do to the character of a state that has long celebrated its natural beauty and isolation? Can an island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean handle the kind of ambitious public works project one would associate with urban centers like Boston and New York?

headline: Cash (From Cans) Is King
text: The Thrifty Redemption Center in Borough Park, Brooklyn, where individuals can get paid for empty bottles and cans. The city has tried to limit the practice.

headline: New York City Fights Scavengers Over a Treasure: Trash
text: The video begins with ominous notes from a piano and an image of crime scene tape. The camera pans to men hunched over garbage pails, sifting for bottles, and a stoop-shouldered woman towing a shopping cart full of cans. Some might feel sympathy for these collectors, but the video makes clear that the New York City Sanitation Department, which made the video and posted it online, wanted them to be seen as something else: common criminals.

headline: Donald Trump Is a Punch Line for Obama, Who Is Getting More Jokes Ready
text: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump’s transformation from reality TV star to presidential candidate threatening to tear apart the Republican Party is eliciting a mixture of disbelief, outrage and laughter among Democrats, and none more so than President Obama.

headline: Russian Town Says Bleak Film Depiction Went Heavy on the Vodka
text: TERIBERKA, Russia — Tatyana Trubilina, the head of the local council in this desolate Russian outpost on the Barents Sea, wanted to make a few things absolutely clear: Not all 1,000 residents are alcoholics; not everyone is depressed; and nobody has committed suicide, at least not recently.

headline: A Manchester Derby With an Unfamiliar Focus: The Future
text: MANCHESTER, England — The 171st game between Manchester City and Manchester United was, much like the previous 170, emotional. There were fans in blue (City) and fans in red (United). There was chanting (some of it encouraging) and singing (some of it crude). There was, it seemed, a fair bit of prematch drinking. All pretty standard.

headline: As Coal’s Future Grows Murkier, Banks Pull Financing
text: Tens of thousands of miners were on strike and coal prices were skyrocketing in October 1902. Afraid of unrest, President Theodore Roosevelt sought the help of John Pierpont Morgan.

headline: Obama Begins Visit to Cuba
text: President Obama on Sunday became the first sitting United States president to visit the island since 1928.

headline: Older Voters May Be Hillary Clinton’s Answer to Bernie Sanders’s Youth Appeal
text: LAKE WORTH, Fla. — The afternoon of the Florida primaries last week, Sylvia Wolfson, 87, and more than a dozen other retirees scurried around an office set up with trays of cookies from Costco and large-print instructions on how to unlock the restroom door.

headline: Queens Bouncer With Imposing Physique Is Remembered as a Peacemaker
text: He had the look of an enforcer, a tough man with 22-inch biceps. But the bouncer known by almost everyone as Dale had a reputation around Johnny’s, a hopping Caribbean restaurant and bar in the South Ozone Park neighborhood of Queens, for his ability to ease alcohol-inflamed tensions without having to get physical.

headline: Apple iPhone Hearing, VW Diesel Update and Luxury Cars
text: More than two dozen European countries will ask the Supreme Court on Monday to let them sue in an American court. They said R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company participated in an international money laundering scheme, using drug money to buy tobacco, in violation of the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO.

headline: A Change of Heart
text: The artificial heart became a media sensation in the 1980s as it both raised hopes and spread controversy. Today, its impact on medical science is still playing out in surprising ways.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “The government of Cuba is like a father. Strong, but worried about the family.”

headline: Imagine the Big East, Coast to Coast
text: DENVER — Mark Few stood outside the Gonzaga locker room Saturday after his Bulldogs had mopped the court with yet another opponent from a supposedly stronger conference.

headline: The Mutual Dependence of Donald Trump and the News Media
text: Did you catch the Trump-Kelly bout Friday night? What a show.

headline: Making Bracket Wasn’t a Given, but Syracuse Looks as if It Belongs
text: ST. LOUIS — Few expected to see either team playing in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Sunday. Syracuse had needed the equivalent of a favorable roll in the men’s basketball selection committee room one week earlier even to be in the bracket. And Middle Tennessee State had to accomplish probably the biggest upset of the tournament to advance to the round of 32.

headline: Oregon Slips Past St. Joseph’s; Texas A&M Needs Two Overtimes
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — With about 90 seconds remaining, trailing by 1 point, Oregon zipped the ball around until it found Dillon Brooks, its best shooter, open on the wing. St. Joseph’s players kept swiveling their heads, trying to keep up and stay in position, but with this Oregon team, no matter where the ball landed, it would not have been ideal.

headline: Self-Correcting Beyond a Web Era Marked by Sensationalism
text: The trial involving Gawker and Terry Bollea, better known as Hulk Hogan, over the publication of a sex video raised timeless legal questions about privacy and freedom of the press. The result, with the jury awarding Mr. Bollea $115 million in compensatory damages, could threaten Gawker’s existence.

headline: For Potvins, a Chance to Reflect on a Shared Islanders’ Legacy
text: Jean Potvin made his entrance at Patsy’s Pizzeria just across Flatbush Avenue from Barclays Center, where he was greeted by his younger brother Denis, still one of the best known figures in New York sports almost three decades after retiring.

headline: Artificial Hearts Ticking Along Decades After Jarvik-7 Debate
text: In the beginning, meaning 1982, there was the Jarvik-7, an artificial heart made of plastic and metal and intended for permanent implantation in a human being.

headline: Jason Day Leads All the Way at Arnold Palmer Invitational
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Jason Day was hitting out of the sand to a green sloping toward a water hazard. If he got up and down for par, Day would win the Arnold Palmer Invitational by one stroke. The shot was not easy, and the circumstances made it harder. The crowd ringing the 18th green at Bay Hill Golf Club included the tournament host, Palmer, who was seated in a cart a few yards away with an unimpeded view of Day’s sandy soliloquy.

headline: Four Candidates Seek Westchester County District Attorney Post
text: WHITE PLAINS — On its face, the job of Westchester County district attorney seems like a fairly staid one. An affluent bedroom community of New York City, with pockets of poverty, the county is rife with neither violent crime nor corporate malfeasance.

headline: Affymetrix Rejects $1.5 Billion Takeover Bid
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Affymetrix, a maker of advanced genetic analysis technology, on Sunday rejected an 11th-hour takeover bid meant to derail its planned sale to Thermo Fisher Scientific for $1.3 billion.

headline: For Transgender New Yorkers, a Center of Their Own in the Bronx
text: Eli Berry cannot go to stores or restaurants without being asked if he is a man or a woman. A mall security guard once demanded that he show identification to use a public men’s room.

headline: First Step in Conservatives’ Supreme Court Fight: Agreeing on a Message
text: WASHINGTON — The live shot on MSNBC was less than an hour away, so Curt A. Levey, executive director of the FreedomWorks Foundation, a conservative group determined to block President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, sat with his communications director for a quick review of what his message to the American public should be.

headline: When M.L.B. Broke the Ice With a Game in Havana
text: On Tuesday afternoon, the Tampa Bay Rays will play an exhibition game against the Cuban national baseball team in Havana. The moment will surely stand out, but it will not be nearly as groundbreaking as the game the Baltimore Orioles played there 17 years ago.

headline: Maryland’s First 3-Pointer, on 16th Try, Goes a Long Way
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — The Hawaii guards had been harassing Maryland guard Melo Trimble all game long, pressing him, bumping him, chasing him. The Rainbow Warriors had set the tone with their aggressive play, getting in the Terrapins’ faces, trying to intimidate the higher seed, and it seemed to be working, as Maryland missed its first 15 3-point attempts.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Season 1, Episode 6: The Adventures of Richie and Ernst
text: This week’s “Vinyl” is an hour of Richie and Devon revisiting their pasts. For Devon, that means staying with her friend Ingrid at the Chelsea Hotel, talking about how lonely she is in Connecticut and posing nude for Ingrid’s artist boyfriend. For Richie, that means snorting cocaine and then snorting more cocaine.

headline: Q. and A.: Noah Bean on Portraying David Bowie
text: Portraying David Bowie at his 1970s peak was a tall enough order for an actor while the rock icon was still alive. But to be the first in those platform shoes and that red mullet since Mr. Bowie’s death in January, at the age of 69, added another layer of anxieties.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 6, Episode 14: Tennessee Waterfalls, Strategic Bites and a Tragic Loss
text: If you don’t wake up and face your what? The suspense is killing me!

headline: Review: ‘The Effect,’ About Falling in Love While Taking Antidepressants
text: How much do you love me? Do you love me as much as I love you? Are you happy that you love me? How happy?

headline: Minnesota’s Amanda Kessel Tops Off Return With a National Title
text: DURHAM, N.H. — As she savored the moment — an unexpected joy, if one was to believe the N.C.A.A. seeding committee — Amanda Kessel had one overriding thought: This was why she had come back.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: San Antonio at Oklahoma City
text: The San Antonio Spurs defeated the Golden State Warriors, 87-79, on Saturday. The loss was the Warriors’ first to a team in the N.B.A.’s top tier. Previously, they had been 1-0 against the Spurs, 3-0 against the Oklahoma City Thunder and 2-0 against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 9: Bobby the Profiteer
text: “Axelrod Hall will not be named Axelrod Hall forever,” I predicted in the recap to the second episode of “Billions,” when Bobby moved to buy the naming rights to a symphony hall and etch his name in the firmament. But who could have guessed the request to remove the Axelrod name would come this soon?

headline: Donald Trump Is Finally Uniting Top Republican Donors — Against Him
text: The prospect of a Donald J. Trump nomination is accomplishing what a diverse and talented field of Republican presidential contenders could not: uniting the party’s big-money donor establishment.

headline: Thomas Walkup Sheds Tears Over What Might Have Been
text: The Lumberjack was trying not to cry.

headline: Tired and Depleted, Knicks Stumble to Defeat
text: A game between two of the worst teams in the N.B.A. unfolded appropriately enough on Sunday evening.

headline: Donald Trump Says He’ll List His Top Supreme Court Picks
text: Donald J. Trump on Sunday promised to make public this week a list of five to 10 judges he would nominate to the Supreme Court, seeking to ease concerns among conservatives that he would appoint liberal justices if he is elected president.

headline: Roger Agnelli, ‘Iron Man’ Who Led a Global Mining Giant, Dies at 56
text: Roger Agnelli, a former banking executive who helped turn the Brazilian company Vale into a global mining giant, died on Saturday when his private plane crashed in São Paulo, Brazil. He was 56.

headline: Wisconsin Upsets Xavier With (What Else?) a 3 at the Buzzer
text: ST. LOUIS — Four Wisconsin players ran in a circle as if around an invisible maypole on Sunday night. A fifth, the freshman Ethan Happ, prepared to pass the ball inbounds from near halfcourt. There were exactly two seconds left.

headline: ‘The Abundance,’ by Annie Dillard
text: THE ABUNDANCENarrative Essays Old and NewBy Annie Dillard271 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $25.99.

headline: ‘The Passion’: Jesus’ Final Hours as a Halftime Show
text: On the seventh day, Fox didn’t rest. It took the greatest story ever told and turned it into a halftime show.

headline: ‘A Murder Over a Girl,’ by Ken Corbett
text: A MURDER OVER A GIRLJustice, Gender, Junior HighBy Ken CorbettIllustrated. 273 pp. Henry Holt & Company. $27.

headline: 中国罢工潮涌动
text: 中国减缓的经济造成全国范围内工人罢工游行次数激增。在这种形势下，有个人正在试图帮助这些弱势的工人群体。

headline: What to Watch Monday
text: If you want to see for yourself what went on between Leo and the bear in “The Revenant,” the Oscar-winning film has made its way to iTunes. And “Dancing With the Stars” returns for a 22nd season of feel-good ballroom battles. For reality TV with more sass, there is always “RuPaul’s Drag Race.”

headline: The Pressure of the Sierra Madre
text: In northern Mexico, the indigenous Rarámuri have reached an uneasy accommodation with the cartel that controls the opium trade.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Pressure of the Sierra Madre
text: Christian Rodriguez knew he had to stop taking pictures in a small indigenous village in Mexico’s Sierra Madre once he saw the enforcers with AK-47s chatting on two-way radios. If he needed any further confirmation, there was always the men he spotted higher up looking at them through binoculars.

headline: On Invincible Ignorance
text: Remember Paul Ryan? The speaker of the House used to be a media darling, lionized as the epitome of the Serious, Honest Conservative — never mind those of us who actually looked at the numbers in his budgets and concluded that he was a con man. These days, of course, he is overshadowed by the looming Trumpocalypse.

headline: Chinese Problems on America’s Shores
text: In recent months, there has been a sharp drop in China’s foreign reserves, with lots of families and companies sending dollars overseas as the government cracks down on corruption and the economy weakens. Those fears have not let up, though this month the Chinese central bank did report an abrupt, puzzling slowdown in the outflows in February.

headline: A Presidential Rebuke to the Saudis
text: It is rare for an American president to skewer a friendly government publicly. But that’s what President Obama did last week in presenting a well-considered analysis of troubles in the relationship with Saudi Arabia.

headline: Will a Liberal Supreme Court Limit Money in Politics?
text: The words “Citizens United,” especially when amplified by a vigorous Democratic presidential nomination fight, have become a potent shorthand for the influence of great wealth over American democracy. With the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, the possibility of reversing the 2010 decision in Citizens United v. Federal Election Committee quickly became a live issue in the election and in the shadowboxing over Justice Scalia’s replacement.

headline: What Mexico Thinks About Trump
text: MEXICO CITY — IN 2011, when the Republican presidential hopeful Herman Cain proposed building an electric fence on the Mexican border, it predictably caused shock waves south of the Rio Grande. Priests, the press and a former president expressed outrage. Mr. Cain quickly pulled back, saying he was just kidding. “That is not a serious plan,” he said. “America needs to get a sense of humor. That is a joke, O.K.?”

headline: Learning Lessons From Outrage
text: There is so much we have learned from this painful election season and the rise of a demagogic real estate developer.

headline: Religion and Birth Control at the Supreme Court
text: If the harm that Senate Republicans are inflicting on the nation by refusing to consider filling the Supreme Court vacancy were not already self-evident, a case that the remaining eight justices are hearing on Wednesday drives the point home.

headline: The Prison-Commercial Complex
text: ORANGE, Conn. — LAST week, an order from the Federal Communications Commission that caps rates for United States prison telephone calls went into effect. A late stay by a federal appeals court, sought by phone companies suing the F.C.C., had threatened to delay the order’s implementation. The stay affects several portions of the F.C.C.’s regulation, but key rate caps and restrictions on charges now apply — to the delight of advocates for prisoners and their families who have long criticized the call rates as a form of price gouging.

headline: Exposure: Chernobyl
text: I am on a sleeper train, traveling from Moscow to Anapa, a town in Southern Russia, on the shore of the Black Sea. It is April 26, 1986, a week before my sixth birthday. We have been en route for nearly two days and the provisions we brought from home are running down. The train has stopped at the station in Rostov-on-Don, 700 miles away from our home on the outskirts of Moscow.

headline: Q. and A.: The Artist Zhang Hongtu on Appropriating Mao’s Image
text: Zhang Hongtu, a Chinese-born artist who came to the United States in 1982 and is now based in New York, won early attention for his “political pop” works appropriating the ubiquitous image of Mao Zedong, notably his portrait of Mao superimposed on a Quaker Oats carton and his reimagining of da Vinci’s “Last Supper” with Mao occupying the position of Jesus Christ and his 12 disciples.

headline: North Korea Launches Short-Range Projectiles, Seoul Says
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea launched several short-range projectiles off its east coast on Monday, the South Korean military said.

headline: Obama in Cuba: An Activist Awaits
text: Amid the euphoria of President Obama’s visit is a darker reality for the artist Danilo Maldonado Machado, who has been jailed for his work. He hopes this week will spotlight Cuba’s repression.

headline: News Q’s | Obama Becomes First U.S. President to Visit Cuba in Nearly 90 Years
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Obama Arrives in Cuba, Heralding New Era After Decades of Hostility.”

headline: John Roberts Criticized Supreme Court Confirmation Process, Before There Was a Vacancy
text: WASHINGTON — Last month, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. delivered some blunt remarks about the Supreme Court confirmation process. The Senate should ensure that nominees are qualified, he said, and leave politics out of it.

headline: Stay or Go? Cuban Entrepreneurs Divided on Where to Stake Futures
text: HAVANA — As an inside joke about all the cookies they scorched on the road to establishing a successful bakery, Antonio and Sandra Camacho Rodríguez named their Havana sweets shop the Burner Brothers.

headline: Student Question | What Old, Worn Out Thing Can You Just Not Part With?
text: Most of the time, people look forward to replacing old, worn things with newer, better models. But this isn’t always true.

headline: After Funeral and Cremation, a Shock: The Woman in the Coffin Wasn’t Mom
text: After a long battle with cancer, Val-Jean McDonald, mother of eight sons, with more than 20 grandchildren, almost as many great-grandchildren and three great-great-grandchildren, died on Dec. 18 at the age of 81.

text: Note: We invite any English-language-learner student 13 years or older to post comments in response to the writing prompts in this post.

text: Gwen Deely’s story is an example of how not to deal with a health crisis when traveling abroad. She realizes she’s lucky to be alive.
