headline: Empathy May Be Overrated in an Election, and in a Leader
text: Is empathy an essential virtue for a presidential candidate?

headline: Amid a Graying Fleet of Nuclear Plants, a Hunt for Solutions
text: The H.B. Robinson nuclear power plant, about 70 miles from Columbia, S.C., has been producing electricity with few interruptions since the Nixon administration. But as of now, its fate is clear: The plant will have to shut down by 2030, when it will be six decades old.

headline: Lamb for Easter, Grass Fed and Antibiotic Free
text: After three years, Stefan Oellinger, who is in charge of meat for FreshDirect, has secured a consistent supply of grass-fed, hormone- and antibiotic-free lamb from a local farm and has it in time for Easter. Drew Lewis, the fourth-generation owner of Brothers Ridge Farm in Newark Valley, N.Y., is raising the lambs on 310 rolling acres of meadow. The meat, mainly from crossbreeds, is mild, tender and rimmed with fat. Cuts include racks, roasts with or without the bone, stew meat, chops, shanks, cutlets and a boneless cut called the loin chump, which is popular in England and is like a thick steak: Grass-fed local lamb, $7.49 to $39.99 a pound, freshdirect.com.

headline: Better Than Drugstore Chocolates
text: Take a break from tinfoil-wrapped eggs and pastel Peeps with these old-fashioned chocolate bars for modern tastes. Showing rabbit scenes in relief, they are made of dark chocolate dusted with sea salt, milk chocolate with cocoa nibs, and white chocolate streaked with raspberry. The Los Angeles chocolatier who makes them also fashions delicate petits fours iced in white chocolate, filled with lemon or cassis and adorned with crystallized pansy petals: Easter bars, $10, and petits fours, $50 for a dozen, from Valerie Confections, 888-706-1408, valerieconfections.com; or petits fours, $65, at Dean & DeLuca stores, deandeluca.com.

headline: Coffee and Cocktails Served at the Bar
text: Kobrick’s has been roasting and selling coffee wholesale since 1920, first in Lower Manhattan and now in Hoboken, N.J. But in today’s coffee culture, the family’s fourth generation, Scott Kobrick and his sister, Nikole Kobrick, thought the company should also have a retail presence. With the approval of their mother and uncle, who are still involved in the company, the siblings have opened a cafe in the meatpacking district where baristas do double duty as mixologists, pouring Negronis as easily as macchiatos after 4:30. And not just any Negronis. Using a Japanese cold-brew drip contraption, they infuse the drink with coffee, adding a dimension of earth-driven bitterness. Other drinks, made with and without the coffee component, include a Bloody Mary that relies on a Chemex carafe to produce. They are working with Tobin Ludwig of Hella Bitters to create cocktails. Wines and light food are also served: Kobrick Coffee Company, 24 Ninth Avenue (13th Street), 212-255-5588, kobrickcoffee.com.

headline: A Coloring Book From the Garden
text: Images of produce from the garden and the market in this coloring book by Jessie Kanelos Weiner are as intricate as French tapestries, presenting an artistic challenge for adult and accomplished child alike. Why not make it a shared activity? Be Henri Rousseau and take a realistic approach, coloring strawberries red, or let your inner Vlaminck emerge as you create bright yellow asparagus, turquoise turnips and green honeybees: “Edible Paradise: A Coloring Book of Seasonal Fruits and Vegetables” by Jessie Kanelos Weiner (Universe Publishing, $16.95 paper).

headline: Gelato Flavors Leaning Into Spring
text: Anticipating spring, Antonio Biagi, a gelato maker in NoLIta, has started churning out lighter, brighter flavors. High on the list is the innocent-looking caipirinha sorbet, white as a lily but lip-smacking with lime and reinforced with cachaça. Mr. Biagi, who is from Brazil, also offers a creamy new “unflavored” flavor he calls bossa nova milk, which gets its richness from its texture and does wonders for an affogato made with intense Brazilian coffee: A. B. Biagi, 235 Elizabeth Street (Prince Street), 212-219-8094, abbiagi.com.

headline: Serving Sardines With the Proper Fork
text: They probably used small, multi-tined sardine forks in “Downton Abbey”; they also have them at the new Suprema Provisions in the West Village, where one of the owners, Stephen Werther, is a collector and happy to share his passion with customers. Alas, the forks are for service only and not for sale. So order sardines, the high-quality, tinned kind that this market and wine bar carries, and snack on them with the proper vintage fork: Suprema Provisions, 305 Bleecker Street and 88 Seventh Avenue South, 646-964-4994, supremaprovisions.com.

headline: A Smaller iPhone and Other Highlights From Apple’s Product Event
text: Times reporters provided live analysis from the event, where the tech company introduced a smaller iPhone, a smaller iPad Pro and new bands for the Apple Watch.

headline: Sharing Everyday Cooking Through a New Food52 App
text: An interactive and addictive app for the iPhone and iPad that allows cooks to share images of everyday dishes and tell how they made them is coming from Food52 on Tuesday. The app, (Not)Recipes, has the look and feel of Instagram; you can favorite posts as well as comment on them. Filters help that roast chicken that didn’t quite brown the way you wanted it to look as if it did: Free at the iTunes App Store.

headline: Morning Agenda: Banks Pull Financing From Coal Industry
text: BANKS PULL FINANCING FROM COAL INDUSTRY | Wall Street’s retreat from the coal industry is an ominous sign for a sector already in decline,Michael Corkery writes in DealBook. JPMorgan Chase said it would no longer finance new coal-fired power plants in the United States or other wealthy nations. Bank of America, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley have made similar decisions.

headline: China Says It Found Ring Said to Sell Improperly Stored Vaccines
text: HONG KONG — The police in China say they have uncovered a criminal ring suspected of selling improperly stored vaccines in dozens of provinces.

headline: Twitter at 10: ‘A Window Into Other Lives’
text: Twitter has become a cultural phenomenon, though not one without growing pains. Neil deGrasse Tyson, Margaret Cho and others reflected on their experiences.

headline: Belgian Police Name Man Suspected of Being Salah Abdeslam’s Accomplice
text: PARIS — The Belgian authorities on Monday identified a man suspected of being an accomplice of Salah Abdeslam, who was captured on Friday and charged with terrorist murder in the Paris attacks of Nov. 13. They had asked for the public’s help in finding him.

headline: A Reconsideration of Children and Screen Time
text: The digital world is changing around us at a dizzying pace; parents want guidance, and pediatricians want to answer their questions with helpful and scientifically valid advice. The American Academy of Pediatrics’ policy on children and media is probably best known for two recommendations: to discourage any screen time for children under 2, and to limit screen time to two hours a day for older children.

headline: Donald Trump Isn’t Alone in Exploiting the Word ‘University’
text: Eleven years ago, Donald J. Trump linked his name to one of the older get-rich-quick ventures in the book: the real estate seminar. Enticed by the promise of their own quick riches in a then-hot real estate market, students gathered in hotel conference rooms for free introductory classes where instructors offered special knowledge and financing — but only if students signed up for additional, increasingly expensive classes.

headline: Mr. Trump Goes to Washington, to Meet the Establishment
text: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump will be in Washington on Monday, addressing the conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac. That’s about where the similarities in their days will end.

headline: In One-Party Vietnam, Independents Vie for Assembly Seats
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — Taking the stage here on Friday, the singer-songwriter Mai Khoi launched into her hit song “Vietnam,” an optimistic ode to the country’s landscape and people. But the rest of her set list included songs, such as one called “Cuffed in Freedom,” that addressed hot-button social issues like corruption, gender inequality and official restrictions on artistic expression.

headline: Cuba Heads for Miami
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — So Havana is 20 years behind Ho Chi Minh City on the development cycle that brings you bulldozed historical districts; traffic-clogged streets; a skyline of cranes; fancy golf courses for expats and the local elite; lattes galore; burger joints; smartphones everywhere; a middle class with disposable income; the seductions of credit; fragrant shopping malls; brand heaven (or hell); the end of virgin beaches; massive real estate developments with names like “Central Park”; offshore fortunes for the political architects of capitalist communism; resorts with their manicured lawns; casinos; mass tourism; social media; 6 percent annual growth; mom-and-pop entrepreneurship; suburbia and sprinklers; private schools for kids with Ivy League colleges already in their sights; Asian and Latin American versions of the American dream; and a population fired up and sort of freed by the opportunity to make a buck for the first time in generations.

headline: James Patterson Has a Big Plan for Small Books
text: People already read James Patterson’s books — and in staggering numbers. Last year, he and his team of writers had 36 books land on the New York Times best-seller list. To date, he has published 156 books that have sold more than 325 million copies worldwide.

headline: IHS and Markit, Providers of Data and Analytics, Agree to Merge
text: The data and analytics providers IHS and Markit have agreed to combine in an all-stock transaction that will take IHS, which is based in Colorado, to London.

headline: Marriott Raises Bid for Starwood
text: Marriott International sweetened its bid for Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide with more cash, greater synergies and a higher breakup fee. That still may not be enough to deter the Anbang Insurance Group of China and its co-investors from making a counteroffer — yet again.

headline: Cuba Meeting Between Obama and Castro Exposes Old Grievances
text: HAVANA — President Obama stood beside President Raúl Castro on Monday and declared a “new day” of openness between the United States and Cuba, but old grievances and disputes over human rights marred a groundbreaking meeting and underscored lingering impediments to a historic thaw.

headline: China’s Coast Guard Rams Fishing Boat to Free It From Indonesian Authorities
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — China’s Coast Guard rammed one of the country’s fishing boats to pry it free from the Indonesian authorities who had seized it over the weekend, angering the Indonesian government and heightening yet another diplomatic dispute over the South China Sea.

headline: The Long Shadow of Argentina’s Dictatorship
text: BUENOS AIRES — When President Obama lands in Buenos Aires this week, he will be arriving on the eve of one of the most traumatic dates in our history. On March 24, Argentina commemorates the 40th anniversary of a military coup that “disappeared” thousands of people, a deep trauma in Argentina’s national psyche.

headline: A Shake-Up at Valeant Signals the End of an Era
text: As recently as last summer, J. Michael Pearson styled himself as a brash and bold executive with a new way of thriving in pharmaceuticals: buying other companies, slashing costs and sharply raising prices on undervalued drugs.

headline: Breathing Life Into Spaces Well Beyond 6 Feet Under Beijing’s Streets
text: BEIJING — The Digua Shequ community center in Beijing is painted in cheery pastel tones and festooned with colorful paper dragons hung from the ceiling. Inside are a hair salon, a cafe and a gym — normal shops for a typical neighborhood — except that they are underground.

headline: Florida Town Curbs Debauchery, and Pays the Price
text: PANAMA CITY BEACH, Fla. — The sun was sublime, the flour-soft sand could scarcely have been more tempting and the D.J. music thumped loudly enough to jiggle the beer cups resting on nearby tables. All that was missing were the throngs of booze-soaked, sunburned spring breakers who usually swarm this beach town during March.

headline: 19 Yemeni Jews Arrive in Israel, Ending Secret Rescue Operation
text: JERUSALEM — They landed in Israel late at night — a man in a dark suit and traditional headdress, wheeling a suitcase; a mother, veiled, in a long black robe and holding a sleeping toddler; and a rabbi carrying a Torah scroll believed to be more than 500 years old.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Samsung Appeal on Apple Patent Award
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear an appeal from Samsung on what it must pay Apple for infringing on part of the design of the iPhone. In a brief supporting Samsung, companies including Google and Facebook said the legal framework governing the design patents at issue was “out of step with modern technology.”

headline: The Times on the Air: ISIS’s Sex Slavery, Trump and More
text: Over the past week, New York Times reporters, columnists and executives participated in interviews about their coverage and other top news stories. Below are highlights from radio and television.

headline: 1966: Court Lifts ‘Fanny Hill’ Ban
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court refused today [March 21] to modify or discard its nine-year-old obscenity yardstick. But it held that Massachusetts went too far in banning the sale of ‘‘Fanny Hill,’’ the 18th-century novel about a prostitute.

headline: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Challenge to Colorado’s Marijuana Laws
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an unusual lawsuit challenging Colorado’s legalization of recreational marijuana and told a Massachusetts court to take a new look at a Second Amendment case involving stun guns.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Faulting Donald Trump, Calls Israel’s Security ‘Nonnegotiable’
text: Hillary Clinton pledged on Monday that she would stand unyieldingly with Israel and warned that her potential Republican rival, Donald J. Trump, would be an unreliable partner for one of America’s closest allies.

headline: Cleanse Creep
text: A peculiar thing about humans is that we’re persistently disturbed by reminders that we are, in fact, mammals who sweat, shed, bleed and expel foul matter on a daily basis. Entire industries exist to subdue the horror of having a body. Plentiful aisles in the drugstore are devoted to it. You’d think humans would have gotten used to the beastlier realities of existence by now. We’ve had millions of years to get used to it.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Apple and Justice Dept. Prepare to Face Off in Court
text: When it comes to the behavior of the federal government, Apple may want to revive its old slogan, “Think Different.”

headline: Putting Your Twitter Feed Back in Chronological Order
text: Q. Why is my Twitter feed suddenly out of chronological order?

headline: This Week’s Most Sensible Comment by a Republican
text: You know things are going badly when Rick Perry, the former governor of Texas and failed presidential candidate, sounds more sensible than anyone else in the Republican Party.

headline: Where Republican Senators Stand on the Supreme Court Nomination
text: Fourteen Republicans and all Democrats are needed to break a filibuster and confirm the nominee.

headline: Learning How to Deal With the Haters
text: We all like to act as if we’re immune to the vitriol of haters. It’s almost cool to pretend that it doesn’t affect us, like we’re all bulletproof and have some kind of armor against it.

headline: Drake’s Very Own: On Dennis Graham’s Instagram
text: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social media presences of celebrities.

headline: Apple May Be Willing to Risk Contempt Charge
text: Parents are known at times to deliver an ultimatum to a recalcitrant child by saying, “Do this, or else!” The question is what that the frequently undelivered punishment may actually be.

headline: At Microhotels, the Price Is Right and the Space Is Tight
text: On a recent business trip to New York, Kelly Buck went small for her hotel room — as in 100 square feet.

headline: What Spring (and Fall) Looks Like From Space
text: [This article has been updated for 2020’s autumnal equinox. Sync your calendar with the solar system.]

headline: France Takes a Back Seat to Germany in E.U. Migrant Crisis
text: PARIS — The French-German couple has always been assumed to be the engine of the European Union, the crucial team at the heart of a sprawling, unruly family of 28 nations.

headline: Certainty Despite Randomness
text: Cheers! This week we toast the arrival of spring with three beverage-glass challenges. We’ll start with Laura Feiveson, an M.I.T.-trained economist at the Federal Reserve Board and regular Numberplay contributor. Here’s Laura with two problems that may surprise even the most experienced puzzle-solver:

headline: Congolese Politician, Jean-Pierre Bemba, Is Convicted of War Crimes
text: PARIS — The International Criminal Court convicted a Congolese politician, Jean-Pierre Bemba, of war crimes and crimes against humanity on Monday, finding him culpable for a devastating campaign of rape, murder and torture in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003.

headline: No Regrets After Double Mastectomy, but Questions Remain
text: Vivien Foldes says she does not regret having her breasts removed five years ago after she was found to have an early-stage cancer.

headline: Boaty McBoatface: What You Get When You Let the Internet Decide
text: A proposal by a British government agency to let the Internet suggest a name for a $287 million polar research ship probably seemed like a good idea at the time.

headline: Mezzaluna, the Little Restaurant That Started a Revolution
text: An urbane, soft-spoken former auto executive, Aldo Bozzi does not fit the mold of a driven Manhattan restaurateur — much less one who almost single-handedly, if inadvertently, set off a restaurant revolution in the United States and beyond.

headline: The Last Thaw: U.S.-Cuban Relations in Pictures
text: President Obama’s visit to Cuba heralds the end of decades of enmity and hostility between that country and the United States.

headline: Why the Republican Establishment Doesn’t Like John Kasich
text: Improbable as it seemed just two months ago, the one remaining “establishment” Republican presidential candidate in the race is John Kasich, whose last name many voters still can’t pronounce. (Try remembering it this way: “Kasich” rhymes with “basic.”) After winning Ohio last Tuesday, Kasich has potentially denied Donald Trump the 1,237 delegates needed to clinch the nomination outright. And he goes into tomorrow’s primaries (in Arizona and Utah) as an antagonist to Ted Cruz, whose quest to close the gap between him and Trump is complicated by Kasich’s continued presence.

headline: A Wise Move on Marijuana by the Supreme Court
text: The Supreme Court has sensibly decided not to take a case brought by Nebraska and Oklahoma challenging the way in which Colorado legalized marijuana. The plaintiff states had a weak case backed up with little in the way of evidence.

headline: 1941: Search for German Battleships
text: LONDON — Powerful British naval units are searching the Atlantic for two 26,000-ton German battleships, the Scharnhorst and Gneisenau, which, it was learned here today [March 21], are at large in Western waters, threatening British commerce. The two are the most powerful ships yet used by the Nazis for commerce raiding. The fact that two 26,000-ton ships should be detached from the German fleet indicates that the Germans realize the hopelessness of ever meeting the British Navy in a fleet action and are willing to gamble some of their finest units in the Battle of the Atlantic. — New York Herald Tribune, March 22, 1941

headline: Like a Green Juice, but Boozy
text: In simpler times, a great barman was associated with a place — sleek or divey, he was always there. But this is the age of the pop-up, and like many great chefs, Matthew Biancaniello takes his cocktail craft on the road. Since he left his post at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel’s Library Bar over three years ago, the L.A.-based mixologist has been mostly consulting, traveling and writing — and making his farm-to-glass drinks on occasion, at special events.

headline: Fantasy Sites DraftKings and FanDuel Stop Taking Bets in New York
text: Two of the largest daily fantasy sports operators, DraftKings and FanDuel, stopped taking bets in New York on Monday as part of an agreement with the state attorney general’s office, which had accused them of illegal gambling.

headline: New York State Regents Elect Betty Rosa as Chancellor
text: The members of the State Board of Regents on Monday elected Betty A. Rosa, a former New York City principal and superintendent, as the new chancellor, signaling a sharp shift in the state’s education policies after dramatic protests by parents.

headline: New York City Bill to Call for Free Tampons in Public School Restrooms, Shelters and Jails
text: New York City Council members are joining a growing national movement to improve access to feminine hygiene products, and on Tuesday will introduce proposals for free tampons and pads in city public school restrooms and homeless shelters, and easier access at correctional facilities.

headline: Campaign 2016: What’s Next?
text: Times Political Editor Carolyn Ryan chats with political reporters Maggie Haberman and Michael Barbaro about the Presidential campaign and what to expect next.

headline: Chris Rock to Talk With J.J. Abrams at Tribeca Film Festival
text: At the Oscars, bits by the host, Chris Rock, in which he was inserted into nominated films like “The Martian” were among the highlights of a much-criticized ceremony. The director J.J. Abrams’s company Bad Robot had a hand in those spoofs. And now Mr. Rock and Mr. Abrams will sit down for a conversation at the Tribeca Film Festival next month, one of several talks that organizers announced on Monday.

headline: Fidel Castro Is Out of Sight as Obama Visits Cuba
text: This is not how they imagined it.

headline: Experimental Vaccine Shows Promise Against a Form of Dengue
text: An experimental dengue vaccine worked almost perfectly in a small trial in which volunteers were deliberately given a mild form of the disease, scientists said last week.

headline: Moqueca Offers Flavors of Brazil in a Tropical Fish Stew
text: I visited Brazil late last year expecting to sample moqueca (moe-KAY-cuh), a tropical fish stew, on its home turf and to bring back a recipe.

headline: Judge in Apple Case Seen as Unfazed by Stress, Even a Plane Crash
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — Just before Christmas in 2003, a twin-engine Cessna plane crashed into the Claremont, Calif., home of Sheri N. Pym. The house was destroyed and the pilot was killed.

headline: Apple’s Modest Product Upgrades Take Back Seat to Worries on iPhone Encryption
text: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple held one of its regular product showcases on Monday, but this time the products did not take center stage.

headline: Valeant’s Struggles Could Lead It to Crumble
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International is running the risk of an Enron or WorldCom endgame.

headline: Hunting the Genetic Signs of Postpartum Depression With an iPhone App
text: With mothers and medical providers clamoring for answers about postpartum depression, scientists are beginning a major effort to understand the genetic underpinnings of mood disorders that afflict millions of women during and after pregnancy.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Campaign 2016: What’s Next?
text: Campaign 2016. It’s settling down. Sort of. Marco Rubio is out. Bernie Sanders says he’s in until the end. Donald Trump promises riots in Cleveland if the Republican Party tinkers with the rules and tries to nominate another candidate. President Obama suggests authenticity is overrated and urges Democratic donors to unite behind Hillary Clinton. What’s next?

headline: Ben Affleck, Henry Cavill and Amy Adams at ‘Batman v Superman’ Party
text: The film’s stars attend a superhero-size premiere at Radio City Music Hall, followed by a party at a make-believe Gotham.

headline: Ben Affleck, Henry Cavill and Amy Adams at ‘Batman v Superman’ Party
text: The film’s stars attend a superhero-size premiere at Radio City Music Hall, followed by a party at a make-believe Gotham.

headline: ‘The Brothers Grimsby’ Trots Out a Demeaning Racial Trope
text: “Modern Problems” is a lousy Chevy Chase movie from 1981. But I saw it on HBO when I was 7 or 8, and whenever it was on, I would watch it. So its lousiness is separate from its being memorable. What I remember especially well is the end.

headline: North Korea’s Nuclear Threats
text: To the Editor:

headline: Elizabeth Warren Gives Donald Trump a Hostile Welcome to Washington
text: Senator Elizabeth Warren welcomed Donald J. Trump to Washington on Monday with a blistering assault on his character and business record while urging Democrats to unite against him.

headline: Obama in Cuba
text: President Obama and President Raúl Castro of Cuba had their third meeting since they announced plans to restore diplomatic relations in December 2014.

headline: F.D.A. Proposes a Ban on Powdered Medical Gloves
text: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration proposed banning powdered medical gloves on Monday, saying the powder can inflame wounds and cause scars to form between organs and tissue after surgery.

headline: Torture Is Against ‘America’s Core Values and Security’
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Four Architects Envision the New SFMOMA — as Jewelry
text: For fans of the sort of jewelry that’s best described as “architectural,” the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has something better: It has commissioned four trained architects to translate the museum’s new building into wearable designs. In May, the museum opens a new expansion by the Norwegian architecture firm Snøhetta. “Who would match a Botta building with a Snøhetta building? It really is a challenge. They are as crazy as me,” laughs the Buenos Aires-based architect Diana Schimmel, of Mario Botta’s original 1995 design for the museum. Schimmel’s pieces for the capsule collection similarly play on the merging of disparate elements; she’s paired, in a mix of gold and silver, Botta’s iconic round oculus and the striated lines of the new annex into a single entity.

headline: Is the Media Unfairly Dismissive of Bernie Sanders?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Rise of Donald Trump, From Many Angles
text: To the Editor:

headline: Enter Week 2, Exit the Have-Nots
text: ST. LOUIS — Middle Tennessee State Coach Kermit Davis wanted his team to be That Team in this year’s N.C.A.A. tournament, and on Friday, after the 15th-seeded Blue Raiders beat Michigan State, among the most accomplished basketball programs of the past decade, that’s what it was.

headline: After Conquering Europe, Eurovision Is Coming to Asia
text: The spectacle of the Eurovision Song Contest — which since 1956 has crowned the continent’s best amateur pop number in a flamboyant televised competition that reaches as many as 200 million viewers — is coming to Asia.

headline: Judge Garland to Meet With More Senators This Week
text: While the fight over President Obama’s nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court has largely shifted from Washington to congressional districts, Judge Garland is still planning to meet with senators this week.

headline: The Mideast Came to Idaho State. It Wasn’t the Best Fit.
text: POCATELLO, Idaho — When the Rev. Jim Jones, pastor of the Blazing Grace Church here, approached the lectern at City Hall, he was holding a copy of the Quran.

headline: Rihanna Is Back at Top Spot on Billboard
text: What makes a No. 1 album?

headline: Judge Approves Orange County Register Sale to Digital First
text: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Last week, Tribune Publishing won an auction for a coveted asset — Freedom Communications, the parent company of The Orange County Register and The Press-Enterprise of Riverside, Calif. On Monday, however, the company could only watch as the sale of Freedom to Digital First Media was approved by a judge.

headline: BP and Statoil Pull Employees From Algeria Gas Fields After Attack
text: BP and the Norwegian oil company Statoil announced on Monday that they were withdrawing their employees from two of Algeria’s largest natural gas fields after Islamic terrorists staged the second attack in three years on their installations.

headline: Analysts Urge Citigroup Split
text: Analysts at Keefe Bruyette & Woods on Monday waded into the debate over breaking up the nation’s biggest banks, releasing a report that urges Citigroup to split up.

headline: Selections from Of Rare Origin’s Aviary Collection
text: Leslie Tcheyan and Octavia Giovannini-Torelli debut their new pieces here.

headline: Intricate Jewelry, From a Mother-Daughter Duo
text: Flicking through photographs on her smartphone, the jewelry designer Leslie Tcheyan lands on a nonpareil early ’90s snapshot: She’s wearing a grayish, shoulder-padded blazer, with one arm around her 10-year-old daughter, Octavia Giovannini-Torelli (who’s missing at least one of her front teeth). Both are dripping in diamonds. “It was Take Your Daughter to Work Day and Mom arranged breakfast at Harry Winston’s; I wore a turtleneck and Mom was devastated because I selected all of these huge necklaces,” says Giovannini-Torelli, laughing. “I remember, so vividly, her saying, ‘I can’t believe you wore that.’” Tcheyan, known to others as Che, is a jewelry-industry veteran: Over the last three decades, she worked at Fred Leighton and then began designing packaging and displays for the likes of Schlumberger, Verdura, Sotheby’s and numerous retail jewelers. This led to consulting for Verdura and other brands, all the while sourcing gems and antiques, and manufacturing contemporary pieces worldwide for private clients.

headline: Only a Man Could Forget When Women Ruled Tennis
text: Of all the sports platforms from which to suggest that women “go down every night” on their knees and “thank God” for male counterparts to whom, they owe, in effect, their livelihoods, the last one we might have expected it from was tennis.

headline: The House That Art, Fantasy and Mystery Built
text: Last week, the Santa Fe-based art collective Meow Wolf introduced “The House of Eternal Return” — an interactive, multimedia art experience that one of Meow Wolf’s co-founders, Vince Kadlubek, refers to as “immersive storytelling.” And appropriately for the otherworldly space, created by a team of 135 artists, maestros-of-fantasy like George R. R. Martin and Neil Gaiman attended the opening.

headline: Inside ‘The House of Eternal Return’
text: Take a tour of Meow Wolf’s first permanent exhibition, located in Santa Fe and funded by George R. R. Martin.

headline: Credit Default Swaps Make Restructuring More Difficult
text: Several years ago I wrote an article predicting that the growth of credit default swaps would make it increasingly difficult to restructure distressed companies. The drama surrounding a Norwegian paper maker shows that, if anything, I understated the potential problem.

headline: For a New ‘Rainbow,’ Donald McKayle Is Still Explaining
text: “Ah haaa!”

headline: Review: Met Chamber Ensemble, Led by Levine, Explores Schoenberg and Mozart
text: A conductor’s most important contributions to a performance occur during rehearsals, long before an audience is present. So James Levine deserves much credit for the Met Chamber Ensemble’s winning performances of demanding serenades by Schoenberg and Mozart on Sunday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. His effectiveness conducting the actual performance was harder to assess.

headline: Review: ‘The Year of the Runaways,’ About Fighting for Scraps in a New Country
text: Even as waves of refugees fleeing the war in Syria have created an urgent world crisis, many immigrants who have already made it to Europe have been grappling with prejudice, poverty and unemployment. No recent novel does a more powerful job of capturing the day-to-day lives of such immigrants than Sunjeev Sahota’s second book, “The Year of the Runaways,” which was shortlisted for the 2015 Man Booker prize.

headline: Holding Out in Harlem, but Not Holding a Grudge
text: The blog post should have been the least of Tracy Butler’s worries, what with the demolition and excavation work going on on three sides of her family’s 129-year-old brownstone on West 123rd Street. Yet four months later, it still bemused her.

headline: Attack Reported on Mali Hotel Used by European Union Military
text: Unidentified assailants attacked a hotel on Monday that is used by European Union military officials in Bamako, the capital of Mali, an African nation that has struggled with recurrent instability and assaults by Islamist militants.

headline: Leon Cooperman and Omega Advisors Receive S.E.C. Notice
text: The longtime Wall Street trader Leon G. Cooperman is preparing for a showdown with regulators.

headline: Russian Judge Postpones Verdict in Trial of Ukrainian Pilot
text: DONETSK, Russia — A Russian judge on Monday adjourned the reading of the verdict in the politically charged case against Nadiya V. Savchenko, a captured Ukrainian military pilot, until Tuesday morning.

headline: Parrots Are a Lot More Than ‘Pretty Bird’
text: Juan F. Masello never intended to study wild parrots. Twenty years ago, as a graduate student visiting the northernmost province of Patagonia in Argentina, he planned to write his dissertation on colony formation among seabirds.

headline: An Australian Chef in Hong Kong, Serving Casual French Fare
text: Since the nomadic Australian chef James Henry abruptly closed his acclaimed Paris bistro Bones last August, he has been waiting for his next project to begin. And finally, it has — in Hong Kong. Beginning Monday, he’s offering the city a taste of his new restaurant that just opened there, with a weeklong pop-up during Hong Kong’s contemporary art fair.

headline: MCC Theater to Kick Off Construction of Its New Home
text: It has been a long journey from start to sledgehammer.

headline: Find Your Happy Place
text: The United Nations issues lots of important, if not exactly scintillating, reports. Then there is the annual World Happiness Report, released last week.

headline: Street Style: SXSW
text: The kickoff of the music-festival style season happened in Austin, Tex.

headline: Street Style at SXSW
text: The kickoff of the music-festival style season happened in Austin, Tex., at SXSW.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Cuba, iPhone, Donald Trump
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: U.C.L.A. Center on Police-Community Ties Will Move to John Jay College
text: A national research center focused on interactions between the police and the communities they serve will open this summer at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, with the college’s first endowed professor as its director.

headline: Review: Stormzy Delivers Grime Music From Britain
text: A couple of years ago, Stormzy was invited to be the first unsigned rapper to appear on “Later … With Jools Holland,” a British institution of televised live music. He’d been asked to perform “Not That Deep,” one of his tough early singles, and offered instead to do something a little more polished. “I can soften it up, put on a shirt,” he recalled in an interview leading up to that performance, “and they’re like, ‘Nah, nah, nah.’”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: N.F.L. Aims to Play Regular-Season Game in China
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Eager to expand its footprint internationally to generate more revenue, the N.F.L. plans to play a regular-season game in China as early as 2018.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Operations Against ISIS
text: The Department of Defense has identified 12 American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Most Republicans Feel Embarrassed by Campaign, Poll Says
text: Alarmed by the harsh attacks and negative tone of their presidential contest, broad majorities of Republican primary voters view their party as divided and a source of embarrassment and think that the campaign is more negative than in the past, according to a New York Times/CBS News national poll released on Monday.

headline: Why Sanders Trails Clinton Among Minority Voters
text: Asked during a January debate why he trailed Hillary Clinton so badly among minority voters, Senator Bernie Sanders said he would gain ground once those voters became familiar with his track record and agenda on the economy and criminal justice.

headline: How the New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from March 17 to 20 with 1,252 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,058 said they were registered to vote.

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on What Voters Think About the Campaign
text: Broad majorities of Republican primary voters say they believe the party is divided, are embarrassed by the party’s presidential campaign and consider a contested convention to be bad for the party. Democratic primary voters say their party is much more unified, but their race is tighter, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Chanel, Dior, Fendi and Kors Unveil Latest Offerings at Baselworld
text: BASEL, Switzerland — Each year, some 150,000 industry insiders and haute horlogerie fanatics descend upon this small town, near the German and French borders, for Baselworld, the biggest watch fair in the world.

headline: Jury Tacks On $25 Million to Gawker’s Bill in Hulk Hogan Case
text: A Florida jury assessed Gawker Media millions more in punitive damages on Monday for having invaded the privacy of the retired wrestler Hulk Hogan, adding to the $115 million it awarded in compensatory damages last week.

headline: Roles of Race and Partisanship in Legislative Maps Argued at Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court wrestled on Monday with the role race may play in drawing legislative maps.

headline: U.S. Says It May Not Need Apple’s Help to Unlock iPhone
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The Justice Department said on Monday that it might no longer need Apple’s assistance in opening an iPhone used by a gunman in the San Bernardino, Calif., rampage last year.

headline: After Oregon Standoff, Birding Is Back
text: In a lifetime of offbeat travel experiences, searching for mating sage grouse in a snow squall may rank as one of my oddest pursuits.

headline: U.S. Ends Spying Case Against Former Envoy
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has closed its espionage investigation into the former American diplomat Robin L. Raphel and will file no charges, her lawyer said on Monday, ending a case that had put her under a cloud of suspicion over her ties to Pakistan for more than a year.

headline: Outfitting Hasidic Women With Stylish, Yet Modest, Fashions
text: Sifting through the crop tops and sheer blouses for sale at Junee, a boutique in Borough Park, Brooklyn, is an unexpected clientele: some of New York City’s most modest women.

headline: North Carolina: State to Consider Blocking Charlotte Anti-Bias Law
text: The General Assembly will hold a special session on Wednesday to consider blocking a Charlotte ordinance that would broaden local protections for gay and transgender people. The measure — which officials in Charlotte, North Carolina’s largest city, approved last month — is to take effect April 1 and forbids discrimination in public accommodations, like restrooms, because of a person’s sexual orientation or gender expression. Opponents, including Gov. Pat McCrory, condemned the plan as a threat to public safety, and at least three-fifths of the Republican-controlled House and Senate agreed to the special session. In a statement on Monday, legislative leaders said, “We aim to repeal this ordinance before it goes into effect to provide for the privacy and protection of the women and children of our state.”

headline: Donald Trump Calls Himself ‘Lifelong Supporter’ of Israel
text: Donald J. Trump expressed his solidarity with Israel in passionate terms on Monday, promising a gathering of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee that as president he would always stand up for it against its enemies in the Middle East.

headline: Bob Adelman: From Civil Rights to Making a Difference
text: Bob Adelman, a chronicler of the civil rights era who died over the weekend, was convinced photography could change the world.

headline: Bob Adelman: From Civil Rights to Making a Difference
text: Bob Adelman, a photographer known for his sweeping, dramatic and intimate coverage of the civil rights movement, was found dead in Miami Beach, Fla., over the weekend. The Miami Herald reported that a friend discovered him at his home Saturday with a head wound.

headline: New Reality Looms: Only a Friendly Senate Will Confirm Justices
text: WASHINGTON — The bitter impasse over the nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland is raising a once unthinkable possibility: Presidents may no longer be confident of filling a Supreme Court vacancy unless their party controls the Senate.

headline: Deal Appears to Curb Migrant Flow, but Greece Still Faces ‘Uphill Effort’

During the past nine months, hundreds of thousands of refugees had crossed these waters on smuggler rafts to reach Europe.

headline: Reaction to Obama Trip Reflects Change in Cuban-Americans

headline: Morocco Asks That U.N. Close Western Sahara Military Office

headline: Bob Adelman, Whose Vivid Photos Captured Civil Rights Struggle, Dies at 85

headline: Clinton and CAFTA
text: Joel Benenson, Hillary Clinton’s number-cruncher/strategist, has an interesting note up about the implications of the Ohio primary. The rules of the game require, of course, both that he be totally positive about his candidate and that he profess a certainty about the meaning of every victory that I’m fairly sure he does not, in fact, possess. The truth is that nobody can be sure exactly why Ohio was so different from Michigan; the big takeaway from the Ohio result was, instead, that the yuge Michigan polling miss was an outlier rather than a harbinger, and that — combined with the big HRC delegate gain on 3/15 — moves a Clinton nomination from highly likely to overwhelmingly probable.

headline: What Are We Voting For?

headline: Elegant Bird Discovers Junk Food
text: A new study shows that the glorious annual migration of white storks from Europe to Africa is being disrupted by the birds’ growing addiction to junk food in the garbage dumps below their flight path. Thousands no longer make the crossing for the winter, preferring to build year-round nests at rubbish pits in Spain and Portugal where they conserve energy and have an easier time breeding and defending their nests.

headline: ‘Arcadia,’ by Iain Pears
text: Nobody can tangle a text like Iain Pears. His best-known novel, “An Instance of the Fingerpost,” explored a 17th-century Oxford murder and its aftermath through the memoirs of four unreliable narrators, each hotly disputing the others’ versions of reality, science, religion and justice. After nearly 700 pages of deposition, when the guilty are finally sorted from the hard-to-call-innocent, many readers will understandably have already lost track of their scorecards. Now, almost 20 years later, Pears’s latest novel presents a complexly interwoven series of narrative entanglements that stretch across time, alternate universes and at least several textual realities — from Elizabethan pastoral romance and multiple universe theory to a Narnia-like fantasy world and Cold War international intrigue. What’s the difference between all these systems of order, knowledge and storytelling? the attentive reader might ask. And the answer might well be: no difference at all. They are equally “real” and equally “unreal” — take your pick.

headline: How Can Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders Both Be ‘Populist’?
text: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders share an upbringing in New York’s outer boroughs and a repugnance for trade deals, but the similarities pretty much end there. Sanders routinely inveighs against “corporate America”; Trump is an executive of almost 500 business entities, more than 200 of which are named after himself. Trump lends his name to a line of power ties and cuff links; the adjective most often applied to Sanders’s wardrobe is “rumpled.” Yet journalists routinely refer to both men as “populists.” How can a word that purports to describe both a proud socialist and an arrogant billionaire have any meaning?

headline: Should Parents of Children With Severe Disabilities Be Allowed to Stop Their Growth?
text: Ricky gazed up toward the pine trees as his mother, Cindy Preslar, pushed him along the village road in an orange jogging stroller. She was marking the route for the Summer 2014 Run Through the Clouds 10K, a fund-raiser for the public schools in Cloudcroft, N.M. “You’ll run with Dad and Max tomorrow,” she said. “Right, Ricky?” She ruffled his fine blond hair. By “run” she meant “ride” — Ricky was 7, but his legs were unable to bear his full weight. As a result of a complication during pregnancy, Cindy says, he was born with a form of cerebral palsy known as spastic quadriplegia with static encephalopathy, which meant permanent brain damage and severely limited eyesight because of cortical vision impairment.

headline: 1941: U.S. Labeled as Enemy
text: ROME — Every city in Italy will celebrate tomorrow [March 23] the twenty-second anniversary of the founding of the Fascist party. There will be a display of flags, parades, oratory and other accompaniments of a national holiday. On the eve of the celebration, spokesmen of the party told the public today that the revolution of Fascism, originally purely Italian, had grown into a world-wide revolution in which the Anglo-Saxon ‘‘pluto-democracies’’ were the enemy. Editorials in the ‘‘Relazioni Internazionali,’’ a leading Italian weekly on foreign affairs, and in ‘‘Il Giornale d’Italia’’ made it clear that the United States was now included in the Fascist list of foes. — New York Herald Tribune, March 23, 1941

text: PARIS — Since the November attacks in Paris, the Belgian authorities have conducted dozens of raids, combed whole neighborhoods for well-known militants and even locked down the capital for days, all part of promises to step up efforts to root out jihadists.

headline: Serena Williams: Why Tennis Needs the Miami Open
text: Editor’s note: The Miami Open, a joint ATP/WTA tournament that began this week, is subject to a legal battle over possible renovations to the site, which is a public park. The dispute has led to speculation that the event, one of the biggest tennis tournaments in the United States, will move.

headline: ‘Curious Incident’ to Close in September
text: The Tony-winning “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” will end its run this September after opening in fall 2014.

headline: Hillary Clinton Vows to ‘Defeat Terrorism’ but Cautions About Shutting Borders and Torture

headline: ‘Blindspot’ Season 1, Episode 14: Jane Takes a Back Seat
text: A week after an installment that was more mind game than action yarn, it was back to the run-and-gun style on Monday’s episode of “Blindspot.” One of Jane’s tattoos led the F.B.I. team to a sex-trafficking ring and a race against the clock to keep an innocent man from being executed.

headline: Low Gas Prices Create a Detour on the Road to Greater Fuel Economy

headline: Rob Ford, Blustery Ex-Mayor of Toronto Whose Struggles Went Public, Dies at 46
text: Rob Ford, the combative former mayor of Toronto who gained international notoriety with his confession of crack cocaine use, his public drunkenness and his belligerent clashes with other public officials, died on Tuesday. He was 46.

headline: Hundreds of Looted Ancient Artifacts Are Returned to Italy
text: ROME – Hundreds of looted archaeological artifacts that officials say were handled by the London dealer Robin Symes and destined for markets in the United States, Japan and Britain have been returned to Italy, Italian culture officials said Tuesday.

headline: Obama, in Havana Speech, Says Cuba Has Nothing to Fear From U.S.
text: HAVANA — President Obama on Tuesday made a full-throated plea for Cuba’s autocratic government to change, calling on President Raúl Castro to loosen his grip on the economy and political expression or risk squandering the fruits of a historic thaw.

headline: The First Lady Wears Naeem Khan at the Cuba State Dinner
text: When President Obama, the first lady and their daughters arrived in Havana on Sunday, it was the first presidential visit to Cuba since Calvin Coolidge in 1928. Such an occasion demanded diplomacy, behind the scenes and publicly (Mr. Obama and Raúl Castro, Cuba’s president, gave a lengthy news conference), sightseeing and a bit of celebration: a state dinner, held at the Palace of the Revolution.

headline: 1966: Anglican Protests Over Talks
text: The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Michael Ramsey, flew here today [Mar. 22] for history-making talks with Pope Paul VI amidst shouts of ‘‘You traitor.’’ A group of five Protestants, opposed to the historic meeting of the leaders of the Anglican and Roman Catholic Churches, arrived from London on the same plane as the Anglican primate. The five already had caused a scene at London Airport and tried to create another at Rome’s Leonardo da Vinci International Airport, wearing apronlike affairs saying ‘‘Archbishop Ramsey is a traitor to Protestant Britain.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 23, 1966

headline: Carnival Will Begin Cruises to Cuba in May
text: Cruising to Cuba from the United States is now a reality. Carnival Corporation announced Monday that it will offer cruises to Cuba starting May 1, after Cuba granted approval for the company to begin travel there; it’s the first time in more than 50 years that a cruise ship has permission to sail from the United States to Cuba.

headline: Beetle Moms Send a Chemical Signal: ‘Not Tonight, Honey’
text: It’s the bane of a new mother’s life: She’s exhausted, but her male partner wants sex. And besides, she still has to get up for those middle of the night feedings.

headline: Politics and Policy Favor a $15 Minimum Wage in New York
text: The Long Island Fight for $15 — a coalition of low-wage workers, unions, immigration activists and other progressive groups — is arguably the most important right now of many groups fighting to raise chronically low pay.

text: HAMBURG, Germany — With refreshing frankness, a reporter for Der Spiegel has turned the spotlight on himself this week, chronicling his reactions since the authorities announced plans in August to settle 700 refugees in his quiet, family-friendly community in northern Hamburg.

headline: Sourdough Starter, America’s Rising Pet
text: Twenty years ago, after leaving his job as the manager of an Albertsons Market bakery in Twin Falls, Idaho, Rick Hazen found himself missing the taste of fresh bread. He made a sourdough starter using flour and some unprocessed apple juice.

headline: Sturm, Ruger, a Gun Maker, Under Pressure From New York Public Advocate
text: New York’s public advocate is pushing regulators to investigate the gun maker Sturm, Ruger & Company’s disclosures to investors about the risks it faces.

headline: American Cut Brings a Downtown Steakhouse Uptown
text: American Cut Like the chef, the bar area wears downtown black. But this branch of Marc Forgione and LDV Hospitality’s TriBeCa steakhouse is an uptown affair, in the historic Lombardy hotel, steps from Park Avenue in Midtown, so glamour rules. The main dining room, with 132 seats, has the original leaded windows, echoed in the chevron-patterned glass dividers and warmed with rich gold and rosy tones. A wine room with tasting tables runs behind the bar. Steaks are the mainstays, with a 42-ounce tomahawk and a 52-ounce porterhouse that’s flamed with marrow butter. There are grilled fish options, a Caesar salad tossed tableside and the chef’s signature chile lobster in a sriracha and butter sauce served with toast. Aiming for a piece of power-lunch action, the midday menu offers a sandwich of pastrami cured in-house and a quick prix fixe menu with the option of dessert to go. (Opens Wednesday): 109 East 56th Street, 212-388-5277, americancutrestaurants.com.

headline: Silence Equals Trump

So I’ll just recommend his whole post, and quote from the part that addresses the arguments I’ve heard from many people in the know explaining why prominent Republicans, from Paul Ryan on down, are wary of being too forthright about the depth of their opposition to Trump:

headline: English National Opera’s Music Director Resigns
text: In another blow to a beleaguered institution, the English National Opera announced on Tuesday that Mark Wigglesworth would resign as its music director, just months after starting in the position in the fall. The company said in a news release that Mr. Wigglesworth “feels unable to continue as music director despite the best efforts of the board and senior management to persuade him to remain.”

headline: F.D.A. Toughens Warning Labels for Some Opioid Painkillers
text: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that it was requiring new warning labels for certain types of opioid painkillers, a step that it said would help ease an epidemic of abuse in the United States.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Call to ‘Secure’ Muslim Neighborhoods Stirs a Backlash
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas angered American Muslims on Tuesday with a call to “patrol and secure Muslim neighborhoods” in the wake of the terrorist attacks in Brussels.

headline: John Kasich Warns Against Singling Out Muslims for Monitoring
text: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio on Tuesday cautioned against monitoring Muslim-Americans after the attacks in Brussels, saying that such a step would create division and harm the country’s ability to gather intelligence.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Worker Class-Action Suit Against Tyson
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday sided with thousands of workers at an Iowa pork processing plant who had sought to band together in a single lawsuit to recover overtime pay from Tyson Foods.

headline: The Fitness Store Challenging Lululemon With $400 Yoga Pants
text: On a recent Wednesday night, about 70 fitness devotees wearing in-the-know brands like Heroine Sport and Outdoor Voices were crammed into a studio in the Flatiron district, mastering their leg lifts while Pink Floyd’s “Comfortably Numb” blared overhead. Taryn Toomey, a founder of the workout program called “the Class,” led the group.

headline: Donald Trump Dismisses Ad That Quotes Him Demeaning Women
text: Donald J. Trump this week dismissed questions about an advertisement that features women reciting some of his past words about female physical appearances, including insults, calling the remarks “show business.”

headline: Living With One Parent
text: Children living with a single parent tend to do worse in life than those who grow up in a stable two-parent family. The United States has one of the highest percentage of children living without a father among advanced countries, as well as one of the highest shares of children living in poverty.

headline: Review: ‘Seven Brief Lessons on Physics’ Is Long on Knowledge
text: The short and resonant essays in Carlo Rovelli’s “Seven Brief Lessons on Physics” began as columns in Il Sole 24 Ore, the Italian newspaper. Even better, they appeared in that paper’s culture section, its editors sensing that its arty readers could use a bit of stretching.

text: Should the government push poor people to marry?

headline: Gail Collins: What’s My Column About? It’s About 800 Words.

headline: Mind-Based Therapies May Ease Lower Back Pain
text: Sixty-five million Americans suffer from chronic lower back pain, and many feel they have tried it all: physical therapy, painkillers, shots. Now a new study reports many people may find relief with a form of meditation that harnesses the power of the mind to manage pain.

headline: In Criminal Rulings, Garland Has Usually Sided With Law Enforcement
text: WASHINGTON — After a jury found a man guilty of several gun and drug offenses, he took his case to the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. In the spring of 1998, two of the judges on a panel that heard his case agreed to vacate two of his convictions, saying that the evidence was too thin to support one, and the trial judge had made a mistake that tainted the other.

headline: Chip-Card Payment System Delays Frustrate Retailers
text: Avi Kaner, a co-owner of the Morton Williams supermarket chain in New York, has spent about $700,000 to update the payment terminals at his stores.

headline: David Chang’s Next Restaurant, Ando, Will Be Delivery Only
text: David Chang doesn’t want you to know the location of his next restaurant. In a new article in Fast Company magazine, the chef says that this spring he plans to open a place called Ando, devoted exclusively to food that’s delivered to customers.

headline: The Voluntourist’s Dilemma
text: Several years ago, when I was working as a reporter based in Haiti, I came upon a group of older Christian missionaries in the mountains above Port-au-Prince, struggling with heavy shovels to stir a pile of cement and sand. They were there to build a school alongside a Methodist church. Muscular Haitian masons stood by watching, perplexed and a bit amused at the sight of men and women who had come all the way from the United States to do a mundane construction job.

headline: Review: Anthony Cheung’s ‘Elective Memory,’ a Response to Beethoven
text: When the violinist Jennifer Koh asked Anthony Cheung to write a piece for her, responding to Beethoven, he happened to be already working on “Lyra,” a commission from the New York Philharmonic partly inspired by that composer’s Fourth Piano Concerto.

headline: The Filler Effect
text: When patients land in a dermatologist’s office, frustrated with a line or fold, they often want to plump the offending crease with filler. See a wrinkle, fill a wrinkle.

headline: In Brussels, Europe Is Struck at Its Heart
text: BARCELONA, SPAIN — It is not working. President Obama’s slow-but-steady strategy to defeat the Islamic State is clawing back a little territory in Syria and Iraq but is doing nothing to dent the charismatic appeal of the militant group, disrupt its propaganda or prevent it from killing Europeans.

headline: Review: ‘Heartbeat,’ a Hospital Drama, Goes Above and Beyond Credulity
text: The situation is growing desperate in America’s fake hospitals. Not from a financial crisis or a nursing shortage. It’s a desperation of plotting. The medical-drama genre is now so exhausted that hospital shows have to go to absurd lengths to make viewers pay attention, and that has never been more evident than in “Heartbeat,” which begins on Wednesday on NBC.

headline: With Brussels Airport Shut Down, What Travelers Need to Know
text: Brussels Airport shut down following the terrorist attacks in the city on Tuesday morning and will remain closed through tomorrow, Friday, according to a statement on the airport’s site.

headline: The Death of the Latin American Left
text: The Latin American left has had a miserable few months. In Argentina, Venezuela and Bolivia, it was decisively defeated in three different kinds of elections. The president of Ecuador, Rafael Correa, most likely seeing the trends around him, decided to abandon his attempts to remain in power. In Chile, corruption scandals are tightening around previously respected leaders. Most recently, the web of graft has caught one of the most revered figures among Latin America’s 21st-century leftists: the former president of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

headline: Review: Joshua Bell Plays Tchaikovsky at David Geffen Hall
text: Joshua Bell and the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields gave a crisp, accomplished rendition of Tchaikovsky’s Violin Concerto on Monday evening at David Geffen Hall. But during the performance my mind kept drifting to a version of that work that’s been surging out of my headphones in recent days.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Honest Message in Cuba
text: President Obama began his speech to the Cuban people on Tuesday with humility and grace. “Cultivo una rosa blanca,” he said, reciting the opening line of one of the most famous poems by José Martí, the island’s national hero. “I plant a white rose.”

headline: A Furniture Maker’s Quest: Create Everything From Scratch
text: M. Crow & Company, a new boutique at 16 Howard Street in SoHo, is filled with lust-worthy, whimsical wares you probably never knew you needed.

headline: Political Substance Abuse: Donald Trump’s Washington Press Conference
text: This installment of Political Substance Abuse is set in the “Old Post Office,” in Washington, D.C., a historic building that The Trump Organization is converting into a hotel. Donald Trump held a press conference there on Monday as part of a day trip to the nation’s capital that many media commentators called “trying to look presidential.” Mr. Trump met with legislators on Capitol Hill and visited the editorial board of the Washington Post, where he revealed that rather than solely advising himself on foreign affairs, he sometimes relies on a collection of mostly-unknown advisers, who help him advise himself. He sat down to an on-camera, in-person interview on CNN, instead of phoning it in, as he usually does, then capped his day by speaking at the American Israel Public Affairs Committee’s conference. Mr. Trump had an actual speech written for his AIPAC appearance, and he used a teleprompter, despite saying, in Florida last week, verbatim: “No teleprompters. Do you notice? I’m not reading speeches. No reading speeches. No reading speeches. Speak from the heart, and from the head. But speak from the heart. We gotta do it. We gotta do it. We speak from the heart. And from the head! You know? Let’s not forget that. But we’ve gotta do it.”

headline: Sophia Webster Wins British Fashion Award
text: LONDON — Sophia Webster, the London-based accessories designer best known for her eye for color and playfully eccentric statement footwear, won the 2016 British Fashion Council/Vogue Designer Fashion Fund prize Tuesday night.

headline: Brussels Attacks Fuel Debate Over Migrants in a Fractured Europe
text: LONDON — It did not take long. Almost as soon as the bombs went off in Brussels on Tuesday morning, the new act of terrorism in the heart of Europe was employed in the bitter debate about the influx of migrants from the Middle East and North Africa.

headline: Flamenco Shows of Intimacy, Passion and Spectacle
text: For dance fans in New York, the madness this March has been the flood of flamenco. After the four-day Festival Ay! Mas Flamenco at Symphony Space at the start of the month, three weeks of Flamenco Festival New York followed, bigger than ever. Productions at City Center and Carnegie Hall were augmented by a series of intimate shows at Joe’s Pub. As soon as those ended, on Saturday, the beloved local troupe Noche Flamenca moved right in to Joe’s Pub to extend the madness for another week.

headline: The Unsettling Acquisitiveness of Anbang, a Chinese Insurer, in the U.S.
text: A buying spree by a Chinese insurance company that has emerged seemingly overnight is flashing a warning sign.

headline: A Cult Hotel Opens in New Orleans
text: Despite their distinctly local designs, stepping into any of the Ace Hotel’s eight international locations — where moody interiors attract familiar crowds of 30-something hipster types — triggers a bit of déjà vu. Such is the case at the chain’s ninth hotel in New Orleans, which opened last week in a 100-year-old Art Deco high-rise on the outskirts of the French Quarter.

headline: Beach House’s Installation Show
text: The musical duo has created a series of concert experiences with immersive multimedia elements, for several stops interspersed with their regular tour.

headline: Beach House’s New Transportive Performances Double as Art
text: The members of the dream-pop duo Beach House tend to spend their time onstage swathed in brilliant hues, or backlit by stars. When Victoria Legrand and Alex Scally take to their instruments (keyboards and guitar, respectively), they’re washed in shades of fuchsia and violet; the outlines of their bodies and the flourish of their movements are the only things that keep them from melting into the saturated field of color behind them. Their backdrop recalls the fluorescent lightscapes of James Turrell — gradual, simple spreads of brilliance that serve as a perfect foil to the ethereal music they’ve been crafting since they met and began to work together in 2004.

headline: Deirdre O’Connell, Theater’s Master of the Melancholy Mom
text: The actress Deirdre O’Connell wants all you writers to know how much fun she’s had playing your characters. If you would just stop killing her children, that would be super.

headline: Brussels Survivors Say Blasts Instantly Evoked Paris Attacks

Salomé Corbo, an actress from Montreal, was at the Air Canada counter, about to check her luggage. Elouan Preaud and his wife, Angelina Centeno, were having breakfast, waiting to board an American Airlines flight to her native Colombia.

headline: Brussels Attacks Raise Questions on Readiness
text: Washington — A week after the attacks early last year in Paris against the magazine Charlie Hebdo and a kosher grocery, Belgian police officers were fired on as they executed a search warrant in the town of Verviers. Officials learned that the assailants were members of a terrorist cell that had been planning a significant attack on Belgian police officers or civilians.

headline: World Monuments Light Up in Colors of Belgium
text: A look at landmarks around the world lit up in the colors of the Belgian flag.

headline: Thermo Fisher’s Rival for an Affymetrix Deal Raises Its Bid
