headline: Standing With Brussels Against Terrorism and Fear
text: This time the bombs exploded in Brussels, at the airport and on a metro train, brutally snuffing out at least 30 lives and wounding hundreds. The airport and much of the city were shut down, the police dragnets spread and the anguished questions arose: Why? How did the Islamic State, which claimed responsibility, plan this attack? Was this retaliation for the arrest last week of the last surviving Paris bomber? What have we missed?

headline: Art of the Anecdote: Presidential Candidates’ Speeches to AIPAC
text: Personal anecdotes, especially when deployed in debates, tend to register as shallow, self-aggrandizing attempts to show that a candidate has compassion, experience, or a compelling history. But at times the vignette a candidate chooses sheds light — for better or worse — on his or her personality. At Monday’s conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee in Washington, a prime opportunity to woo pro-Israel voters, every candidate drew from examples of terrorist outrages against Israel to condemn extremists in the Middle East. Ted Cruz, John Kasich, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton all appeared in person, delivering staunch and often hawkish pledges to defend Israeli national security. Bernie Sanders did not appear in Washington but delivered his AIPAC speech at a school in Salt Lake City, where he was campaigning. Mr. Sanders reiterated America’s commitment to “guaranteeing Israel’s survival” but he also criticized Israel’s “disproportionate responses to being attacked” by Palestinians.

headline: Kevin Hart to Publish Memoir Next Year
text: Like most comedians, Kevin Hart takes a confessional tone in his stand-up. He has made intimate and often uncomfortable jokes about his father’s cocaine addiction, his mother’s death from cancer, his marriage and divorce, and his experience being a parent.

headline: Boy With Gun at Brooklyn Middle School Is Charged
text: A 14-year-old boy took an unloaded gun in his backpack to a Brooklyn middle school on Tuesday, the third time in a week that a student has been caught with a firearm on a New York City school campus, the authorities said.

headline: Queens Man Convicted of Murder for Dragging Victim Under Car
text: A 22-year-old Queens man was found guilty on Tuesday of driving into a crowd and killing a man pinned under his car after a fight at a baby shower in 2014, prosecutors said.

headline: Raiders’ Owner Looks to Las Vegas as Possible New Home
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — With all the criticism the N.F.L. has taken about its stance on gambling and daily fantasy sports, perhaps the last place a team might land is Las Vegas.

headline: Goldman Banker in Document Leak Case Avoids Prison
text: A former Goldman Sachs banker who pleaded guilty to taking confidential documents from a source inside the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was sentenced to probation on Tuesday, bringing to a close an episode that embarrassed the bank and the New York Fed alike.

headline: A Blurry Photo Hints at ISIS Tradecraft
text: The grainy image captured on a surveillance camera at Brussels Airport shows three men pushing luggage carts into the check-in terminal. Their expressions seem casual, even relaxed.

headline: A Well-Traveled Jordan Spieth Adjusts to Being the Main Attraction
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The handshake line for the superstar formed near the courtside seats reserved for Jordan Spieth, his girlfriend and four other friends during the Mavericks’ game last week against the Golden State Warriors in Spieth’s hometown, Dallas. As Stephen Curry entered the court for pregame warm-ups, Spieth stood alongside other avid basketball fans and extended his left arm to try to make a connection with Curry, who jogged right past him.

headline: Puerto Rico Fights for Chapter 9 Bankruptcy in Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — Debt-laden Puerto Rico went toe to toe with its creditors at the Supreme Court on Tuesday, arguing that it has been wrongly locked out of the bankruptcy courts, the only place it can reasonably expect to restructure its crushing debt.

headline: New York Police Increase Patrols Around 20 Clubs to Combat Knife Violence
text: Police officials said on Tuesday that they would increase enforcement around 20 bars and clubs in New York City with a disproportionate share of the stabbings and slashings that have resulted in a surge in knife violence this year.

headline: Nuclear Plant Leak Threatens Drinking Water Wells in Florida
text: MIAMI — When Florida’s largest power company added two nuclear reactors to an existing plant that sat between two national parks — Biscayne Bay and the Everglades — the decision raised the concerns of environmentalists and some government officials about the possible effects on water quality and marine life.

headline: Apple Policy on Bugs May Explain Why Hackers Would Help F.B.I.
text: SAN FRANCISCO — After a third party went to the F.B.I. with claims of being able to unlock an iPhone, many in the security industry said they were not surprised that the third party did not go to Apple.

headline: Mets and Yankees Brace for a Future Without Smokeless Tobacco
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Midway through spring training, the Yankees posted a sign on a bulletin board in their clubhouse telling players that anyone wanting “nicotine replacement therapy supplies (gum, lozenges or patches) — to kick the habit” should see the team trainer.

headline: Leon H. Charney, Investor, Cable TV Host and Peace Broker, Is Dead at 77
text: Leon H. Charney, an entertainment lawyer who expanded his portfolio to become an author, a television host, a real estate mogul and a back-channel peace broker between Egypt and Israel, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: Birth Defects Tied to Zika in Panama
text: WASHINGTON — Panama has reported its first case of birth defects associated with the Zika virus, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday — new evidence of the epidemic’s potentially dangerous effects spreading throughout the region.

headline: A Victory for the Visitors, but a Celebration for the Fans
text: HAVANA — The ball soared off the bat of Tampa Bay’s James Loney in the top of the fourth inning and headed toward the stands in right field that were painted with the slogan “Sport, Conquest of the Revolution.”

headline: Top Experts Confounded by Advisers to Donald Trump
text: WASHINGTON — When Donald J. Trump finally began to reveal the names of his foreign policy advisers during a swing through Washington this week, the Republican foreign policy establishment looked at them and had a pretty universal reaction: Who?

headline: New York State Considers Further Expansion of Once-Illicit Activities
text: ALBANY — Gambling. Hand-to-hand combat. Booze.

headline: Dementia Care, Tailored to N.F.L. Retirees
text: BRADENTON, Fla. — With the expectation that more N.F.L. players will suffer dementia from repeated head hits, businesses that cater to people with memory loss are gearing up for what could be droves of new clients in the near future.

headline: Cuban Dissidents Praise ‘Closeness and Trust’ After Meeting With Obama
text: HAVANA — Leading Cuban dissidents, including some who have been critical of President Obama’s policy of engaging with the Cuban government, spent nearly two hours on Tuesday discussing human rights with the president.

headline: Presidential Candidates Walking a Tightrope Over the Fight on Terrorism
text: WASHINGTON — Ten hours before terrorists struck Brussels, Donald J. Trump was on television describing his strategy for confronting the Islamic State: He would pound it with airstrikes, but any ground action must be taken by the United States’ partners in the region. He did not mention, if he knew, that this was a pretty close approximation of President Obama’s approach.

headline: Porous Borders and Calcified Security Aid Islamic State in Europe
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and its allies have spent nearly 20 months bombing the Islamic State in classic military style — barraging Syria and Iraq in an effort to dislodge the group from its seat of power.

headline: New York Passes Rent Rules to Blunt Gentrification
text: The New York City Council passed sweeping changes to the zoning code on Tuesday, compelling private developers to build low-cost rental units and handing Mayor Bill de Blasio a victory on the centerpiece of his efforts to blunt neighborhood gentrification.

headline: 3 Men Killed in Queens House Fire
text: Three men died after a fire broke out in a house in Queens late on Monday, the authorities said.

headline: Fine Arts Museums in San Francisco Picks Max Hollein as Next Director
text: In a surprising move, the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco has gone beyond the United States for its next director, hiring Max Hollein away from the Städel Museum in Frankfurt.

headline: Derek Jeter Emerges at Rays-Cuba Game in Havana
text: After a year spent mostly out of the spotlight, Derek Jeter was front and center Tuesday afternoon, sitting in the stands in Havana to watch the Tampa Bay Rays take on the Cuban national team, joking with President Obama, who was sitting nearby, and taking part in an interview on ESPN, which broadcast the game.

headline: Review: ‘Dry Powder,’ a High-Finance Comedy Drama
text: Calling all Bernie Sanders fans. There’s a pageant of red meat for you onstage at the Public Theater, where Sarah Burgess’s “Dry Powder,” about rapacious wheeling and dealing in the world of high finance, opened on Tuesday night. Take your forks and knives — and heck, your pitchforks, too — and dig in!

headline: Minuet Meter
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s possible to overthink a theme, and today I did just that. Maybe you did, too. I have to say that I honestly didn’t see this one coming. Bravo to Alex Boisvert and Jeff Chen for pushing the envelope, because I don’t believe that anyone else has taken this type of theme this far.

headline: Jan Nemec, Czech Filmmaker Known for Works of ‘Dream Realism,’ Dies at 79
text: Jan Nemec, whose surreal, parable-like films made him one of the leading lights of the Czech new wave in the 1960s, died on March 18 in Prague. He was 79.

headline: In a Cuban Enclave in New Jersey, Skeptics View a Moment With Open Minds
text: Union City, N.J.

headline: Belgian Golfer, Set to Begin Tournament in U.S., Has Heavy Heart
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The Belgian golfer Thomas Pieters awakened in his hotel room Tuesday to a buzzing smartphone. It was around 6 a.m. on the eve of Pieters’s debut in the World Golf Championship match-play event at Austin Country Club. Pieters, 24, scrolled through the numbers and saw that friends from all over the world had contacted him, and his heart sank. He said he “kind of knew” before he turned on the television that terrorists had struck again.

headline: U.S. Strike in Yemen Kills Dozens in Qaeda Affiliate, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — An American airstrike on Tuesday killed dozens of fighters at a mountainous training camp used by the Yemeni affiliate of Al Qaeda, Pentagon officials said, the latest sign that the military is hastening its strikes against militants in the Middle East and Africa.

headline: Charles Kaufman, Transformative Leader of Mannes College of Music, Dies at 87
text: Charles Kaufman, who led a faculty coup that spared the century-old Mannes College of Music in Manhattan from a troublesome merger in 1979 and then restored it to fiscal soundness, died on March 17 at his home in Hillsdale, N.J. He was 87.

headline: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’ Season 1, Episode 8: We the Jury
text: Was being a juror on the O.J. Simpson trial so miserable that one of them actually tried to escape and run away?

headline: In Havana, Rapprochement Through the Lens of ESPN
text: The game between the Tampa Bay Rays and the Cuban national team in Havana on Tuesday was a television spectacle, presented by ESPN as a game entwined in international politics. The visuals were clear from the frequent cuts between the on-field action and President Obama and President Raúl Castro, who were sitting together at Estadio Latinoamericano. Economic policy was laid out in Obama’s remarks about how business from America will help give the United States leverage in Cuba.

headline: Steven Matz Struggles, but Luis Severino Doesn’t as Yankees Beat Mets
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When Steven Matz exited after another disappointing spring training start, and later when he met with reporters, he did not show any sign of emotion. Dan Warthen, the Mets’ pitching coach, had talked to him about taking a cue from Matt Harvey and Jacob deGrom and maintaining his composure and exuding calmness.

headline: Clinton and Trump Win Arizona; Cruz Picks Up Utah; Sanders Takes 2
text: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump overwhelmed their rivals in the Arizona primaries on Tuesday, a show of might from two presidential front-runners who are hoping to avoid prolonging the nominating contest and begin training their fire on each other.

headline: Jack Antonoff Will Track the Glory Days of CDs for a Book
text: In the age of streaming music, there is no shortage of nostalgia for record stores that fostered a sense of community and also sold tangible products. But in mourning that mostly bygone era of erudite clerks and obscure, collectible titles, it’s possible to overlook the very recent past — namely, the more mainstream ’90s CD culture, with its megachains like Tower Records and Sam Goody.

headline: Medicare Proposal Takes Aim at Diabetes
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration plans on Wednesday to propose expanding Medicare to cover programs to prevent diabetes among millions of people at high risk of developing the disease, marking the sixth anniversary of the Affordable Care Act with the prospect of a new benefit, federal officials said.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | trappings
text: trappings • \ˈtra-piNz\ • noun

headline: Convoy Sees Itself as the Uber of Local Trucking
text: SEATTLE — It has become a tech industry cliché to describe new on-demand businesses as “Ubers for X” — with X being anything from furniture movers to dispensers of medical marijuana.

headline: Baselworld: A Time Zone
text: Hundreds of watch brands take to the floor each year at Baselworld, the world's largest luxury watch fair. Here are the most arresting new pieces unveiled at the 2016 event.

headline: Donald Trump Threatens Ted Cruz’s Wife, Eliciting Angry Retort
text: For a moment, it seemed Donald J. Trump thought he had gone too far. The moment passed.

headline: What to Watch Wednesday
text: Jason Segel stars as David Foster Wallace in “The End of the Tour,” about that author’s book tour for “Infinite Jest.” And cable TV provides opportunities to see both “The Avengers” and its bombastic sequel, “Avengers: Age of Ultron.”

headline: Corrections: March 23, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “In 10 seconds, everything changed. It was an apocalypse. There was blood everywhere.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Attacks Donald Trump in Arizona Victory Speech
text: SEATTLE — Hillary Clinton used a victory rally here on Tuesday night to sharply challenge the leading Republican candidate, Donald J. Trump, calling him a “demagogue” who was “inciting bigotry and violence” and whose “bullying behavior” called for a timeout.

headline: Women Balancing Work and Family
text: When Alice Proujansky was pregnant with her first child, a man at a party came up to her and remarked, “You’ll never want to go back to work when you see those baby’s eyes.” Ms. Proujansky doesn’t remember her reply. “Probably something like, ‘Well, I doubt that will happen,’ ” she said. “Documentary photography isn’t exactly the kind of career people are lukewarm about or just fall into and out of. And my children’s eyes are beautiful, but they won’t pay my student loan bills either!”

headline: John Coltrane’s ‘A Love Supreme’ and Billy Joel’s ‘Piano Man’ Join National Recording Registry
text: John Coltrane’s “A Love Supreme” and Billy Joel’s “Piano Man” are part of the incoming class added to the National Recording Registry of the Library of Congress this year. The diverse crop of new inductees also includes the Vienna Philharmonic’s 1938 recording of Mahler’s Ninth Symphony, Metallica’s “Master of Puppets” and live coverage from Wilt Chamberlain’s 100-point game.

headline: Bush Would Have Nominated Garland
text: AS the chief ethics lawyer in the White House Counsel Office, I helped President George W. Bush with the nomination and confirmation of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. to the Supreme Court.

headline: Does Obama Have This Right?
text: Sulaimaniya, Iraq — As one could see from President Obama’s recent interview in The Atlantic, he pretty much hates all the Middle East’s leaders including those of Turkey, Iraq, Syria, Israel, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Jordan, Iran and the Palestinians.

headline: The Republican Crackup
text: The furious fighting in the ranks of Republican opponents of Donald Trump — combat that is growing ever more heated and rhetorically violent — has forced open to public view long-festering wounds in the conservative coalition.

headline: No Contraception? No Equality
text: THE Supreme Court will hear a second challenge to the Affordable Care Act’s contraceptive mandate on Wednesday in a case called Zubik v. Burwell. The plaintiffs want to extend the 2014 ruling in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, which recognized the right of certain for-profit companies to a religious exemption from the act’s requirement that employers’ health plans provide contraceptive coverage.

headline: Waiting for Round 2 in the Phone Fight
text: The Department of Justice says that it might have found a way to unlock an iPhone used by a terrorist without Apple’s assistance. For the moment, this has halted a legal confrontation between the government and the company. But the question of whether the government can compel Apple to assist it in unlocking its phones remains unanswered, which means that similar disputes will continue to develop.

headline: Brothers Among 3 Brussels Suicide Attackers; Another Assailant Is Sought
text: BRUSSELS — The Brussels suicide bombers included two Belgium-born brothers with a violent criminal past and suspected links to plotters of the Islamic State’s Paris attacks last November, the authorities said on Wednesday, raising new alarms about Europe’s leaky defenses against a militant organization that has terrorized two European capitals with seeming impunity.

headline: Lights Are Displayed on Trade Center in Brussels Tribute
text: After some initial technical difficulties, 1 World Trade Center was lit up in the colors of Belgium’s flag late Tuesday in a show of solidarity after the attacks in Brussels.

headline: News Q’s | Strikes Claimed by ISIS Shut Brussels and Shake European Security
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Strikes Claimed by ISIS Shut Brussels and Shake European Security.”

headline: Debris Is Probably From Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, Investigators Say
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The authorities said Thursday that two pieces of debris found in Mozambique were highly likely to have come from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which has been missing for more than two years.

headline: Women Balancing Work and Family
text: After Alice Proujansky’s first child was born, she set out to photograph women who — like her — were balancing the demands of a career and family.

headline: Credit Suisse Chief Says Risky Bets Were a ‘Surprise’
text: A thirst for revenue “at all costs” drove traders at Credit Suisse to take large, risky positions, catching top executives off guard and forcing them to accelerate cost-cutting over the next three years, the bank’s chief executive said on Wednesday.

headline: Living in Ossining, N.Y.
text: The village on the Hudson in Westchester draws first-time buyers and empty nesters with its reasonable home prices.

headline: Ossining, N.Y.: History, Parks and ‘Mad Men’
text: The village of Ossining, N.Y., on the Hudson River in Westchester, has a surprisingly large place in American culture, given its three-square-mile size. Rich in pre-Revolutionary War history, it is also the site of the state-run Sing Sing Correctional Facility and was home to both the author John Cheever and the fictional character of Don Draper in the AMC series “Mad Men.”

headline: Global Crises Shadow, and Overshadow, Obama’s Foreign Trips
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama woke up in Havana on Tuesday to news that explosives had ripped through an airport and a subway in Brussels, it was a familiar, if disconcerting, feeling: another foreign trip overshadowed by violence elsewhere in the world.

headline: Obama Visit Affirms Argentina’s Shift Toward Center
text: BUENOS AIRES — The last time an American president visited Argentina, he got caught in the maw of a rising leftist movement in Latin America.

headline: Student Question | How Do You Deal With Haters?
text: How do you deal with haters? Do you shake it off, as Taylor Swift suggests? Or do you find that the mean comments get you down no matter how hard you try to move past them?

headline: The Uber Model, It Turns Out, Doesn’t Translate
text: In San Francisco, as in most cities, parking is an expensive daily grind that saps the soul. So a year and a half ago, when I discovered the valet-parking app Luxe, the heavens parted, choirs began singing and double rainbows colored the sky. This, I was convinced, could be the next big thing.

headline: Justices Seem Split in Case on Birth Control Mandate
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court weighed moral theology and parsed insurance terminology on Wednesday in an extended and animated argument that seemed to leave the justices sharply divided over what the government may do to require employers to provide free insurance coverage for contraception to female workers.

headline: What’s at Stake in Supreme Court Case on Contraception
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Wednesday in a case about access to contraception and religious liberty, Zubik v. Burwell, No. 14-1418. Here is a look at the parties and issues in the case.

headline: Cuba Says It Has Solved Racism. Obama Isn’t So Sure.
text: HAVANA — President Obama spoke of his Kenyan heritage. He talked about how both the United States and Cuba were built on the backs of slaves from Africa. He mentioned that not very long ago, his parents’ marriage would have been illegal in America, and he urged Cubans to respect the power of protest to bring about equality.

headline: At Columbus Circle, a New Home for Underground Gourmets
text: Sit-down dining is coming to the subway.

headline: ‘Rightful Heritage: Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Land of America,’ by Douglas Brinkley
text: RIGHTFUL HERITAGEFranklin D. Roosevelt and the Land of AmericaBy Douglas BrinkleyIllustrated. 744 pp. Harper/HarperCollins Publishers. $35.

headline: Chocolate Can Boost Your Workout. Really.
text: Adding a little dark chocolate to a training diet may effortlessly improve endurance performance, according to a new study of sports nutrition. The findings provide ammunition both for athletes looking for an edge and those hoping for an excuse to indulge.

headline: Resort News: Luxury at Disney World, Flowers in Tuscany
text: A NEW DESTINATION ON SRI LANKA’S SOUTHERN COAST

headline: The Secrets to a Happy Life, From a Harvard Study
text: What does it take to live a good life?

headline: Jeb Bush Endorses Ted Cruz in Republican Primary
text: Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida who left the presidential race after the South Carolina primary, endorsed Ted Cruz on Wednesday, becoming the most prominent member of the Republican establishment to support the Texas senator as he tries to slow Donald J. Trump’s efforts to capture the presidential nomination.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Brussels Airport, iPhone, Rob Ford
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: China Aims to Tighten Its Borders Against Foreign Place Names
text: HONG KONG — There is a Vancouver Forest in Beijing, a Thames Town in Shanghai and an Oriental Yosemite in Dalian, China.

headline: After Taking a Shower, Shower Your Lawn?
text: Food from garden to table. Solar power from roof to outlet. And now soapy water from your own shower to your lawn?

headline: New York Today: Ready to Rezone
text: Updated, 7:43 a.m.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Unsettling Acquisitiveness of Anbang
text: THE UNSETTLING ACQUISITIVENESS OF ANBANG | Anbang’s spending spree is a sign that deal-making has gone awry,Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.

headline: Brussels After the Attacks
text: The Belgian capital began returning to a semblance of normality on Wednesday, albeit under a heavy police and military presence.

headline: Paul Ryan to Urge Republicans to Focus on Policy
text: Is someone going to start listening to House Speaker Paul D. Ryan?

headline: Fresh Off Grand Slam Win, England Appears Energized by Its New Coach
text: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — England has celebrated its first Six Nations Grand Slam in 13 years, but the challenge it faces in Australia in June will most likely be significantly sterner and should give its new coach, Eddie Jones, a clearer picture of where his team sits in rugby union’s global pecking order.

headline: Australian Energy Giant Woodside Delays Large Offshore L.N.G. Project
text: Woodside Petroleum and its partners, including the energy giants Royal Dutch Shell and BP, have decided to delay indefinitely the development of a huge liquefied natural gas project off Western Australia, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start the day.

headline: How Much Money Is Enough?
text: Most of us want our children to have the best of everything, but not too much of anything.

headline: Brioni Announces Its Own Unconventional Hire
text: Justin O’Shea, former fashion director of the German e-commerce giant MyTheresa, has been appointed creative director at Brioni, the latest unorthodox hiring by a luxury brand as the sector strains for innovative approaches in an ever more competitive environment.

headline: How to Stop the Bouncing Between Insurance Plans Under Obamacare
text: Millions of Americans are finding Obamacare to be unstable ground.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Just Saying No to a Baby Registry
text: Viola writes: I am a grown woman starting a family with my beloved wife. I know what I want to have for my child in my home and take pleasure in being able to afford those things. My family insists that if I don’t provide them with a registry, they will just get me gifts anyway. How can I prevent this and maintain my status as a kind person?

headline: Must a Woman Confront a Bigoted In-Law?
text: My father-in-law is quietly racist, sexist and anti-gay. He was kind enough to offer me a job at his firm. I had previously voiced my (respectful) dissent, but this became tiring when I saw him every day. I began to ignore his comments but felt guilty, because I believe that silence equals complicity. One day, after he said something particularly mean and I said nothing, I assuaged my guilt by making a donation to Planned Parenthood. Since then, I’ve adopted a strategy of donating to different organizations whenever I fail to speak up. The amounts are small, but large enough to be uncomfortable for me; I see these as a kind of punishment for not being courageous or energetic enough to keep standing up to him.

headline: We’re More Honest With Our Phones Than With Our Doctors
text: In the late 1960s, an undergraduate psychology student at Wellesley College named Martha McClintock noticed something interesting: Women who spent a majority of their time together tended to get their periods around the same time. She suspected that menstruating bodies could influence one another somehow, but it was just a hunch. So she asked 135 of her fellow students to keep track of their cycles. Three times that year, she quizzed them about their period start and which women they socialized with the most.

headline: After a Fire, Megabus Passengers Stranded on Compensation
text: When I exited my Megabus a few weeks ago in Milwaukee, Wis., saying goodbye to my fellow passengers and ending what had been an extremely eventful, harrowing trip, I had a sinking feeling that the events of the day would quickly be glossed over and forgotten. The bus I was on had erupted into a ball of fire on the Interstate, endangering our lives and destroying the bus and most of my fellow passengers’ baggage (I did not lose any property). Thankfully, we all managed to get away unharmed. But while my tweetstorm garnered attention, I knew that because there were no injuries, Megabus would very likely not be taken to task for the incident, beyond some bad P.R.

headline: How Aerial Surveillance Has Changed Policing — and Crime — in Los Angeles
text: The air-support division of the Los Angeles Police Department operates out of a labyrinthine building on Ramirez Street in the city’s downtown, near the Los Angeles River. A looming mass of utilitarian architecture tucked beside the 101 Freeway, the complex appears to have no real public face; here the view from the street matters little. Instead, like much of the city around it, the air-support division makes more sense when seen from above.

headline: With Jeb Bush’s Backing, Ted Cruz Makes Push to Stop Donald Trump
text: In the wake of the results of the contests in Arizona and Utah, the dual-track primaries move forward to the next big test, Wisconsin, on April 5. But in the Republican battle, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is spending time on Donald J. Trump’s turf for a second day in a row, as he tries to galvanize support in the establishment behind his candidacy.

headline: The Islamic State’s European Front
text: The bombs that exploded in the Brussels airport and at a central metro station on Tuesday morning, killing at least 30 people, came as only the latest in a string of terrorist outrages on a continent that is starting to see horrific violence as the new normal. Hours later the Islamic State claimed responsibility.

headline: HSBC Adds Former Chief Executive of Standard Life to Board
text: LONDON — HSBC said on Wednesday that it would add the former chief executive of the insurer Standard Life as a director, as the British lender continues to shake up its board.

headline: Whiting Foundation Announces Winners of 2016 Awards for Writing
text: The winners of the 2016 Whiting Awards were announced on Wednesday night at the New-York Historical Society, with each of the 10 chosen writers receiving a cash award of $50,000. The awards are given for “early-career achievement and the promise of superior literary work to come,” according to the Whiting Foundation.

headline: Prime Suspect in Koala’s Murder: Los Angeles’s Mountain Lion
text: LOS ANGELES — The murder was grisly. A koala disappeared from the Los Angeles Zoo one night this month. Its body, mangled and bloody, was found the next morning on a nearby hillside.

headline: Regrouping After the Death of a Top Executive
text: After three years of planning and design work, XTI Aircraft, a start-up in Englewood, Colo., developing an experimental jet, was poised to finally leave the runway. The company had lined up its executive team, received its first patent and begun a crowdfunding campaign for its next stage of development work.

headline: A Hairbrush in the Tuba
text: Dear Diary:

headline: $1,749,000 Houses in Maryland, Florida and Washington
text: BALTIMORE

headline: What You Get for ... $1,749,000
text: A 19th-century townhouse in Baltimore, a house in Florida and a view of water in Washington

headline: Judge Orders Extradition to U.S. in ‘Flash Crash’ Case
text: LONDON — A judge ruled on Wednesday that Navinder Singh Sarao can be sent to the United States to face criminal charges accusing him of playing a role in the May 2010 “flash crash” in the United States stock market.

headline: Alabama: Head of Police Agency Fired
text: Gov. Robert Bentley fired the state law enforcement secretary, Spencer Collier, on Tuesday after an internal review. In a statement, Mr. Bentley said the inquiry at the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency had “found a number of issues, including possible misuse of state funds.” The state attorney general’s office is expected to review the results of the inquiry, which began in late February. Mr. Collier, a former state legislator, has been on medical leave since last month and could not be reached for comment on Tuesday night.

headline: Russia, Light on Cash, Weighs Risks of a Heavy Tax on Oil Giants
text: MOSCOW — As the gusher of oil money that underpinned the rise of President Vladimir V. Putin has dwindled in the price slump, the Kremlin has found ways to keep the economy chugging along, albeit at a reduced rate, spending down rainy day funds and cutting wages and pensions.

headline: 1941: Marking Greek Independence
text: The national colors of Greece, Great Britain and the United States fluttered along Park Avenue yesterday, carried by a long column of Greeks and Americans of Greek descent, to mark the 120th anniversary of the beginning of the Greek war of independence.

headline: For Apple, Potential Flaw May Be a Wake-Up Call
text: Timothy D. Cook has found himself in a strange position. It looks like someone knows about an important flaw in Apple’s flagship product, and won’t tell its chief executive what it is.

headline: Taking Someone Off Your iPhone’s Blocked List
text: Q. How do you unblock a number that had been previously blocked on the iPhone 6?

headline: In Defense of Moderate Drinking (Again)
text: A few months ago, I wrote an article here on The Upshot discussing the potential health effects of alcohol. I pointed out that the scientific research said moderate drinking isn’t bad for you; indeed, it might even offer some benefits.

headline: Don Cheadle on Becoming Miles Davis
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Don Cheadle was not looking to play Miles Davis. He had done biopics before, starring as Sammy Davis Jr. in “The Rat Pack” (1998), which earned him a Golden Globe, and as the hotelier and accidental humanitarian Paul Rusesabagina in the 2004 film “Hotel Rwanda,” for which he received an Academy Award nomination. Mr. Cheadle had played the street hoops star Earl Manigault, a.k.a. the Goat, in “Rebound” and the radio D.J. Petey Greene in “Talk to Me”.

headline: Blogger Gets Jail Term in Singapore for Posts Said to Incite Ethnic Hatred
text: HONG KONG — A Japanese-Australian woman was sentenced on Wednesday to a 10-month jail term in Singapore over blog posts that besmirched foreigners in the city-state.

headline: Rule to Require Employers to Disclose Use of Anti-Union Consultants
text: WASHINGTON — The Labor Department on Wednesday released the final version of a rule requiring employers to disclose relationships with the consultants they hire to help persuade workers not to form a union or support a union’s collective bargaining position.

headline: Raiding the Sex Shop for the Latest Fashion
text: “Hmm … I’ll have what she’s having,” I thought last week as I watched the Saint Laurent spring runway show online, the model’s ball-bearing hips sheathed in a black latex bodysuit.

headline: Three Rules of Kremlin Power
text: AT a recent awards ceremony at the Kremlin for scientists, artists and public intellectuals, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia couldn’t help but recount his country’s achievements. But he also offered a word of caution. “We still have a lot of unsolved problems and questions,” he said. “It is certainly no time for us to be ‘dizzy with success.’”

headline: Ex-Trader Tom Hayes Ordered to Pay $1.2 Million in Libor Case
text: LONDON — A judge on Wednesday ordered Tom Hayes, a former UBS and Citigroup trader, to forfeit more than 878,000 pounds, or about $1.2 million, in bonuses and other compensation because of his conviction last year of manipulating a global benchmark interest rate known as Libor.

headline: ‘Daredevil’ Season 2: Watched It All? Let’s Talk
text: Bingeing through the full second season of “Daredevil” exposes you to some of the promises and the pitfalls of Netflix original series. This adaptation of the Marvel comic book about a blind vigilante doesn’t pander to its audience, unless your definition of pandering includes taking the demands of the superhero and crime-noir genres seriously and conscientiously to be a form of pandering per se. And you can see Netflix’s dollars at work, in the explosions and elaborate props and endless waves of ninjas. (O.K., maybe it’s the same 10 ninjas over and over again.)

headline: Sext and the Single Girl
text: GIRLS AND SEXNavigating the Complicated New LandscapeBy Peggy Orenstein303 pp. Harper. $26.99.

headline: Square Teams Up With Facebook to Offer Ads That Can Be Gauged
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Square has long pitched itself to small businesses as a one-stop shop for processing customers’ credit cards. Now the company wants to help get more of those customers in the door.

headline: As Coal Prospects Decline, a Colorado Town Reconsiders Marijuana
text: HOTCHKISS, Colo. — This mountain town of coal miners and organic farmers wasted no time in saying no to marijuana. After Colorado’s 2012 vote legalizing marijuana, local leaders concerned about crime and the character of their tranquil downtown twice voted to ban the recreational and medical pot shops springing up in other towns.

headline: Rise Up! Sourdough Nation
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Doctors Experiment With New Way of Fixing the A.C.L.
text: Anterior cruciate ligaments often tear on the sports field, and after a complete rupture, they are notoriously hard to get to heal.

headline: What Obama Should Know About Macri’s Argentina
text: During his trip to Argentina this week, President Obama is unlikely to visit Milagro Sala. A prominent social activist in the northwestern province of Jujuy, Ms. Sala was arrested in January at the behest of Gov. Gerardo Morales, a political ally of the country’s new president, Mauricio Macri.

headline: Flint Water Crisis Inquiry Finds State Ignored Warning Signs
text: An independent panel has concluded that disregard for the concerns of poor and minority people contributed to the government’s slow response to complaints from residents of Flint, Mich., about the foul and discolored water that was making them sick, determining that the crisis “is a story of government failure, intransigence, unpreparedness, delay, inaction and environmental injustice.”

headline: Bob Mould’s Advice: Keep It Simple and Avoid Streaming Music Services
text: By now, Bob Mould knows what he’s good at.

headline: MoMA Revisits the 1960s
text: The installation of the Museum of Modern Art’s permanent collection has for years been the purview of one or two curators from its department of painting and sculpture, who concentrate almost exclusively on those mediums. But faced with reinstalling its fourth-floor permanent collection galleries after a Picasso sculpture show, MoMA is suspending a familiar postwar narrative. Instead, it has narrowed the focus to the 1960s, one of the most artistically diverse decades of the 20th century, while inviting 17 curators to collaborate on a wide-angle view of the period’s achievements.

headline: Shapes of Morocco at New York Live Arts
text: Radouan Mriziga considers himself an artisan as well as a dancer and choreographer. He treats his body as a tool to fashion not only changing shapes in space but also forms on the floor on which he moves. In “—55,” his 55-minute solo that is to have its American premiere as part of the Live Arts Live Ideas festival, he uses chalk and tape to trace intricate lines and circles on the stage while he dances. His bodily motions may vanish, but his designs remain.

headline: ‘You, Me and the Apocalypse’: Are We Ready for the End?
text: “You, Me and the Apocalypse” hasn’t been the ratings success that NBC hoped for, but it has been one of the season’s most enjoyable series nonetheless. Its finale is Thursday night, March 31, and the fate of the world hangs in the balance. A comet is on a collision course with Earth, and multiple plot threads have been counting down to impact day. A lot of hopes were riding on a plan to divert the comet with a nuclear blast, but — well, we’ll say no more here in case you want to binge this very binge-able series later.

headline: Flint Water Advisory Task Force Report
text: Findings of the Flint Water Task Force, created by Michigan Governor Rick Snyder to investigate lead contamination in the city’s water supply.

headline: In Zayn Malik’s ‘Mind of Mine,’ a Singer Eager to Reclaim Parts of Himself
text: Some of the most impassioned vocals on “Mind of Mine,” the solo debut of the One Direction dissident Zayn Malik, come on a modest mid-album interlude called “Flower.” The producer Malay plays a gentle folk-influenced guitar figure, and Mr. Malik exhales deeply atop it and then begins singing with deeply centered but controlled fervor, “Until the flower of this love has blossomed/Until this heart is at peace.” Then, three times, he pleads, “Give me your heart.”

headline: ‘Fully Committed,’ a Restaurant Story, Is Broadway Bound
text: Take a funny hit show that had a long run in a small Off Broadway theater in the late 1990s, add a charismatic television star and revive it on Broadway: This formula worked well for “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” which debuted in 1998 and triumphantly arrived uptown with Neil Patrick Harris in 2014.

headline: Sam Peckinpah Features at Film Society
text: Sam Peckinpah (1925-1984) was known for his movies about savage collisions between old eras and new, reflecting his own experience as a director who straddled the studio system and New Hollywood. Difficult and headstrong, Mr. Peckinpah made films that critics said glorified carnage and were more than faintly misogynistic. Even so, his bleak morality tales re-energized several genres.

headline: Jen Shyu Presents ‘Song of Silver Geese’ at Roulette
text: The ambition of the singer and composer Jen Shyu keeps pushing outward. She has drawn large parts of her music from travel and study in places including East Timor, Taiwan and Indonesia, where she has learned spoken languages, folk narratives, dances and instrumental techniques. At home in New York, she invests this knowledge in improvisation, working with some of the best jazz musicians around. There’s great erudition in her work, but she wears it lightly; what you notice, both in her singing and her band-leading, is wild originality, purpose and discipline. Ms. Shyu’s latest project is “Song of Silver Geese,” a “ritual music drama” performed in seven languages. It is written for her band, Jade Tongue, as well as a string quartet, and the dancer Satoshi Haga serves as her narrative foil. Its first performance, with the Mivos Quartet, will be on Monday, March 28. (Roulette, Brooklyn; roulette.org.)

headline: ‘Yardbird’ Imagines a Ghostly Charlie Parker Encore
text: The tenor Lawrence Brownlee is familiar to New York opera audiences for his precise coloratura and smooth bel canto singing. This week, he shows off a different side of his artistry — including wordless scat riffs — in the role of Charlie Parker for the New York premiere of “Yardbird,” an opera by the composer Daniel Schnyder and the librettist Bridgette A. Wimberly.

headline: 1966: Chinese-Soviet Split
text: MOSCOW — Peking’s rulers broke off Communist party relations with the Soviet Union today [March 23], creating a rupture between the two great powers that appeared impossible to heal.

headline: Google Showcases Its Cloud Efforts, Determined to Catch Up to Rivals
text: In the cloud computing business, Google’s technology prowess is rarely questioned. Its commitment, however, has been doubted.

headline: John Legend to Co-Produce Play About Dick Gregory
text: John Legend, the Oscar-winning musician, has signed on to produce a new Off Broadway play about Dick Gregory, the influential comedian and civil rights activist.

headline: For One Los Angeles Designer, Jewelry Mingles With Fine Art
text: For the designer Kathryn Bentley, jewelry is as much about sculpture as it is fashion, thanks to a background in academic fine art and an affinity for raw materials. Her brand and four-year-old store in Silver Lake, Dream Collective, is evidence of her magpie eye, and serves as an indicator of her latest influences: She stocks everything from stoneware peace pipes by the artist Ben Medansky to the cult perfume range by Coqui Coqui. “I am rarely looking at other jewelry,” she says. “Art is my inspiration. And how things are made — the actual hands-on part of it. That’s what is interesting for me.”

headline: At Home With Kathryn Bentley in Montecito Heights
text: The jewelry designer, sculptor and owner of Dream Collective takes T on a tour of her midcentury home.

headline: Republicans Channel the Bundys With Federal-Land Bill
text: Say what you will about Utah’s delegation to the House of Representatives, they don’t negotiate with insurrectionists, terrorists or common criminals. They waited a whole month after a group of armed fanatics seized control of federal lands in Oregon, threatening to kill federal or local law officers, before they gleefully took on the criminal gang’s demands as their own cause.

headline: Seattle Man Descends From 80-Foot Tree After 24 Hours
text: Equipped with snacks and warm clothing, an agitated man climbed an 80-foot sequoia tree in downtown Seattle and defied efforts to bring him down for more than 24 hours before finally descending Wednesday.

headline: These Apps Promise to Encrypt Your Smartphone Communications
text: THE topic of smartphone security and secure communication is front and center these days, thanks to the battle between Apple and the F.B.I. over opening up an iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino, Calif., mass attackers.

headline: Exploring the Cordillera de los Frailes in Bolivia
text: In the Cordillera de los Frailes of Bolivia, the Jal’qa people commune with another world.

headline: In the Mountains of Bolivia, Encounters With Magic
text: With a face as creased as a walnut shell and a smile as gleeful as it was toothless, 98-year-old Augustina Lamagril welcomed us into the small shop inside her adobe home. Rickety wooden shelves were stocked with sardines, cigarettes, beer, soda, kitchen utensils, light bulbs and other household goods. Beneath posters of the Virgin Mary and baby Jesus, two metal-framed beds were heaped with blankets. From the ceiling — rice sacks that had been stapled together — the corpses of hummingbirds dangled from strings, drying.

headline: What Canada Learned From Rob Ford (and What America Could)
text: Nearly everything about Rob Ford, the former Toronto mayor who died on Tuesday at 46, was text, needing little subtext. He looked like a character in a Coen Brothers film: corpulent, corrupt, but with a clear knack for physical comedy. Tossing a ceremonial football, he’d trip over his own feet. Trying to dash around the City Council room, he’d plow into a mild-looking woman in a kelly green suit. Something about the picture of him standing with his crack-cocaine dealers added texture to his story. It is impossible to imagine what would have happened if that mind had been implanted in another sort of body.

headline: Malik Taylor, Phife Dawg of A Tribe Called Quest, Dies at 45
text: Malik Taylor, the wry and agile rapper known as Phife Dawg, who as a member of A Tribe Called Quest brought left-of-center hip-hop to the masses, died on Tuesday at his home in the San Francisco Bay Area. He was 45.

headline: The Kitchen Announces Spring Season
text: Joan Jonas, whose “They Came to Us Without a Word” at the Venice Biennale last year was seen as a triumph, will bring a version of the work to the Kitchen to open its spring season.

headline: Names of the Brussels Victims Emerge Online, One by One
text: In the hours after the deadly suicide bombings in Brussels on Tuesday, relatives and friends of Léopold Hecht, a Belgian college student, were hoping that he would emerge safely from the chaos. Without his cellphone, maybe, and perhaps in a hospital bed, but safe.

headline: Obama Declares a New Partnership After Talks With Argentine Leader
text: BUENOS AIRES — President Obama on Wednesday declared a fresh era of partnership between the United States and Argentina, saying he stood ready to support Mauricio Macri, the country’s new president, in his bid to improve the nation’s economy and credibility on the world stage.

headline: Credit Suisse’s Too-Long Road to Recovery
text: Credit Suisse is closer to making acceptable returns for shareholders — but it has taken too long a road to get there.

headline: Uncovering the Links Between the Brussels and Paris Attackers
text: At least two of the attackers are believed to have had roles in both plots.

headline: Musical Adaptation of ‘Roman Holiday’ Aims for Broadway
text: A musical adaptation of “Roman Holiday” will be staged in San Francisco during the spring of 2017, with a planned transfer to Broadway that fall, the show’s producers said Wednesday.

headline: Brussels Attacks Rekindle Debate Over Airport Security
text: PARIS — In the hours after the attacks in Brussels on Tuesday, many countries quickly added soldiers and police officers at airports and rail and subway stations, hoping to reassure passengers and deter other potential terrorists.

headline: Alabama Governor, Robert Bentley, Denies Having Affair With Aide
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama acknowledged Wednesday that he had made inappropriate and sexually charged remarks to one of his closest aides, but he denied an accusation that he and the woman had pursued a physical relationship.

headline: For the Bulls, Change Has Not Been for the Better
text: An N.B.A. playoff team with a great defense and a building-block star fired its polarizing coach and replaced him with a rookie coach who had been a sharpshooter in the 1990s. It was a recipe that worked so well for the Golden State Warriors that the Chicago Bulls went out and did virtually the same thing a year later.

headline: Poll Suggests Donald Trump Would Be Weak Candidate in November
text: Donald J. Trump would be the weakest Republican presidential candidate to face off against Hillary Clinton in a general election matchup, according to a new poll that shows Senator Ted Cruz and Gov. John Kasich as stronger nominees against the Democratic front-runner.

headline: Valeant Has Few Options to Remove a Recalcitrant Director
text: Howard B. Schiller, the former chief financial officer and a current board member of Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, refuses to leave quietly, and a quirk in the laws makes it likely that he will be around a bit longer.

headline: Risky Rats Give Clues on Brain Circuitry Behind Taking a Chance
text: When people make risky decisions, like doubling down in blackjack or investing in volatile stocks, what happens in the brain?

headline: Steps Arranged by Women, With History, at Dance Theater of Harlem
text: Lately, the world of ballet has been scrutinized and criticized for two things: its lack of diversity and the paucity of female choreographers. Dance Theater of Harlem has the first one covered. This season, it will do something about the second.

headline: A ‘Festival Summit’ by Hunter
text: LONDON — Last December, Hunter — the British wet-weather brand — announced that it was giving up its slot on the London Fashion Week schedule.

headline: Lead Problems Elsewhere Prompt New York Schools to Show Drinking Water Is Safe
text: Following the discovery of high levels of lead in the water in Newark’s schools, New York City is unveiling a website where parents can track the results of lead testing in its schools.

headline: Voices From Brussels and America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fight to Keep Alternative Energy Local Stymies an Industry
text: COWGILL, Mo. — Up and down the center of the country, winds rip across plains, ridges and plateaus, a belt of unharnessed energy capable of powering millions of customers, with enormous potential to help meet national goals to stem climate change.

headline: Demography Is Destiny? Teaching About Cause and Effect With Global Population Trends
text: There’s a common saying: Demography is destiny. It holds that population trends and distributions determine the future of a country, region or even the entire world. For example, if the human population increases too fast or too slowly, or if there are too many young or old people, then certain outcomes are likely to follow, such as economic boom or bust, political unrest or mass migration.

headline: Brussels Attack Victim, Olivier Delespesse, Remembered as a Devoted Colleague
text: When Olivier Delespesse, who was seldom late, did not show up for work on Tuesday, his colleagues said they began to worry. They made desperate appeals on Facebook to find him.

headline: From Paris, With Vinyl: Courrèges, Space Age Pioneer, Flies Again
text: Lapin à la moutarde (rabbit in mustard sauce) is a grandmotherly French classic that has not yet had a wide revival among those New York restaurants that have made a fetish of pork belly and foie gras.

headline: Roger Goodell Calls C.T.E. Link to Football Consistent With N.F.L.’s Position
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., affirmed statements made by a top league executive who said that football-related head trauma was linked to brain disease.

headline: Bookshelf: Look and Do Touch
text: New interactive picture books by Robert Sabuda, Britta Teckentrup and more.

headline: Why You May Want a Smaller iPhone, and Your Questions Answered
text: It is hard to turn back after going big. When people moved up to big-screen televisions, nobody wanted to switch back to small TVs. Larger computer monitors have also ruined smaller screens for many people.

headline: Joe Weisberg and Joel Fields Discuss ‘The Americans,’ Ronald Reagan and Pastor Tim
text: Once mostly anonymous, the producers who oversee top television series have sometimes become as well known as the actors who star in them. On occasion, The New York Times will pose questions from readers (and some of our own) to notable showrunners.

headline: A 16th-Century Home in Riga’s Old Town
text: The property, which served as a barn and a warehouse before its renovation in 2012, is on the market for $3.62 million.

headline: A Quandary for Europe: Fighting a War on ISIS Within Its Borders
text: LONDON — When the United States declared war on Al Qaeda after the Sept. 11 attacks, American leaders took the fight to the militant group’s hide-outs in Afghanistan, a faraway and failing state, with an invasion and occupation.

headline: The New Citrus: Spring’s Bergamot-Infused Fragrances
text: Light, fresh and slightly masculine, the Italian fruit invigorates these four new  perfumes.

headline: The Outsize Role of Brothers in Terrorist Plots
text: In terrorist attacks around the world, pairs of brothers keep turning up as suspects.

headline: Paul Ryan Addresses Political Clashes, but Not Congressional Gridlock
text: WASHINGTON — In an address billed as an examination of the future of politics, Speaker Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin on Wednesday admonished politicians in both parties for debasing political discourse, urging candidates to lift their gaze toward matters of serious policy and to strive for civility.

headline: Where There’s Smoke, There’s Stagecraft
text: The barometric pressure affects it. So do the whims of air-conditioning systems. Under the wrong circumstances, it could get whooshed into the crowd the moment the curtain rises.

headline: Face-Off Between Strongmen Exposes Afghanistan’s Political Rifts
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In northern Afghanistan, a dispute over billboard portraits of the country’s vice president has inflamed tensions between two of the most powerful regional strongmen, exposing internal political strains even as the government faces a dire challenge from Taliban offensives.

headline: Fitness Entrepreneur Pleads Guilty in Wire Fraud Case
text: Joshua B. Newman, the serial fitness entrepreneur with the knack for self-promotion, is now a felon.

headline: Family Sees TV Talent Scout Where Israeli Authorities See Jihadist Spy
text: JERUSALEM — The young man was on his way out of Gaza on an innocent-seeming mission: to scout potential contestants for his embryonic “Palestinians Got Talent” television show and meet the show’s West Bank staff in Ramallah. He had an Israeli permit for the journey.

headline: Moynat Sets Up Shop on Madison Avenue
text: On Thursday, Moynat, the French luxury travel-goods house, will open a New York shop. Inside a cathedral-like space in one of the 19th-century brownstones just south of the old Whitney Museum, you will find the 160-year-old heritage label’s full range of women’s and men’s leather goods and accessories, luggage and textiles, including a store-exclusive Danse bag in supple nubuck leather inspired by the rectangular volume of a classic trunk ($3,593). At 937 Madison Avenue.

headline: U.S. Should Follow Canada’s Lead on Heroin Treatment
text: VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA — The crisis that led officials in Ithaca, N.Y., to consider opening a supervised-injection center for heroin users, part of what the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has called a national epidemic of overdose deaths, is sadly familiar to us here.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: The News with Andrew Rosenthal
text: Times editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal talks about Brussels, a proposal to exploit land in Utah and Game of Thrones

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: The News with Andrew Rosenthal
text: The Times’ editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal talks about Brussels, a proposal to exploit land in Utah and Game of Thrones

headline: Review: ‘Batman v Superman’ ... v Fun?
text: What an adversarial time this is. Hulk Hogan versus Gawker. “The People v. O. J. Simpson.” Bernie versus Hillary. Trump versus Everybody. And now Batman versus Superman. One of these things is not like the others, I know. Two of the most famous good guys in pop culture can’t really be enemies, can they? The Gotham Bat and the Man of Steel inhabit the same intellectual-property universe, and the fight between them is, depending on how you look at it, either a diabolical stunt cooked up by Lex Luthor or a cynical cash grab engineered by DC and Warner Brothers.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Says He Will Retire After 2017 Season
text: Alex Rodriguez has been in the major leagues for over two decades, will turn 41 in July and has compiled an incredibly complicated résumé that includes the fourth most career home runs in baseball, three Most Valuable Player Awards and a yearlong drug suspension.

headline: Hillary Clinton Dismisses Rivals for ‘Reckless Actions’ in Foreign Policy
text: In her most vigorous assault yet on her Republican rivals, Hillary Clinton on Wednesday ridiculed the foreign policy prescriptions of Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz, calling them “reckless actions” that would alienate America’s closest allies, demonize Muslims and empower Russia.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | Mom/Not Mom/Aunt
text: In the 11th episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actor Jesse Tyler Ferguson (“Modern Family,” “Fully Committed” on Broadway) reads “Mom/Not Mom/Aunt” by Jerry Mahoney.

headline: Boston Lyric Opera Announces Itinerant 2016-17 Season
text: The Boston Lyric Opera, which is leaving its longtime home at the Shubert Theater, announced on Wednesday that it would mark its 40th anniversary next season by presenting four operas on four different Boston stages — including the East Coast premiere of Calixto Bieito’s staging of Bizet’s “Carmen” — as it continues to search for a permanent home.

headline: Ted Cruz Deplores ‘Liberal, Left-Wing Values’ While Lobbying for New York Votes
text: Senator Ted Cruz spoke in a stately reception hall — with two chandeliers, cushioned seats and what appeared to be a gilded eagle — as a vendor out front, on Manhattan’s West 51st Street, sold knockoff bags and heavily discounted wool hats.

headline: Republican Pennsylvania Senator to Meet With Merrick Garland
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Patrick J. Toomey, a Pennsylvania Republican facing a difficult re-election fight in a Democratic-leaning state, said Wednesday that he would meet with Judge Merrick B. Garland, an apparent response to calls for him to consider President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee.

headline: Yi Fuxian, Critic of China’s Birth Policy, Returns as an Invited Guest
text: BEIJING — Eight thousand miles is a long way to fly someone so he can tell you you’re wrong.

headline: Journalist Jailed in Eastern India Over Social Media Post
text: NEW DELHI — A journalist in eastern India was arrested after he posted a message on social media criticizing the police and calling for legal protections for reporters in the violence-scarred region, his lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: Doug DuBois’s “In Good Time”
text: The photographer’s work goes on view this week at Aperture Foundation, presented by the Hermès Foundation.

headline: Everyday Portraits That Go Beyond Intimacy
text: “If my work was as good as an Hermès bag, or sold as much, well, that would be nice!” jokes the photographer Doug Dubois. But Hermès has offered a different kind of validation for Dubois’s intimate portraiture: Cory Jacobs, who’s served as the label’s go-to photography curator for the last seven years, has curated Dubois’s first midcareer survey, “In Good Time,” which opens this week at the Aperture Foundation in New York.

headline: Prosecutor Won’t Seek Prison for Peter Liang, Ex-Officer Convicted in Killing
text: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office announced on Wednesday that it would not seek prison time for the former New York City police officer convicted last month in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man in a housing project in East New York.

headline: Let’s Bring Back the Spring Coat
text: Denim and leather will never go out of style, but try welcoming the new season with a change. Plus: mesh socks and a smart new Polish label.

headline: Review: ‘The Caped Crusade’ and Batman’s Reach Beyond — Gasp! — Comic Book Lore
text: A few days ago, I would have said that the world could be divided into two types of people: Those who think deeply about the hermeneutics of Batman, and those who do not. That was before reading Glen Weldon’s “The Caped Crusade: Batman and the Rise of Nerd Culture.” I’m now of the mind that there’s a continuum from normals to nerds. I land somewhere in the middle.

headline: Brighter Lights, Bigger City: The Odeon’s Second Act
text: The publisher and TriBeCa resident Judith Regan was in her reliable old neighborhood restaurant the Odeon the other day when she smelled something different in the air, and it certainly wasn’t a new entree on the menu.

headline: Inside the Button Shop
text: Tender Buttons is in a tiny Manhattan townhouse, but it may house millions of buttons, practical, whimsical and collectible.

headline: Cure for the Lost Button
text: If everything else were destroyed, buttons would not be a bad representation of the last few centuries of human history. They have recorded, in miniature, the French Revolution, the construction of the railroads, whaling voyages and countless modern fascinations: dogs, cartoons, telephones, martinis.

headline: Bruins’ Stempniak Brings Long Résumé and New Uniform to Garden
text: Lee Stempniak, a 33-year-old Boston Bruins forward (and former Blue, Maple Leaf, Coyote, Flame, Penguin, Ranger, Jet and Devil) arrived at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday for the 782nd game of his much-traveled N.H.L. career.

headline: Joe Garagiola, a Catcher Who Called a Better Game on TV, Is Dead at 90
text: Joe Garagiola, who spent nine forgettable seasons in the major leagues as a weak-hitting catcher and then parlayed his witty tales of life as a baseball underachiever into a far more notable career as a folksy broadcaster and television personality, died on Wednesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 90.

headline: Donald Trump Accuses Muslims of Ignoring Terror Plots in Their Midst
text: A day after Islamic State terrorists detonated suicide bombs in Brussels, Donald J. Trump, the leading Republican presidential candidate, said that Muslims bore responsibility for such attacks because they had been looking the other way.

headline: Phife Dawg: An Everyman Hero of Hip-Hop Stands Proudly Small
text: Hip-hop excels at poeticizing excess. Wealth, toughness, libido, swagger: The more of it there is, the thinking often goes, the better the song will be.

headline: Turning Discarded Items Into Art About Race in America
text: The Los Angeles artist Rodney McMillian has an ambivalent relationship with mass-produced home furnishings. On the one hand, he has rescued several examples from oblivion, like the time-ravaged lounge chair he wrestled into his car on a corner of Sunset Boulevard and later declared an artwork — untouched, stuffing spewing forth. It’s the kind of ready-made that Duchamp might have chosen if he had grown up in a working-class African-American family in Columbia, S.C., as Mr. McMillian did.

headline: Postcards to Donald Trump Show Deep Support and Reservations
text: ST. LOUIS — On Tuesday night, a group of Republican and Republican-leaning voters here had a decision to make about Donald J. Trump.

headline: Review: ‘De Materie,’ of Matter, Spirit and Sheep
text: Surely this is the first opera production to include 100 sheep among its performers. Heiner Goebbels’s staging of Louis Andriessen’s “De Materie,” which originated in 2014 in Germany, arrived in the vast Drill Hall of the Park Avenue Armory on Tuesday, with dozens of sheep from the Pennsylvania countryside in its cast.

headline: Progeny of the Rolling Stones Make Their Mark
text: As band members are mythologized in a coming museum exhibition, their scions make their cultural presence felt.

headline: Review: Juan Siddi, With His Own Troupe, Makes a Return
text: It had the makings of a triumphant return. A young dancer first appears at the Joyce Theater in New York as a new member of a respected company. Thirteen years later, he comes back with his own troupe, named after him.

headline: South Street Seaport Museum to Receive $4.8 Million
text: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation will give $4.8 million to the South Street Seaport Museum, which is recovering from severe damage incurred four years ago when Hurricane Sandy flooded streets around the seaport, according to state and museum officials. That damage came as the museum was just beginning to emerge from a decade of economic difficulties.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Brussels, Flint, Batman
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Mudslinging Trumps the ‘Middle Way’ in Tibetan Exiles’ Election
text: DHARAMSALA, India — It is often said that the lower the stakes, the more vicious the politics. And so it might be said of the just-concluded campaign for political leader of the Tibetan government in exile, which, given the exalted status of the Dalai Lama, was a bit like voting for the vice president to a sitting president.

headline: As Terrorists Cross Borders, Europe Sees Anew That Its Intelligence Does Not
text: PARIS — If another example of the failure of European intelligence services to share and act on information about potential terrorists was needed, Wednesday’s identification of the bombers in the deadly Brussels attacks the day before certainly provides it.

headline: ‘Who’s Crazy?,’ an Obscure Avant-Garde Film Project, Is Reborn
text: There was a time in the late 1960s when artistic vanguards joined forces: Andy Warhol produced an album with the Velvet Underground, the rock star John Lennon teamed with the conceptual artist Yoko Ono, and Norman Mailer tried his hand at experimental films.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Girl, Instagrammed: The Web Animation of a Book Review Cover
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. Here, Pamela Paul, editor of the Book Review, takes us inside the creation of an animated Web-based illustration used in a review of “Girls and Sex” by Peggy Orenstein.

headline: Review: ‘The Catch’ Is a Glossy Game of Cat and Mouse
text: The 2015-16 television season has been a glossy one, full of shows about rich and powerful characters and their luxurious lives. Is there room for another? The schedulers at ABC think so, but the one they’re unveiling Thursday night, “The Catch,” seems from the premiere as if it could grow annoying pretty quickly.

headline: Son of Wrongly Cremated Woman Comes Forward, Resolving a Macabre Mystery
text: Annie Pearl Little, 82, died on Christmas Day. On the day of her funeral at McCall’s Bronxwood Funeral Home in the Bronx, the manager there called her only son, Donald Little.

headline: Other Stories of Funeral Home Mix-Ups
text: In response to an article about a funeral that included the body of the wrong woman in the coffin, readers wrote in to share similar accounts.

headline: Léopold Hecht, Actor, Law Student and Brussels Attack Victim
text: LONDON — Léopold Hecht was a second-year law student at the Université Saint-Louis in Brussels who enjoyed skiing and had a knack for acting.

headline: New York International Auto Show
text: Media previews began on Wednesday, with the unveiling of many new models. The show opens to the public on Friday and runs through April 3.

headline: Review: Daymé Arocena Mixes a Cosmopolitan Vibe With an Earthy Tone
text: The Cuban singer and songwriter Daymé Arocena was dressed entirely in white, the color of santería ceremonies, when she performed at Subrosa on Tuesday night, and she started her late set with a song invoking Yemayá and Ochún, the saints of oceans and rivers. Her voice opened up to approach the earthy, full-throated cries of Afro-Cuban ritual chants. But the music surrounding her was far from traditional. It was jazz from a piano-bass-drums trio, with the harmonic and rhythmic complexities of hard-bop and the melodic grace of Brazilian pop. Ms. Arocena unites cosmopolitan musicianship with deep roots.

headline: Review: Steven Page, an Ordinary Guy, Reflects on Middle Age
text: Steven Page doesn’t fit the image of a pop performer. Stocky, in his mid-40s, with a cherubic face and graying hair, he is a founding member of Barenaked Ladies, the boisterous Canadian pop band with a fervent cult following, which he left in 2009 after two decades.

headline: Review: Wadada Leo Smith and Vijay Iyer Share Their Influence Through Duets
text: “A Cosmic Rhythm With Each Stroke”

headline: Will the Supreme Court Buy Faulty Logic on Religious Freedom?
text: What is a “substantial” burden on religious freedom? For four Supreme Court justices, the answer may be: whatever a religious objector says it is.

headline: Review: Layers in ‘Tropix,’ From Céu
text: “Tropix”

headline: Liang Sentencing Letter
text: Ken Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, told a judge that his office was not requesting any jail time for Peter Liang, a former New York police officer convicted of manslaughter in a 2014 shooting.

headline: John Kasich Rejects a G.O.P. Call to Quit to Block Donald Trump
text: Republicans desperate to stop Donald J. Trump from capturing the presidential nomination increased the pressure Wednesday on Gov. John Kasich of Ohio to quit the race, with Jeb Bush joining the growing number of party figures throwing their weight behind Senator Ted Cruz.

headline: Ted Cruz, Day After Brussels Attacks, Belittles Donald Trump on Foreign Policy
text: Senator Ted Cruz on Wednesday relentlessly belittled the foreign policy acumen of Donald J. Trump, casting him as dangerous and ill prepared one day after the terrorist attacks in Brussels refocused the presidential race on issues of national security.

headline: Valeant Losses Push Ackman Hedge Fund Down 25% for Year
text: For investors in William A. Ackman’s Pershing Square Capital Management, the recent ride down continues to be hair-raising.

headline: Running on Vacation
text: On the second day of a recent two-week road trip, I woke up at a Holiday Inn off Interstate 95 in Santee, S.C., and drove to a nearby state park. I was in my fifth week of marathon training and needed to complete three miles, so why not do so in a new place I might never see again? I’ve run in many unfamiliar towns and cities — Chicago; Minneapolis; Seattle; San Francisco; St. Pete Beach, Fla.; Freeport, Me.; Rome — and each jaunt has given me a unique look at a part of the world I might have missed otherwise.

headline: ‘Shuffle Along’ and the Lost History of Black Performance in America
text: Ninety-­five years ago in New York, a journalist named Lester Walton bought a ticket to see a much-­buzzed-­about new show, a “musical novelty” that had opened about a week before at the Sixty-­Third Street Theater. Or the Sixty-­Third Street Music Hall, as it was more properly called. A kind of multipurpose performance space, not very big, not very nice, “sandwiched in between garages,” Walton wrote, and “little known to the average Broadway theatergoer.” You could rent the place for the night. It had philosophical lectures, amateur violin recitals and religious meetings, and during the day it showed silent movies: “ ‘Pudd’n Head Wilson,’ with Theodore Roberts, tomorrow.” But on this evening — and for many months to come, as it turned out — the stage belonged to an all-black show called “Shuffle Along,” a comedy with lots of singing and dancing. A problem: The music hall had no orchestra pit, and this show needed an orchestra. It needed space for the band, which happened to include a 25-year-old musician known as Bill Still, later to become the famous composer William Grant Still, but in 1921 a mostly unheard-­of young man from Arkansas, switching among the six or seven instruments he taught himself to play. The production was forced to rip out seats in the front three rows to make room. These were people used to improvising. Among themselves, they referred to the show as “Scuffle Along.”

headline: Rick Wilson Would Take Clinton Over Trump
text: You’ve gained lots of fans on the left thanks to your vicious descriptions of Trump and his supporters. Once, on MSNBC, you called his base ‘‘childless single men who masturbate to anime.’’ That was in reference to the alt-right part of his base. I wish I could take credit for it being a broader smear. If one is going to insult a group of people who think that Trump is their own private postmodern Hitler, one ought to be specific.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Hasbro Joy for All
text: Not long ago, a notable pet psychic told me that my cat might be possessed. There may be some truth to this. Whenever my cat hears the sound of a voice on speakerphone, she runs into the room with the fires of hell behind her eyes and sinks her teeth into my leg. Movie night in my home has become a twisted Pavlovian exercise, with my hand hovering above the mute button just in case a character needs to, for whatever reason, talk on a phone.

headline: Travel and Allergies: What to Do When Animals Are on Board
text: Allergies to peanuts, shellfish, dogs, cats and other triggers haven’t stopped 31-year-old Allie Bahn, a fourth-grade teacher and blogger from Boston, from living in Italy for three years and in Australia for seven months. She keeps medication and sanitary wipes handy. Still, she’s had mystery attacks while traveling, including a severe one last fall that forced her to flee a hotel in the middle of the night. Consequently, she prefers renting apartments, as she can interview the owners, and calls airlines in advance to determine her risk.

headline: The Queen of Entrees, Restored
text: I first happened upon it one morning, while flipping through the Time Life Foods of the World book ‘‘Classic French Cooking’’: a photograph of an alabaster edible dome, mosaicked in carrots and turnips, with molding of green beans and English peas, its base edged by slabs of bacon and sausage and glazed tiny onions, looking for all the world like a frosted vegetable cake. It was called a chartreuse. A few days after gazing on its strange countenance, for a different reason entirely, I found myself reading about La Grande Chartreuse — not a food but a monastery built on a white Alpine ridge, reached by a single road winding through a great massif into medieval clouds, in Roy Andries de Groot’s 1973 culinary travelogue, ‘‘Auberge of the Flowering Hearth.’’ And about the Carthusians, an old silent order of vegetarians who spend their days alone in cells. I became transfixed by the dish and the monks and resolved to find out what connected the two.
